Consequences: Negatively affects the choice, location and cost of land, affects pricing of feeds and planting materials, pricing of feeds and planting materials increased, influences acquisition of breeding stock, feed shortages impact the proper physiological functioning and body condition of breeding stock

Potential adaptations: Farmers to upscale afforestration to ensure 10% forest cover and enhance amount of rainfall, this makes land arable and more attractive for potential buyers, to upscale irrigation and conservation agriculture to improve water retention capacity of the soil, farmers practice climate smart livestock production using technologies like zero grazing

Consequences: Affects choice of land because areas prone to high temperatures are less attractive for dairy farming hence few farmers will invest in such areas, dry areas e.g Sirisia and Bumula, high temperatures affect pasture and fodder production leading to increase in feed and input prices, fewer heifers come into heat, increased chances of calf loss

Potential adaptations: Farmers to upscale and maintain intensive dairy farming technologies to mitigate against high temperatures, farmers to upscale to modern technology of nursery management and maintain resistant fodder/pasture varieties, farmers to upscale use of modern farming systems and computerized dairy management systems

Consequences: High temperatures lead to less feed production hence dung and biogas production is reduced, high temperatures cause withering and drying of pastures and fodder leadingto low milk and general farm productivity

Consequences: It affects land preparation because of formation of hard pans, affects availability of feeds during dry periods affecting nutrition of the animal and its productivity

Ongoing adaptations: Farmers use afforestration and small scale irrigation to improve on soil wetness, farmers are using irrigation and drought resistant pasture/fodder varieties to mitigate high temperatures, farmers practice zero grazing, farmers are practising modern zero grazing technologies that guard against high temperatures and also use hormone boosters (injectables) to enhance fertility of breeding stock
Potential adaptations: Farmers to upgrade irrigation technologies and improve on forest cover to improve soil moisture, farmers to upscale use of irrigation technologies and plant resistant varieties at an enhanced scale, farmers to upscale the use of zero grazing technologies and modern breeding technologies like hormone boosters

Consequences: During dry spell we have low production of feeds hence inadequate supply for future use, drying of feeds for storage is affected during low moisture period, extreme moisture conditions affects milk production either in shortage or less milk for bulking
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers use crop residues and shrubs to supplement the feed during dry season, farmers use conserved feeds and commercial feeds to improve milk production, formation of dairy cooperatives
Potential adaptations: Farmers to upscale use of alternative feeds e.g use of crop residues and wastes, feed supplements to cushion against feed shortage, farmers should upscale feed conservation strategies and use of feed supplements to improve milk production, upscaling irrigation in feed production

Consequences: High temperatures interfere with silage making, excess heat and over fermentation, high temperatures lead to low yields due to heat stress, it also leads to milk spoilage during transportation and bulking
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are storing hay and making silage under shades so as to reduce loss of moisture and overfermentation of silage, farmers use metallic cans and improved plastic containers and cooperatives, use chilling tanks to control fresh milk temperatures, farmers are practising clean milk production, transportation and processing by observing  hygienic standards, farmers are also using coders at milk collecting centers
Potential adaptations: Farmers need to upscale technologies of hay and silage making and use of modern stores, farmers and dairy cooperatives to invest in cold chain and cooling facilities to maintain low temperatures, farmers to upscale to modern technologies in milk processing and packaging like UHT and good management systems like HACCP

Consequences: Increases mortality and inaccessibility of farms, makes roads inaccessible thus increasing transport costs, causes supply delays and spoilage
Ongoing adaptations: Increasing packaging materials to transport chicks, use of motorbikes to access market on impassable roads, they prepare own feed rations on their farms, use of ox-carts, motorbikes, and tuktuks, use of service providers who are trained to vaccinate the birds, buying vaccines from local agrovets
Potential adaptations: Improve road networks, construction of more hatcheries close to farmers for better accessibility, maintain on farm feed ration and commercial feeds, feed manufactures should be localized for easy access, use of drones to deliver vaccines to farmers, training more farmers on vaccination so that they can do without assistant

Consequences: The availability of would be very low for chicks to hatch, it will affect availability of feeding material
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are using incubators for hatching chicks, using other birds for hatching e.g ducks, currently raw materials are obtained from their own farms, farmers are using their own feed formulation, use of fridge to store vaccines, extension officers training farmers and agrodealers
Potential adaptations: Commercial hatcheries, introduction of new chicken breeds in the market, use of commercial feeds, to have more farmer field schools and trainings, ownership of deep freezers to store vaccines

Consequences: Reduced access to markets, affects appearance of birds (i.e quality of live birds) thus bought at low prices from farmers, increases market prices since there are less suppliers, rainfall causes incurance of high cost during promotion such as destruction of posters
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers sell at low prices due to curling, use of social media, radio, word of mouth and use of other print media such as newspapers, farmers go to distant markets to sell their produce at good prices, farmers slaughter the chicken and sell them later instead of selling a live chicken which can be easily preserved
Potential adaptations: Hold stock and sell when market conditions have improved, research and sell in other counties, form cooperatives for higher bargaining power, use of social media, maintain and improve use of radio, word of mouth and relavant print media, county government should facilitate exports, improve road infrastructure, create market structures that are specifically for chicken (a modern market other than  the open market currently available), add value to the chicken by slaughtering and dressing

Consequences: Low weight hence low prices of the chicken, less poultry to sell or advertise thus demand higher than supply, high demand leads to fast-moving stock
Ongoing adaptations: Proper feeding to acquire the right weight by own feeds, farmers ensure regular vaccinations of their stock to prevent diseases, word of mouth by farmers, social media platforms e.g phones, WhatsApp, radio, online and social media services to contract buyers, special orders are delivered to the buyers at his cost and refferals
Potential adaptations: Encourage farmers to use commercial feeds, social media, brochures, magazines, and mass media as means of selling, formation of producer organizations

Consequences: Excess rainfall cause mild hypothermia thus disease causing bacteria are bred e.g cocadia, brooding costs are high as heat and feeds are highly consumed, high feed intake,  increased vaccination costs
Ongoing adaptations: Use of brooding pots, jikos and bulbs to regulate temperatures by providing heat, construction of special brooding units e.g 3 ply, brooding mekos, practice intensive management whereby the chicken do not go out in the rains, some farmers curl the stock and retain few
Potential adaptations: Use of modern brooders that have temperature regulators, train farmers on proper brooding, provide more affordable modern brooders, use of brooding pots (made of clay) to prevent charcoal wastage, use of solar heaters, train famers on available technology and how to use it, provide subsidized solar heaters most farmers should practise intensive management, vaccinate the stock before onset of rains

Consequences: Leads to low feed intake thus slow growth rate, causes high mortality rate, the chicken feed less and take more water since dehydration rate is higher
Ongoing adaptations: Constructing fowl runs that allow proper air circulation (well ventilated), vigilance in isolating sick and weak birds and administering drugs, regulate temperatures by proper ventillation, give sufficient anti-stress (amintotal) drugs to cope with heat stress, appropriate packaging and transportation of the vaccines like use of cool boxes, trained farmers administered vaccines on their own
Potential adaptations: Construction of morden poultry structures, installing temperature sensors and controllers in the existing poultry structures, conducting trainings to educate farmers on available technology, incorporating anti-stress in feeds, adaptation to new technologies like advanced temperature regulators, farmers training on use of anti-stress agents, discipline in following prescribed instructions on the vaccines, avail cold chains such as deep freezers in every ward, vaccinating on time and involving technicians for efficiency

Consequences: Incur high cost during transportaton and makes the roads almost impassable, causes contamination and delays, waterproof materials required, labor requirements for packaging increase
Ongoing adaptations: Use of smaller means of transport such as motorbikes to access hatcheries, farms and markets, construction of major access roads which reduce distance, aggregation or collection centers near markets, commercial entities have slaughter slabs, farmers do them in doors or under shades convered vechiles for live birds, water proof materials inducted in packaging of processed birds, aerated vans and packages for chicks
Potential adaptations: Use of air transport (drones), renovation of air strips in all counties, construction of more roads, incorporation of slaughter lines in aggregation centers, meat inspection section should be in the slaughter lines, induction/expansion of more non-carcinogenic packaging materials for processed birds, increased capacity capability of packages (boxes, crates) and vehicles

Consequences: For live birds it increases mortality rate and perishability for already processed birds, high bleeding hence the meat quality is reduced (also blood clots due to high temperatures affect meat quality)
Ongoing adaptations: Use of ventilated trucks and vans for chicks and live birds, use of refrigerated vans for already processed birds, aerated boxes used by farmers, and incorporate use of ice (freezers used), timing of slaughtering which is done during cold hours e.g morning or periods, commercial slaughtering lines, more packing materials used and more space occupied in the vans for the same quantity of chicken
Potential adaptations: Collection center/aggregation centers equipped with cold rooms, high capacity incubators (5000 eggs), fabrication of aerated carts that can be fitted to smaller means of transport such as bikes, aggregation centers incorporated with slaughter lines where temperatures can be regulated, refrigerated equipments used thus increasing quantity of processed birds at the collection centers, trucks and vans equipped with temperature regulators at collection or aggregation centers

Consequences: Increased demand for seeds due to increase of quantities used per farm thus increasing seeds prices and hoarding, high cost of production due to increased amount of fertilizer used, scarcity due to high demand leading to increased prices and leaching of nutrients
Ongoing adaptations: Early purchase of certified seeds and use to tolerant varieties, use of organic (farm yard manure), increased use of inorganic fertilizers, and use of foliar fertilizers, reduced pesticides use as rainfall controls fall army worm
Potential adaptations: Early purchase of certified breed tolerant seed varieties, slow release inorganic fertilizer, use of semi-culture technologies (rapid decompostition for production of organic manure), development of resistant varieties

Hazard: Variation in planting season/ uncertainty in rainfall patterns
Consequences: Variation in planting season requires new seed varieties that are torelant thus causing seed inadequacy which in turn increases prices, causes shortage of fertilizer supply thus increasing prices, low supply of and high demand for specific pesticides leads to a counterfeit market
Ongoing adaptations: Use of early maturing varieties, early purchase of seeds and use of hybrid seeds, use of organic manure, early purchase of fertilizer, use of recommended fertilizers, and soil testing, use of IPM and organic pesticides, use of cultural methods to predict pest infestation and early planting of the crop
Potential adaptations: Use of new improved drought and disease resistant varieties, use of recommeded fertilizer after soil testing and building capacity for farmers through TVETs, policy on soil testing for all farmers, early scouting of pest and diseases and use of recommeded certified pesticides

Consequences: Leads to low produce price and low demand due to low market, high cost of transportation due to poor roads, decreased accesibility of some production areas, and deteoriation of produce quality due to delayed access to market
Ongoing adaptations: Early selling (disposal) to get good prices and selling to NCPB, use of motorcycles, use of animals (donkeys and ox-carts) and use of tractors, individual traders look for produce, middlemen bridging between farmers and traders and use of social media e.g WhatsApp
Potential adaptations: Contract farming, use of early maturing and resistant varieties, construction and upgrading of roads to make them passable, decentralization of storage facilities e.g NCPB and millers, formation of marketing association, contract farming and construction of aggregation centers

Hazard: Variation in planting season/ uncertainty in rainfall patterns
Consequences: Fluctuating prices, high demand and unstable supply, high demand and insufficient means of transport increase cost of transport, unreliable market information leads to poor linkages along the value chain
Ongoing adaptations: Early harvesting (green maize) and proper sorting and grading, use of motorbikes and use of motorized equipments e.g tractors, lorries, information sharing on market by use of mass media
Potential adaptations: Contract farming with millers, building of bulking centers and synchronized harvesting of the crop, use of social media e.g Facebook, WhatsApp and emails

Consequences: Excess rainfall leads to high cost of land preparation (many times at high price), formation of hard pans in the soil and increased soil erosion, high cost of planting due to wet and muddy soils, high cost of weeding due to prolification of weeds, leaching and soil erosion, increased labor costs at harvest, increased losses due to rotting
Ongoing adaptations: Multiple land preparation and use of ox-drawn and manual land preparation, manual planting, early planting, multiple manual weeding, stacking of maize before dehusking
Potential adaptations: Conservation agriculture, use herbicides to control weeds, use of hand held planters, use of combined harvestors (mechanization)

Hazard: Variation in planting season/ uncertainty in rainfall patterns
Consequences: High cost of land preparation because of repeat cultivation and build up of pest and diseases, poor crop germination and occurrence of invasive pests
Ongoing adaptations: Early land preparation, conservation agriculture and use of farm machinery, planting of early maturing varieties, early weeding, early planting and dry planting, early harvesting, and harvesting at the right maturity index
Potential adaptations: Use of climate smart agriculture and weather forecasting given by KMD, conservation agriculture e.g minimum tillage and use recommeded chemicals (e.g herbicides), use of farm machinery for maize harvesting

Consequences: Increases cost due to increased labour, increases post harvest losses (rotting) due to high moisture, causes poor quality due to broken grains and stalks, high cost due to increased labour, causes increase in post harvest losses leading to poor quality produce
Ongoing adaptations: Use of small motorized threshers and use of hand labour, sun drying on canvas directly and selling of green maize, use of gunny bags and storing in houses
Potential adaptations: Use of combined harvestors, promote mobile solar driers, motorized driers for high quantities of maize, use of hermatic storage bags, use of small metallic silos

Hazard: Variation in planting season/ uncertainty in rainfall patterns
Consequences: Reduced maize quality because of broken grains, high cost of drying and afflatoxin control due to rains during harvesting (mostly in Mt. Elgon)
Ongoing adaptations: Use of fabricated small motorized machines, and use of varieties that have good threshing traits (H 513), use of sun drying on canvas and harvesting maize at full maturity, use of hermatic bags for storage, well aerated storage space, use of storage cluster and disposal of maize immediately after harvesting
Potential adaptations: Tractor mount threshing, use of combine harvestors (for harvesting, threshing and winnowing), development of new varieties with threshability traits, use of dryers e.g solar driers (portable), use of metallic silos for storage, use of hermatic bags and NCPB- government storage facilities

Consequences: Delayed marketing, tuber scarcity, increased market prices, missed market opportunities, damaged infrastructure
Ongoing adaptations: Marketing using local media, trade negotiations(using mobile phones), value addition of marketed products(flours), cassava flour enrichment(groundnut flour)
Potential adaptations: Farmers encouraged to form marketing groups, contractual farming, county support to link farmers to potential buyers/external markets, farmers and technical staff taken for an educational tour (exposure), county assisted marketing of tuber produce, promote value addition

Consequences: The wetness will  result to feeds caking and spoiling and hence cause diseases/aflatoxins and the birds will die, feeds in the garden will get spoiled due to a lot of water, the wetness will result to regular cleaning of the equipment and transfer of pests and diseases, decreased rooding/breeding activities, increased demand of extension services
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are using local available material to feed their birds, use of local materials in cleaning poultry water, use of wood shavings, husks and beddings, farmers are vaccinating their birds on the most devastating of diseases, most do it by themselves
Potential adaptations: Access quality feeds from recognised suppliers and stockists, supplement feeding with other farm supply(clean) to reduce costs, put up clean equipment, use of cleaning disinfectants to clean the equipments, vaccinate birds before diseases outbreak through vet personnel, construct raised houses, repair of rural access roads

Consequences: Increased feed costs, because of high temperatures will affect vegetation and insects for supplement feeds, high water intake by birds, weight loss in birds due to poor feeding during heat stress, scarcity of water used for cleaning purposes, increase in pests and diseases in poultry houses hence thorough cleaning and disinfection is required
Ongoing adaptations: Use of leftovers and farm by products like vegetables and ugali to feed the chicken, water harvesting during the farming season, use of litter material in houses, frequent cleaning of poultry equipment and disinfection, use of compound vaccines i.e covers more than one disease, use of thermostable vaccines that do not require vaccines
Potential adaptations: Producing termites stovers to supplement proteins during heat stress periods and maggots at farm levels, planting poultry feeds like sunflower/soybean/millet, use of raised houses for easy elimination of  droppings and proper hygiene, fumigation of poultry houses using chemicals like formaline to prevent pests and diseases, synchronisation of hatching whereby farmers produce chicks in batches for easy and economic vaccinations

Consequences: Low production as feeds will be less prices of chicken will increase due to low supply, low weight hence poor prices, reduced market activity/linkages
Ongoing adaptations: Use of public gatherings and use of posters for marketing, observation of the chicken, using hands to determine chicken weight, selling of live birds, value addition at markets liked cooked chicken(fried/roasting)
Potential adaptations: Promote marketing(electronic/print media), contracted marketing, differentiated chicken parts sales(instead of whole)

Consequences: Challenges in land succession(identification/adjudication and acquisition), the fertilie soil is eroded leading to top soil loss, planting materials-erosion can affect the tubers and weaken the stem hence leads to fall, high labour demands
Ongoing adaptations: Construct soil and water conservation structures e.g fanya juu and fanya chini terraces, mulching, use of cover crops
Potential adaptations: Promote gabions construction and tree planting, research on improved varieties, agroforestry, use of cover crops

Consequences: Less birds available for collection, low egg/meat viability(increased egg spoilage), more space required for the birds due to the high temperatures, high transport costs due to low numbers of birds transported, bodaboda/vehicles will have less income as work will be less, specialised/well ventilated cages will be required for transporting birds
Ongoing adaptations: Use of farmers groups and cooperatives, use of transportation baskets made from reeds with proper ventilation, improved storage(refrigeration/ice cubes), roasting and deep frying, weighing using hands to determine chicken weight
Potential adaptations: Sharing of information by word of mouth, use of multi storeyed transport cages to accomodate bigger numbers of birds to save on the transportation costs, use of ice cubes to preserve slaughtered chicken meat in transit, use of weighing scale, standard meat processing(per weight/kg)

Consequences: Limited market access, low prices, low market/marketing linkages
Ongoing adaptations: Timely promotion/marketing by use of local radio media(mulembe fm, bulala fm), establish local marketing linkages (through brokers)
Potential adaptations: County support to seek external marketing, establish county controlled pricing policies, promote print/electronic marketing(phones, newspapers), external education tours (exposure tours)

Consequences: Very expensive and delay in marketing processing-post harvest losses-rotting, damaged storage structures
Ongoing adaptations: Transport- use improved transport to storage facilities e.g 4 wheel drive pick ups, use of solar driers, timely processing done early before on set of rains, storing-use of hermatic bags, piece meal harvesting
Potential adaptations: All roads must be maintained, access to improved storage facilities(community owned), cooperatives to buy trucks and lorries, credit farmers/processors to purchase solar driers, have more processing machines-individuals to cooperatives, capacity build on use of hermatic bags, county support to provide silos

Consequences: Delayed harvesting, the roads and bridges will be affected or washed away hence leading to delay in marketing and processing, increased incidence of post harvest losses
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of caravats, road repairs, construction of foot bridge, timely processing, harvesting and storage, use of hermatic bags
Potential adaptations: The county government must ensure that roads are well maintained and bridges are well constructed, farmers to be  given processing machines by financial institutions, the county to put up warehouses and solar driers

Consequences: Birds affected by heat stress reduce in production, this is especially in tin sheet roofed and wooded housing, reduced laying of eggs, low viability of eggs and spoilage, increase in pests which affect chicken during brooding especially mites, reduced natural feed sources(insects/green biomass), increased water requirements
Ongoing adaptations: Grass thatched houses for chicken, use of egg trays and proper positioning of eggs in the tray i.e air space exposed for proper breathing, local feed formulation to avoid the movement and costs of acquiring feeds from stockists, vaccines storage in flasks
Potential adaptations: Insulation of iron sheet roofed houses to reduce temperatures

Consequences: Limited access to markets, low sale prices by farmers, low marketing linkages/opportunities, increased transport costs to markets, high market costs by brokers/traders
Ongoing adaptations: Chicken sale in open air markets, use of local marketing channels(promote bird sales), individual poultry pricing, groups pricing(farmers within cooperatives), hoarding(market speculation)
Potential adaptations: Repair of damaged roads, marketing through e-platforms and print media, farmer groups for collective farmer bargaining, county support to explore better market outlets(supermarkets/tourist/hotels/schools)

Consequences: Leads to high labor requirements due to hard pan in the soil, leads to poor germination, low labor output-farmers will weed slower, interferes with the root system of the crop
Ongoing adaptations: Pre stocking seeds prior to planting for improved germination, draught animal practices are used, weeding early in the morning, harvesting is taking place in the morning, conservation agriculture, organic farming, mulching, intercropping and agroforestry
Potential adaptations: Mechanisation to reduce the high labor intensity, use of short shelf life seeds, conservation agriculture to be practiced, improve terms and conditions of engagement for better delivery of services, promote agroforestry and organic farming

Consequences: Makes transportation costs very high as many require special mechanised tools or machines, increased post harvest losses(rotting/aflatoxins/germination), damaged storage structures, high energy costs(seed drying), limited access to labour
Ongoing adaptations: Use of hired/household labor, early harvesting, store on raised platforms/granary for unshelled maize, drying when floods subsidize, wait for the floods to subsidize, shift to higher grounds
Potential adaptations: Construction of drainage structures, use of metallic silos, use of hermatic bags, access to protective clothing, county support for hire of machinery for harvesting, shelling and packaging

Consequences: Human labor is affected because the work output is low(harvesting/winnowing/shelling and packaging), causes post harvest losses e.g weevils attack and the greater grain borer if not properly preserved, low quantity and quality of harvested grain
Ongoing adaptations: Use of motorbikes(local transport), use pesticides, proper drying of maize, seed storage in moisture free spaces, use of hermatic bags, harvesting in the morning, engage family/manual labour at harvesting
Potential adaptations: On farm processing, mechanised harvesting, enhanced use of hermatic bags, use of ventilated stores, use of gunny bags compared to synthetic bags, promote large scale milling by producers, use of hand held maize shellers

Consequences: Labour scarcity, high labour costs, limited access to certified seeds/inputs(low demand)
Ongoing adaptations: Awareness and education through campaigns, farmers obtain local seeds from fellow farmers, seed is purchased from KALRO especially early maturing varieties, use of low quality farm manure, access to poor quality agrochemicals
Potential adaptations: Enhancing soil and water conservation on farms, improved land management(agroforestry), use of early maturing and local drought resistant seeds, establish a workable county climate information service, ensuring constant supply of chemical fertilisers by the government, encourage farmers to use farm manure

Consequences: Removes the topsoil, loss of nutrients and applied fertilisers, loss of planted seeds
Ongoing adaptations: Agroforestry, terracing, increase depth of planting to protect seed
Potential adaptations: Afforestation and agroforestry, improve on extension services to farmers, training on seed protection once planted

Consequences: Delay in land preparation/planting, increased incidence of flooding and waterlogging, crop damage(hailstones/rotting), increased weed incidence
Ongoing adaptations: Early land preparation, early planting, using early maturing varieties, removal of diseased plant material, timely weeding, use of herbicides, mulching, intercropping, crop rotations(cereals), seed selection before planting
Potential adaptations: Crop insurance, enterprise diversification(groundnuts), capacity building gap(pest and disease control), introduce policies to regulate mechanized land preparation,  access to early warning systems, intercropping, mulching

Consequences: The birds will delay or not brought to the centres/slaughter facilities due to poor roads, delayed egg collection, low quantities of eggs, increased incidence for egg spoilage(moisture, dirt)
Ongoing adaptations: Use of bicycles and bodabodas(local transport) to transport chicken, farmers use simple wire cages and baskets, household slaughter
Potential adaptations: Repair roads for efficient accessibility, need to have better cages to transport the birds, better means of transportation i.e lorries, establish local slaughter houses to facilitate bird delivery, formation of farmer cooperatives

Consequences: Delay in access of cuttings, flooding/waterlogging-delay in cutting and even planting, hailstones cause destruction
Ongoing adaptations: Opening of water dams, water harvesting (water pans/furrows), proper timing in planting, early acquisition of material, cut the crops affected in the field, do timely preparation, ploughing and early planting
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on water harvesting, introduce irrigation pumps-solar pumps, build underground tanks, planting materials-increase bulking sites and contracting farmers, insurance cover against hailstones, capacity building on early planting/seed selection

Consequences: Low prices due to reduced quality of produce, affected by sand storms, damaged roads hamper movement, reduced market linkages/opportunities
Ongoing adaptations: Local grain sales(farm gate/along maize corridors), grain marketing through public media(radio) and local market channels(word of mouth), sell to external markets through middlemen and brokers
Potential adaptations: Mechanical sorting of produce, proper packaging equipment to improve produce market quality, county support to form organized farmer groups at village levels(collective marketing), inspection of grain weighing equipment(scales)

Consequences: Low quantity and quality of harvested grain, increased post harvest losses(pest/rodent damage), high transport costs, labour scarcity(harvest, threshing, packaging), reduced labour efficiency
Ongoing adaptations: Winnowing, threshing and sorting at farm level using household or hired help, gunny bags, home silos and granary for storage, farm gate sales to avoid losses
Potential adaptations: Have mechanised threshers to minimise losses, mechanisation of sorting and winnowing and grading, improved and oxygen free bags, construct county wide storage facilities(NCPB)

Consequences: Top soil is washed away, loss/ destruction/carry away the planting materials, low tuber establishment, delayed agronomic practices
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of water conservation structures, plough/planting along the contuors, planting in ridge, use of chemicals, mulching, intercropping, cover crops, agroforestry
Potential adaptations: Increase no of machines such as tractors (mechanized farming), county support to improve access to inputs and agricultural machinery, counties and ministries of agriculture to ensure that farm machines for making ridges are available

Consequences: Increased input demand/cost (drugs, moisture free poultry structures), limited input access(due to damaged infrastructure), increased transport costs
Ongoing adaptations: Iron roofed, muddy and brick walls are used for poultry houses, some farmers have started using clay pots and hay brooder boxes although the number is small, some farmers keep breeding stock/breeding chicks, farmers are using local available feeds to supplement feeding of birds
Potential adaptations: Improved model houses from local resources(timber/stone), introduce climate friendly structures like brooder boxes and brooding pots to be warming houses, promote insulated poultry structures, farmers to be trained on bird breeding, repair rural access roads to access better transport, stockist to be near farmers

Consequences: Exposure of rock soil to the surface/land degradation, loss of soil cover, soil nutrients and water holding capacity, seed loss(damage by pests and diseases), low stand counts, increased weed prevalence, crop nutrient competition with weeds, loss of crop vigour
Ongoing adaptations: Provison of tree seedlings and beehives for enterprise diversification, use of leguminous plants which are deep rooted for intercropping, use of conservation agriculture, staggered planting, terracing, covering manure/fertilizers after planting, timely planting
Potential adaptations: Capacity building in agro forestry, provision of apiculture in hilly areas, promote weather advisory, efficient extension services, explore strategies for curbing seed loss after planting, training on manure compositing

Consequences: Due to flooding travelling will be hard hence limited access to market, high transportation costs, low sale prices by farmers, low marketing linkages/opportunities, high market costs by traders/brokers
Ongoing adaptations: Local produce selling(farm gate/along maize corridor), delayed marketing activities(until flooding recedes), produce marketing through public media(radio) and to local institutions
Potential adaptations: Construct raised stores, county support for roads repair(market access), promote rehabilitation programmes for cereal markets, value addition of grain produce(oil/wines/poultry feed), crop insurance scheme

Consequences: Movement is interfered with, more fuel consumption hence high transport costs, storage facilities may collapse/get damaged with time, increased post harvest losses(rotting/pre-germination), increased seed losses at winnowing, increased cost of structural maintenance
Ongoing adaptations: It is done locally by women through winnowing, sorting and grading(gender biased labour), residents store food produce in their residential houses to reduce theft, use of gunny bags, use of local materials for storage(wood, nylon, bricks), use of bicycles and motorcyles
Potential adaptations: Establishment of grain processors at village level all over the county, establishment of collection and transport systems, introduce post harvest grain inspection programme, capacity building on post harvest storage, value addition and packaging

Consequences: Weight of produce is reduced(mass per unit volume), increases producer losses, reduced market spoilage, reduced market/marketing activities, increased need/demand for shade/shelter in markets
Ongoing adaptations: Bulk buying and selling, hoarding product for price speculation, farmers rely on middlemen and brokers to get market for sorghum, vendors have made makeshift shades at the markets
Potential adaptations: Policy information on binding and legal contacts, encourage bulk buying after value addition, regulated cereal pricing, construction of modern markets, county support for external markets

Consequences: Soil degradation(reduced soil cover, organic matter and microbial activity), poor germination, seed loss(pests/disease damage), reduced fertilizer efficiency, delayed agronomic activities, increased labour costs
Ongoing adaptations: Use of mechanical and animal draught(ploughs), hand weed control, early land preparation, intercropping, tree planting, crop rotations, staggered cropping, use of manual/household labour
Potential adaptations: Regulate use of rotary tillers, promote efficient weed control practices, access to weather advisory, access to efficient mechanized equipment(tractors), promote widespread FYM use

Consequences: Increased seed spoilage(premature germination/rotting), decreased labour requirements and availability
Ongoing adaptations: Land is left barren since seeds do not germinate in floods and hence no adaptation option has been carried out, use of traditional maize varieties, non use of mineral fertilizers
Potential adaptations: Drainage of flooded areas, plant in raised areas, access to fast maturing varieties, promote adoption of early warning systems

Consequences: Affect micro organisms in the soil, temperature affects the soil structure-leads to less soil moisture in the soil  hence affecting the viability of the seeds, lack of water, decreased demad for seed/fertilizer inputs
Ongoing adaptations: Organic fertilisation is being adapated since it retains moisture and maintains soil structure, use of certified seeds from reliable sources and agrovets, working early in the morning and late in the evening and shortening working periods, seed recycling
Potential adaptations: Training farmers on compost manuring, introduce and enhance agro forestry, use of certified seeds from a reliable recognised and registered agrovets, use of shorter shelf life seeds, extension officers to make often/regular visits, improve terms and conditions of engagement for better delivery, use of the right labor i.e men instead of children/vulnerable women

Consequences: Limited chances for farmer linkages, decreased producer prices(low quality), increased transport costs to the market, grain scarcity in markets, increased sale prices(brokers/traders)
Ongoing adaptations: Formation of farmer marketing groups and cooperatives, use of middlemen/brokers and farmer to farmers word of mouth marketing, participation in linkage meetings, carry out activities under natural shades, county support to supply to external markets(millers), contractual farming
Potential adaptations: Organised promotion and targeted marketing, promotions through media use (public media, e-platforms, bulk sms), selling in well packaged container, county support in constructing market shades, regulated maize pricing to curb farmer exploitation

Consequences: Deteriorated soil condition(water logging), reduced seed germination/poor stand establishment, decreased agronomic activities(weeding/spraying)
Ongoing adaptations: Land is left bare, reseeding, staggered planting, early planting, agroforestry, farm drainage structures(furrows), planting in raised beds, use of mechanized labour, intercropping
Potential adaptations: Drainage structures(canals/pans/dams), enterprise diversification to fishing/horticulture, promote intercropping, agroforestry, county support for machinery hire(land preparation/planting)

Consequences: NA
Ongoing adaptations: Storage of seeds from previous season, early purchase of fertilisers
Potential adaptations: Sharing of weather forecast information from meteorological information and department, capacity building on pesticides use

Consequences: Reduced animal feed supply, low production and supply of milk for bulking/collection
Ongoing adaptations: Production for subsistence, buy from other sources, source milk beyond their catchment areas, lay off workers during low season
Potential adaptations: Promote purchase and use of high quality stock, capacity build on importance of builking and chilling, promotion of value addition

Consequences: Difficult transportation due to wet roads, high transport cost, increased disease incidence, increased cost of pesticide
Ongoing adaptations: Using farm saved seeds, early procurement, early acquisition of fertilizers, use of organic manure, some cooperatives help farmers in bulk purchase
Potential adaptations: Having seed multipliers closer to farmers, stocking of seeds, taking fertilizers to farmers at ward level, strengthen cooperatives, introduce disease resistant varieties

Consequences: Low egg production, due to increased feed costs, reduction of green vegetables increases demand for eggs and chicken
Ongoing adaptations: Destocking and use of alternative sources of feeds, market the surplus
Potential adaptations: To be trained on feed preservation (when plenty) for use during scarcity

Consequences: Hampered packaging: increased costs of transportation due to impassable roads, reduced product quality hence poor prices
Ongoing adaptations: Putting in an open space and spreading it out, selling the produce at farmgate, immediate disposal to nearest market, local consumption
Potential adaptations: Bulk transportation to maintain product quality hence good price, proper market information and linkages provide good product prices, farmers to form a group to negotiate for better prices, improve roads to all weather

Consequences: Delayed land preparation, washing away of seeds and leaching of fertilizer
Ongoing adaptations: Minimum tillage by use of herbicides, manual land preparation and weed control by uprooting, cutting-back; late planting
Potential adaptations: Early land preparation, restoration of soil and water conservation structure, continued use of early warning information for decision making, use of county agricultural machinery sevices, draining the seed beds properly, encourage crop rotation

Consequences: The roads become impassable hence accessing the market becomes difficult
Ongoing adaptations: Storage, facilities increase number of eggs incubated per bird
Potential adaptations: Group marketing for egg selling

Consequences: Delayed harvesting, difficulty in threshing and winnowing, high moisture content generates vulnerability to moulds/rotting, increased cost of drying:
Ongoing adaptations: Piece meal harvesting to enable/facilitate drying and minimize losses, immediate disposal to the market
Potential adaptations: Encourage appropriate small scale drying technologies, alternatively encourage selling of green beans to avoid moisture problems when waiting for it to mature fully

Consequences: Excessive loss of moisture reduces product weight hence low income, pest damage risk, prolonged drought leads to price speculation
Ongoing adaptations: Immediate disposal of the produce, disposing wihout sorting, price taking(disposing at the proposed/offered price from the buyer)
Potential adaptations: Use of hermeatic bags(polythene-lined), training on pre and post harvesting management techniques

Consequences: Difficulty in land preparation due to wet soils, difficulty in planting leading to increased cost, high frequency of spraying and weeding increasing production costs
Ongoing adaptations: Spraying with herbicides, increased labour, early land preparation dry planting, increased labour, use of meterological information, earthing up soil, spraying to control pests
Potential adaptations: Mechanized farming before the rainy season mechanized planting at the onset of rains, share information from the relevant departments to many farmers apply pre-emergence herbicides, introduction of pest /disease resistant varieties

Consequences: Feeds become depleted hence expensive:  local feeds are depleted low expenses on disease control
Ongoing adaptations: Reduce the stock by selling so that they will not die, use locally available materials, market the surplus
Potential adaptations: Farmers to organise themselves to sell the poultry in bulk and train them on home made feed rations, use of savings as an insurance measure

Consequences: Prolonged drought leads to diversion of seed and fertilizer funds to other immediate pressing needs affecting the vulnerable group in the society
Ongoing adaptations: Use of recycled seeds, planting without fertilizer or sometimes using manure
Potential adaptations: Timely and accurate information services on drought resistant varieties

Consequences: Not enough moisture for good germination lack of uniformity and one cannot spray stressed crops
Ongoing adaptations: Early planting
Potential adaptations: Farming god's way (conservation agriculture) minimum or zero tillage, supplementary irrigation, mulching to conserve soil moisture, mechanization in planting, introduce drought tolerance varietes. Conservation agriculture, irrigation

Consequences: Increased market outlets, low advertising because poultry and its products are sold with ease
Ongoing adaptations: Quick sale of produce once it has been harvested in an uncoordinated manner between farmers
Potential adaptations: Organise group marketing, improvise on market pricing, advise farmers to save on other hard times

Consequences: High rainfall leads to more production hence market glut, low prices due to high supply:
Ongoing adaptations: Middlemen play the roles of linking the farmer to the market, selling to middlemen, transporting and selling direct to the market and export to tanzania and uganda
Potential adaptations: Strengthen marketing associations and cooperatives, having information platform strengthen cooperatives and marketing associations, construct cold storage facilities, contract farming strengthen cooperatives and associations to add value to potatoes, invest in processing factories

Consequences: Ease in land preparation in some areas while others may expereince hard pans, delayed planting due to inadequate soil moisture, delayed weeding
Ongoing adaptations: Late land preparation, planting during the onset of rains, irrigation, postpone weeding
Potential adaptations: Land preparation after harvesting to avoid formation of hard pan, early warning information, use early maturing varieties and drought tolerant varieties, efficient irrigation and integrated weed management

Consequences: Roads to advertising places become impassable hence low sales and income, the posters are washed away by the rains
Ongoing adaptations: Selling poultry and its products locally, individual to individual marketing
Potential adaptations: Group strategy to marketing and to come up with technology to storage, promote internet marketing especially for youth, opening outlet at strategic places

Consequences: Low production of chicks and death(extreme cold and water logged areas kill the chicks), increased maintenance cost,roads to shopping agrovets become inaccesible
Ongoing adaptations: Buy chicken/chicks from neighbourhood/local farmers, farmers staying with chicken in the same house and use of portable traditional made chicken coup, using kitchen and garden waste
Potential adaptations: Group approach for poultry production i.e introduce hatcheries to produce as a group, build a well designed chicken coup using locally available materials, group approach to poultry production.

Consequences: Supply of commercial poultry feeds decrease, disease incidences increase hence cost of control goes up, cold weather is not conducive for brooding
Ongoing adaptations: Full free range system, use of local herbs e.g aloe vera, pepper, sell chicken once there is an outbreak of diseases, using enclosers (homemade) to protect the chicks from cold/rain and predators
Potential adaptations: Training on homemade poultry feeds and supplimentation, use of group approach in sourcing drugs/vaccines for chicken, synchronise the periods for vaccination, training on disease management and housing

Consequences: Poor accessibility to seeds, accessibility to fertilizer is poor
Ongoing adaptations: Use of donkeys, tractors and human beings to transport the inputs,  opting for an alternative enterprise
Potential adaptations: Stocking of seeds and facilities within the locality through stockists and farmer cooperatives, improve roads to all weather status, availing information on weather

Consequences: Reduced milk quality and income, difficulty in milk collection and bulking
Ongoing adaptations: Milking in the open and poor constructed structures, collection at the road side, use of motorcycles, donkeys, tractors and four wheel vehicles milk is sold at the formal local market, preparation of sour milk
Potential adaptations: Capacity build farmers on clean milk production, construction of milk parlours and zero grazing units construct enhanced milk collection structures and improve road netwok, capacity build on group milk marketing

Consequences: High moisture spoil/reduce quality of animal feed, high pests and diseases hence high cost of treatment.low milk production, inaccesibilty of ai
Ongoing adaptations: Timely planting and harvesting, vaccination, treatment, sraying and dipping, from bull services to subsidized ai services
Potential adaptations: Constructing modern feed structure, timely planting and harvesting,capacity building on feed formulation, enhanced routine vaccination, spraying, dipping and deworming, make vaccination free, add more vets, zero grazing units, ai services, strengthen farmer organizations

Consequences: During dry season chicks survive and hence sold cheaply, expenditure on poultry feeds increases, local feeds are depleted
Ongoing adaptations: Improvising on locally available feeds  (remnants and plant residues)
Potential adaptations: Familiarise with management of poultry to increase survival of stock for the new farmers, group strategy to buy as a group from millers

Consequences: Delayed harvesting: high wastage and poor quality, inaccessible roads which delay collection, increased cost of transportation, when harvested during wet conditions tubers carry a lot of soil hence poor storage quality
Ongoing adaptations: Harvested tubers are left to dry before selling/storage, use animal draught/power and human labour to transport the tubers. Farmers sale immediately after harvest, delay harvest
Potential adaptations: Strengthen cooperatives to acquire cleaning and drying machineries, improve feeder roads to make them all weather, encourage storage to attrach better prices, construction of cold stores

Consequences: Low yields:  poor yields due to misture stress hence less produce for sale poor quality and low supply for processing: due to poor yields
Ongoing adaptations: Linkage by middlemen, individual farmers are trying to access the market, selling through middlemen
Potential adaptations: Empowerment of marketing association and cooperatives, introduction of sms platforms, strengthening of cooperatives and marketing associations, construction of processing plans, capacity building on value addition

Consequences: The infrastructure is affected, difficult to reach feeds, delayed feeds, mobility of extension officers & ai is affected
Ongoing adaptations: Use of locally available feed materials and mineral licks, borrowing from neighbours, calling for extension service providers , use of available bull schemes, use of available subsidized ward ai service providers
Potential adaptations: Conservation and storage of feeds, start farmer groups and cooperative societies. Training, deploying more extension officers and use of ict in extension, proper government policy, intensify ai services providers upto locational level, farmer organizations to store for their own service

Consequences: Low milk prices, high milk spoilage and wastage. Reduced income; limited demand
Ongoing adaptations: Selling to hawkers, formal and informal markets
Potential adaptations: Provision of milk coolers, improve road network, formation, capacity building, strengthen of farmer groups on marketing channels

Consequences: Clean tubers, sorting and easy grading and transportation, roads are passable
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed harvesting waiting for better prices
Potential adaptations: Mechanized harvesting and sorting, setting up collection centers and stores, construction of more cold storage facilities

Consequences: Supply is low low volumes of milk for distribution hence high milk prices
Ongoing adaptations: Sell directly to hawkers and consumers, group sales, sell milk to loyal or contracted customers, source milk from distant sources
Potential adaptations: Promote milk value addition for cooperatives, promote advocacy and market research and linkage groups for sustained milk supply

Consequences: Inadequate animal feeds and mineral supply:  reduced feed supply, high demand and cost of extension services
Ongoing adaptations: Use of crop residues, cattle salt, tree branches, forest grazing and migration to relatives in fair areas, use of indigenous technology and knowledge, use of ict
Potential adaptations: Introduce new fodder production technologies e.g hydroponics, pooling resources to acquire and stock feeds/suppliments, use of ict, strengthen farmer cooperatives

Consequences: Pasture failure hence scarcity of animal feed, increased cost, high pests and disease incidences, low breeding
Ongoing adaptations: Keep of indigenous traditional knowledge in disease treatment, irregular spraying and vaccination, keeping of disease resistant breeds, use of bulls (natural services)
Potential adaptations: Capacity build farmers on feed conservation, storage and proper animal husbandry, improved vaccination and disease control measures, proper fertility management, quality feeding and mineral suppliments

Consequences: Harvesting is easier since the crop will dry adequately, dry spell will lead to pods split open thus spillling the beans hence losses, harvesting can be difficult due to soil compaction,  increased storage pest damage
Ongoing adaptations: Harvest crop early in the morning to reduce shattering, immediate disposal of the produce
Potential adaptations: Further research for bean varieties that dont shatter when dry, use of hermatic bag (polythene-lined bags).

Consequences: Increase seedling loss after planting and incidence of pest and fungal diseases, high labour costs for pest/disease control, reduced growth rate from poor soil property/condition
Ongoing adaptations: On farm water harvesting, supplement water supply, bucket irrigation, increase plant population, intercropping, agroforestry, use of pesticides, replanting
Potential adaptations: Improved access to irrigation facilities(drip irrigation), breeding for shorter duration, disease tolerant and high yielding varieties

Consequences: Low prices for milk sale due to oversupply and low quality (watery milk)
Ongoing adaptations: Local(farm gate and community) milk sales, engagement with community associations for sale of milk
Potential adaptations: Introduction of programs for external milk sale, establishing community based milk reserves and cooperatives for negotiating activities in milk value chain

Consequences: Milk and meat reduction, reduced processing volumes, high incidences of milk spoilage, reduced household milk reserves
Ongoing adaptations: Installation of coolers and refrigeration facilities, value addition(proceesing to fermented and reconstitute dry milk), scale down milk processing plant operation during milk scarcity, enterprise diversification
Potential adaptations: Establishment of cooperatives to facilitate profitable milk sales, increased storage capacity for powdered milk, installation of coolers and processing plants

Consequences: Maize prices will be higher hence challenging grain processors arising from low yields and high local demand
Ongoing adaptations: Grain outsourcing for processing operations, sale of grain locally(farm gate and within local communities)
Potential adaptations: Establishment of cooperatives to facilitate profitable marketing by producers, weather based index insurance schemes to cushion grain losses

Consequences: Reduced work hours and poor sanitation, high disease incidences, increased labour costs, destruction of housing units, reduced quality of feed sources
Ongoing adaptations: Vaccinations, deworming, prophylatic treatment, repair of animal husbandry structures (sheds/housing), improved housing e.g concrete floor, establishment of fodder trees, afforestation, advice from bulletins, extension and development agents, feed conservation
Potential adaptations: Community based livestock mass vaccination/new vaccines, research and development on adaptive(disease resistant) breeds, improved waste processing, modernized livestock housing, capacity building on improved feed technologies

Consequences: Low seed viability, low quality and quantity of organic manure
Ongoing adaptations: Use of indigenous seed preservation techniques (ash) as an alternative to pesticides to control soil borne pests, use of certified seeds, removing the manure and leaving it to cure
Potential adaptations: Promotion and use of certified seeds and seasonal purchase to avoid loss of seed viability, preservation and conservation of manure

Consequences: Increased incidence of soil pests, loss of soil fertility inputs, increased labor cost due to tilling hard pans, faster growth of weeds
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed planting, terracing, replanting, cover crops intercropping, agroforestry, use of animal(oxen) and maual labor(farmer groups) for land husbandry activities, application of fresh organic manure at planting, conservation agriculture, advice from extension services
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on manure preservation techniques, research on drought tolerant varieties, mechanized farming to reduce soil pests, diversification to other adaptable/profitable crop varieties, improved access small scale irrigation equipment

Consequences: Milk spoilage due to inadequate storage facilities and poor transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Mechanization of milking process, existing graded roads ease transportation challenges, coolers and refrigeration facilities installation, value addition processing (fermented and powder milk)
Potential adaptations: Introduction of dairy levies from milk sales for road maintenance, extend road network, introduce programs to absorb excess milk

Consequences: Lack of access to inputs (certified seeds, fertilizers, chemicals for pests and diseases )
Ongoing adaptations: Use of indigenous seed supply (neighbor to neighbor), use ash to treat their seeds, use of treated seeds
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on water harvest, use of certified seeds soil sampling

Consequences: Hard pans from reduced soil moisture and compaction, high labour costs on tilling and ploughing, poor stand establishment(seed loss through pests, rodents), poor soil quality and soil erosion, weeds prevalence
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed/ staggered planting, terracing and mulching to control soil erosion, replanting, manual weeding, diversification of livelihoods, application of organic and inorganic soil fertility inputs, crop rotation, agroforestry, advice from early warning systems, tree planting, land leasing
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on water harvesting and the use of intergrated pest management, strengthen the farmer diversification of livelihoods through capacity building e.g starting small businesses to kiosks, capacity building on small scale irrigation farming, research on drought tolerant varieties, improved access to advisory

Consequences: Delayed planting time and seedlings takeoff, delayed application of fertilizers, increased infestation of sucking insects and diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Mulching of planted seedlings, on farm water conservation, agroforestry, intercropping with cover crops, chemical insecticides, biological (predatory) control
Potential adaptations: Hedge tree planting  to act as live wind breaks, access to drip irrigation, research on pests and diseses control systems, access to improved water harvesting technologies

Consequences: High milk prices due to increased demand and low supply, reduction in marketing activities
Ongoing adaptations: Diversion of milk to local and household consumption, scarcity of household milk results to changes in eating habits e.g porridge and githeri
Potential adaptations: County and state government support to source for external milk markets, capacity building on regional milk marketing opportunities

Consequences: Water scarcity, increased costs of feeds, poor sanitation, increased disease incidence, animal malnutrition and poor growth rates
Ongoing adaptations: On farm-feeding, fodder conservation, feed supplementation, drought resistant fodder varieties, improved water harvesting and storage facilities(pans), mass vaccinations, capacity building on animal husbandry, weather based index insurances, improved access to advisory
Potential adaptations: Construction of water storage structures(dams), capacity building on strategies for improved feeding(irrigation, drought resistant fodder/pastures), research on improved cattle breeds, design of improved feed rations and supplementation strategies, modernized cattle housing

Consequences: Infestation by storage pests (large grain borer), poor quality and low grain yields, reduction in processing activities
Ongoing adaptations: Use of chemicals to control storage pests, use of traditional methods of grain preservation(use of ash)
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on the use of hermetic bags and silos, improved grain storage structures(granaries), improved access to government owned structures(NCPB silos)

Consequences: Low seed viability leading to poor germination
Ongoing adaptations: Planting of drought resistant seeds
Potential adaptations: Improved access to irrigation facilities for continous cropping, shifting from inorganic to organic farming

Consequences: Reduced market activities leading to low household incomes, high market prices(grain scarcity and high demand)
Ongoing adaptations: Local produce marketing at low farm gate prices
Potential adaptations: Training and empowering vulnerable groups on entrepreneurship and post harvest opportunities

Consequences: Increased grain prices due to high demand and low supply, reduction in marketing activities
Ongoing adaptations: Grain outsourcing for processing operations, sale of grain locally(farm gate and within local communities)
Potential adaptations: Establishment of cooperatives to facilitate profitable marketing

Consequences: Reduced fruit yields, reduced product shelflife, lack of storage structures, reduced opportunities in processing and value addition operations
Ongoing adaptations: Covering with green banana leaves to prevent moisture loss, construction of communal storage sheds for temporary fruit storages
Potential adaptations: Construction of cold storage facilities, use of refrigerated transporters, value addition activities

Consequences: Low production increases fruit market prices locally and externally, reduced market and marketing activities due to produce scarcity
Ongoing adaptations: Artificial water application, sprinkling produce with water to reduce the moisture loss of the fruits
Potential adaptations: Access to refrigeration and moisture controlled chambers, establishment of cooperatives and associations to facilitate marketing

Consequences: Increased cost of breeding cattle and breeded calves, reduced fodder production and water scarcity, unaffordability of disease and pest control inputs
Ongoing adaptations: Diversification to locally available feed, pest and disease control supplements, reliance on early warning systems
Potential adaptations: Establishment of county and communal drought funds, establish communal strategic feed reserves, support to access inputs through county government and aid organizations

Consequences: Difficulties in accessing inputs, limited access to artificial insemination, acaricides and feeds(pastures and concentrates)
Ongoing adaptations: Diversify transport to facilitate input access e.g use of boda boda
Potential adaptations: Improve infrastructure(all weather roads) to improve access to inputs, improved access to farm machinery, capacity building on feed conservation technology

Consequences: Increased seedling loss at nursery stage
Ongoing adaptations: Use of irrigation structures, laying shades-nets in nurseries, nursery establishment, utilizing soil treatment, drenching, use of pesticides
Potential adaptations: Automated drip irrigation, construction of improved seedling facilities(tissue culture)

Consequences: Infestation by storage pests (large grain borer), low grain yields and of poor quality, reduction in processing by millers
Ongoing adaptations: Application of storage pesticides, use of hermetic bags, use of ash for grain preservation, construction of food storage granaries
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on post harvest management strategies, construction and maintenance of storage structures(silos), increased availability of storage bags, research on efficient storage systems and structures

Consequences: Reduced marketable tonnage, insufficient raw material for post harvest processing
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of community fruit grading sheds, covering fruit with green banana leaves to prevent moisture loss
Potential adaptations: Construction of humidity controlled packing houses, access to refrigeration and moisture controlled storage facilities, value addition

Consequences: Poor quality seed hence poor quality establishment, inadequate seeds due to high cost
Ongoing adaptations: Use of drought resistant seeds, short maturing seed varieties, seed bulking, access to credit facilities for acquistion of farm inputs
Potential adaptations: Research on drought resistant seed varieties, wide-scale bulking for multiplication, improved access to credit facilities for acquistion of farm inputs

Consequences: Reduced market activities leading to low household incomes, high market prices(grain scarcity and high demand)
Ongoing adaptations: Establishment of strategic reserves at community and county levels, training and empowering our youth and women on entrepreneurship
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on grain marketing strategies and marketing opportunities

Consequences: Very poor yields caused by crop failure, delayed planting due to lack of seeds, reduced spraying due poor establishment
Ongoing adaptations: Conservation agriculture, harvesting water for irrigation, planting of early maturing varieties, diversification to other crops
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on conservation agriculture, breeding bean varieties tolerant to moisture stress, land leasing to more comercially-viable enterprises

Consequences: Low yields (poor quality and quantity), lack of labour opportunities from poor grain activities, household grain scarcity from crop failure
Ongoing adaptations: Diversification of other crops, application of storage pesticides
Potential adaptations: Construction of improved storage facilities, establishment of community and county based strategic grain reserves

Consequences: Poor yields caused by crop failure, loss of casual labor opportunities in post harvest grain handling e.g winnowing and grading, household grain scarcity, increased incidence of storage pests
Ongoing adaptations: Application of storage pesticides, diversification with other legumes
Potential adaptations: Adaptation training on new farming technologies in beans e.g green house training women and youth on other entrepeneurship activities

Consequences: Reduced agronomic perfomance through applied agrochemicals, hard pans increase labor costs
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed land preparation, delayed weeding in fear of disturbing soil, reduced yields due to wilting, zero tillage method of farming, planting of early maturing seed varieties, agroforestry, intercropping, crop rotation, crop loss protection through insurance
Potential adaptations: New intercropping strategies with newly emerging food crops, soil and water conservation, greenhouses and tree planting

Consequences: Reduced production output increasing the price, reduced household incomes
Ongoing adaptations: Sale of banana locally(farm gate/community) and on external markets
Potential adaptations: Establishment of associations for banana produce marketing

Consequences: High risk seedling loss at nursery level, reduced production of manure due to slow decomposition of organic matter
Ongoing adaptations: Use shade nets to cover up nurseries seedlings, use of organic manure and biograders e.g BM, EM
Potential adaptations: Enhancing water harvesting technologies, integrate banana farming with livestock farming, use of inorganic fertilisers to supplement fertilizers

Consequences: Crop destruction, water logging and washing away of the crops, delayed crop husbandry practices, delay in supply of inputs and harvesting
Ongoing adaptations: Avoid planting on the flood prone areas, flood receding-cropping pattern, early warning systems on expected flood occurrence and duration to guide crop management decisions, timely stocking of cereals, seeds by the stockists
Potential adaptations: Establish irrigation land away from the river banks-hinderlands, direct excess flood water to irrigated farms for integrated farming, staggered planting of maize so as to poduce when other areas have no green maize, make use of rain and boost with irrigation to reduce cost of production

Consequences: Low feed intake and performance, low body condition, score poor health, high morbidity and mortality, weak immunity, high milk spoilage
Ongoing adaptations: Pasture and fodder production (natural pasture), traditional husbandry practices, water harvesting micro structures(interval watering), use of local equipment(can/with cloth)
Potential adaptations: Use of tolerant varieties, formulate feed from local sources

Consequences: Low sales and income, fluctuation in prices
Ongoing adaptations: Individual marketing of milk on low scale, source from interior hinter lands, local processing of milk products to increase shelf life
Potential adaptations: Encourage group marketing of milk, processing in bulk during periods of plenty for sale during drought, livestock insurance programs

Consequences: Loss of pasture areas, water logging and soil erosion, increased outbreak of waterborne diseases
Ongoing adaptations: River bank protection through tree planting /preservation of tree cuttings, channeling of water in common dams/small dams
Potential adaptations: Construction of dykes/ditches along the rivers, construction of bigger dams (40.000m3) to prevent flooding

Consequences: High post harvest losses in the farms due to delayed harvesting, high incidence of aflatoxins
Ongoing adaptations: Use of donkey carts for transportation, early crop harvesting at physiological maturity
Potential adaptations: Use of group breed transport vehicles, open farm access, farm land processing and value addition

Consequences: Destruction of established crops, delay in land preparation and crop management practices, high costs of production incurred for labour and fuels to relocation and rehabilitation of farm machinery and infrastructure
Ongoing adaptations: Timely planting, conservation agriculture, use of manure to enhance soil water retention, strengthening river banks
Potential adaptations: Shade net technology to screen insects and reduce infections

Consequences: Total crop failure, reduced grain quality from pest damage, reduced income from cereals farming
Ongoing adaptations: Guarding and scaring of birds, wildlife to avoid loss, drying by use of sun-moisture content reduction, individual farmers distribution, diversification of crop enterprises
Potential adaptations: Early and timely harvesting of crop varieties that can be easily eaten by birds, introduction of moisture meters for moisture content, introduction of bulking and collection centres, use grain storage bags with pre treated insecticide, use of grain moisture meters to ensure correct storage moisture content and avoid afflatoxin contamination

Consequences: Delay in delivery of farm input, destruction of planting materials, delay in planting and application of fertilisers
Ongoing adaptations: Early maturing and fast maturing crops, high yielding crops e.g cowpeas and watermelon, certified seedlings
Potential adaptations: Green manure/drip irrigation, multistrorey gardening, screening technology(nets)

Consequences: Total crop failure, increased farmer-wildlife contact, increased crop farmer-pastoralists contact
Ongoing adaptations: Early planting, introduction of drought tolerant crop varieties, diversification of crop enterprises
Potential adaptations: Use of climate field schools to develop a cropping calendar to disseminate climate information, use of water harvesting technologies for crop production e.g zai-pits, promotion of specific value chain production approach

Consequences: Increased cost of feeding and watering, more cost on vaccines and drugs due to diseases outbreaks, deaths
Ongoing adaptations: Rechanneling of water array from farms, soil conservation(terracing, gabion, fanja juu ), presumptive vaccination and pest control
Potential adaptations: Creation of small/fish ponds within the farm, fodder/tree/grains, planting on the terraces, introduce large animals like cattle rather than sheep and goats, traditional preservation methods like Nyinyiri

Consequences: High milk spoilage due to build up of microbes, low quantities for bulking/transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Traditional postharvest methods e.g smoking equipment, transportation using public means and using local milk equipment
Potential adaptations: Processing, value addition, packaging transport using milk carriers(cooler vehicles), cooling plant, bulking, cans

Consequences: Inadequate quantities for bulking, collection and handling, inadequate supplies to take to market
Ongoing adaptations: Value addition, boiling and freezing, use of local milk, herding equipment, bulking of milk for sale, informal financing/borrowing, grants
Potential adaptations: Modern processing to new milk products-mala/yoghurt, use of appropriate equipment for milk handling, bulking and cooling using modern coolers/vehicle coolers, link to financial institutions, insurers

Consequences: Increased use of pesticides, reduced soil moisture, increased use of irrigation(fuel)
Ongoing adaptations: Supply of early maturing seeds/ drought tolerant crops e.g.water melon and cowpeas, certified seedlings
Potential adaptations: High yielding seed/crop e.g hybrid Kilele F1, Rio-grande, establishment of kitchen gardens e.g multistorey gardens, gravity fed large irrigation schemes

Consequences: Low animal vigour and productivity, loss of livestock, disease outbreaks from contaminated water
Ongoing adaptations: Fodder production, migration, water development-water pans, bore holes breeding and herd management selection, herd separation (milking herds)
Potential adaptations: Use of drought tolerant fodder grass varieties/high yielding/short maturity/feed, watering troughs at watering points to improve on water sanitation, strategic feed stores along water corridors

Consequences: Low quantity and quality of meat sold, low sale of processed meat
Ongoing adaptations: Reduced quantity of meat sold
Potential adaptations: NA

Consequences: Low carcass price, loss of income
Ongoing adaptations: NA
Potential adaptations: Livestock insurance programs, creating small/fish ponds within the farm to diversify farm production

Consequences: Reduced supply of cereals
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers market produce individually, immediate disposal of the produce after harvest, farmers dispose ther produce to the surrounding markets
Potential adaptations: Establishment of marketing group(communal village), utilize a valuable marketing information systems-SMS, web based, introduction of cooperative for collective marketing

Consequences: On farm animals death, reduced weight gain, poor body condition and low reproduction, increased costs of production due to disease management
Ongoing adaptations: Reduced number of watering days for livestock, reducing the herd or the stock and use vaccinations, internal and external parasite control
Potential adaptations: Use solar and wind generated pumps in boreholes and big water tanks, keeping camels in anticipation for drought, introduction of disease resistance varieties, establishing meat processors, breed improvement through selection for climate related shocks

Consequences: Increase in produce price, poor quality produce, loss of income
Ongoing adaptations: Food safety and handling, sourcing from outside county outgrowers
Potential adaptations: NA

Consequences: Decline in pasture quality and availability, decline in water quality and quantity
Ongoing adaptations: Migration to grazing zones reserve, desiltation of available water pans
Potential adaptations: Pasture conservation through hay/fodder banks, seed bulking to provide seed for pasture reseeding programs, WUA to formulate and enforce regulations/policies on water use and protect water catchments, access to grazing reserves in times of drought

Consequences: Inadequate pasture and water, low milk yield, low feed intake, reduced animal weight gain and reproduction, upsurge of diseases including(Trypanosomiasis, Pester Pester Ruminater(PPR), CBPP, PPR)
Ongoing adaptations: Feed supplementation using salt licks and available fodder
Potential adaptations: Integrated herd management to encourage pasture regeneration, pasture/fodder banks to conserve pasture, improved animal herds

Consequences: High losses due to spoilage, low sales due to low milk volumes
Ongoing adaptations: Diversification of enterprises, selling milk under open air conditions on market, use of organoleptic and ocular tests for quality assurance
Potential adaptations: Cooperative formation to pull together resources and linkages, spread risks and high bargaining power, promote sale of milk in designated sheds, promote opening milk dairies/bars, processing plants(small scale), use of testing equipment

Consequences: Farms are inaccessible, spoilage of produce, loss of yields
Ongoing adaptations: Cleaning, sorting and grading
Potential adaptations: Packaging and branding, forced ripening with ethylene and preservation through drying, building marketing sheds for fruit and vegetables

Consequences: High prices high demand, low prices at farm gate
Ongoing adaptations: Sourcing of produce from outside Garissa county, food safety and handling  standards
Potential adaptations: Develop cold storage syytems, processing to other products, formal credit facilities to support investment in fruit production

Consequences: Lack of pasture(malnutrition), low body condition, disease outbreaks and increase in internal and external parasites, reduced water availability
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of water pans and boreholes, pastures conservation, internal and external disease and pests control through vaccination
Potential adaptations: Piping of water and drilling more boreholes, growing and stocking of grains, maize, stovers and other fodder, keep drought tolerant animals like camels

Consequences: Low quality meat and meat products, reduced production
Ongoing adaptations: Infrastructure improvements(e.g grade access roads leading to slaughterhouses)
Potential adaptations: Improved road infrastructure for fast movement of livestock, reintroduction of livestock auctions to cushion farmers from animal loss
