Consequences: Reduced meat, increased processing costs due to the need of alternative sources of water
Ongoing adaptations: Reduced quantity of processed meat, use of local meat preservation techniques
Potential adaptations: Use of abattoir/slaughterhouse to ensure and enforce good hygiene standards

Consequences: Increased wildlife farmer conflicts, pests and diseases, increased production costs for irrigation, reduced plant vigour and stunted growth
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed planting of crops, conservation agriculture, irrigation and manure application
Potential adaptations: Having early information warning information to guide decisions in planting, irrigation and harvesting, enhance extension services to support new technologies, formal credit facilities to support investment in fruit and vegetable production

Consequences: High rate of spoilage due to high temperatures, poor packaging and reduced yields
Ongoing adaptations: On maturity harvest or physiological stage, cleaning, sorting and garding of produce at harvest
Potential adaptations: Cold storage and processing facilities

Consequences: Low supply of inputs, reduced purchasing power of farm inputs, reduced soil moisture to support plant growth, increased farmer-livestock-wildlife conflicts over forage and water, high incidence of storage pests, unscrupulous supply of ucertified seeds during drought recovery stage
Ongoing adaptations: Supply of drought tolerant seeds, selection and storage of their own seeds for planting, outreach programmmes for inputs near the farmer communities
Potential adaptations: Research and breeding of drought tolerant crops for Garissa county, establishment of communityowned agro input stockists, use of water harvesting technologies for crop production e.g zai pits

Consequences: Shortage of the commodities in the market(low supply), destruction of market infrastructure sheds
Ongoing adaptations: Early stacking of cereals seeds by the stockists, increasing the market prices due to low supply
Potential adaptations: Establish grain banks at farm level, have controlled prices through establishing production policies

Consequences: Inadequate supply of inputs, spoilage of inputs(seeds), crop damage and loss from water logging
Ongoing adaptations: Early procurement of inputs, early warning systems to guide inputs
Potential adaptations: Use of cropping calendar for guide on what to purchase/procure, diversification of crop types, changing planting dates

Consequences: Reduced grading: selection for sale and grading is compromised, increased losses along the value chain due to dehydration, increased need for storage
Ongoing adaptations: Strategic destocking, transported by trucks/lorries, construction of bomas
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on value addition e.g goat meat drying and sales, goat skins processing and sales, improve feeder roads network to the market, establishment of group feed lot systems

Consequences: Low quality goats, difficulty in transportation due to heat, need for shelter to prevent heat stress
Ongoing adaptations: Infrastructure development of abbatoir, feed lot, grass farm at LMD, movement regulation, disease surveillance, construction of bomas
Potential adaptations: Improve road networks to the market, use good condition double-deck trucks, developing infrastructure of good sheltering at market centres and provide water

Consequences: Reduced vet services, mobility problem due to heat stress, reduced extension services, logistic problems, less training
Ongoing adaptations: Proper storage of vet drugs, conduct vet services in the mornings and evenings, use of radio for extension advice, move resting shed for animals,
Potential adaptations: Decentralize and increase number of vet/extension staff, promote private vets, create extension tents, improve roads, use maintained reliable transport

Consequences: Less selling and promotion due to less milk production, high demand hence high prices
Ongoing adaptations: Alternative income generating activities by women, increase milk prices, use designated milk market centres, advertising with posters/bill boards, reduce milk consumption, maintain willing customers
Potential adaptations: Use of mass media, bill boards, product labelling, quality land management, pasture management, selling milk in other places

Consequences: Reduced milk production due to heat stress, reduced feeding since animals resting under shed, less spraying due to less ticks
Ongoing adaptations: Reduce milking frequency, milk when temperatures are low, graze morning, evening and at night, spray morning, evening and under shade
Potential adaptations: Create resting sheds, improve pasture production, proper grazing patterns, provision of animal feeds in time, creation of cattle dips, good supply of drugs, buying of spraying pumps

Consequences: Reduced vet services due to logistics problem, reduced extension services, increased labor due to pasture and water search
Ongoing adaptations: Pastoralist buying own drugs, mobile vet services, more herders used, cooperation of herders, support from more enlightened herders, take extension service to pastoralists whenever they are by government and NGOs
Potential adaptations: Government to deploy skilled personnel, decentralize vet services, proper early warning system by government and provision of commercial feeds in time by the government, government to deploy more extension officers

Consequences: Increased storage cost, more milk spoilage due to heat, less promotion due to less milk production
Ongoing adaptations: Use of powdered milk, use of other livestock milk, alternative business, advertise to contact consumers and billboards, reduce volume used
Potential adaptations: Creation of processing plants, provision of storage/preservative chemicals, use of local channels and posters source milk from other areas, proper livestock, treatment and feeding

Consequences: Reduced feeding due to low pasture production, reduced deworming and vaccination

Potential adaptations: Improved rangeland management, improved water harvesting systems, proper timing of deworming before drought, proper timing of vaccination before drought, proper disease control, establishment of group feedlots

Consequences: Reduced linkage of farmers to buyers, low pricing: due to high perishability and eggs spoilage, low selling volumes in the market

Potential adaptations: Enhance product linkages, enhance market research, suppliment feeding to improve survival, bulk selling, import eggs from other counties

Consequences: Difficulty in linking farmers to buyers:  less products for linkage (less birds and egg production), high prices due to the law of supply and demand, low selling volumes

Potential adaptations: Strengthen the market linkages via group fromation and trainings, enhance production of eggs through quality feeding and rearing of high breed that are tolerant to drought, bulk selling (sell in group)

Consequences: Reduced cleaning: multiplication of pathogens, disease micro-organisms thrive well and multiply due to high temperature, reduced feeding: low feed intake- birds take less feed due to high temperature, vaccines lose viability

Potential adaptations: Culling, improve enclosure designs(heat resistant), introduce multivitamins and other supplements to increase feeding intake, supplement feeding to increase survival

Consequences: Reduce number of training, drying of seedlings due to high temperature or withering

Consequences: Farmers migrate to different places in search of pasture, reduced field demonstrations due to crop failure, no water for demonstrations plots, reduced procurements for seeds and planting materials due to low purchasing power

Consequences: High prices for the commodity due to low production, reduced market linkage, reduced grading due to lower produtivity

Potential adaptations: Formation of ICT platforms for market information, establishment of decentralized market centres

Consequences: Food insecure at household level, high commodities price, in-flow from other counties, high cost of transportation, reduced collecction due to crop failure

Consequences: Reduced extension services: farmers migrate to different places hence extension officers cannot locate them, reduced vet services, poor housing

Potential adaptations: E-extension mobile vet, train more community disease monitors, enhance disease surveillance, capacity building on anti-heat agents, design good structures

Consequences: Reduced extension services (farmers migrate to different places hence extension officers cannot locate them), reduced vet services: inaccessibility of farmers due to migration, low purchasing power, loss of birds, reduced production.
Ongoing adaptations: Mobile pastoralist training unit (MPTU), community vet health workers, private vets (sidai), use of local materials like sticks and thorns

Consequences: Reduced feeding due to reduced pasture and water, increased deworming and vaccination

Potential adaptations: Hay banking, promotion of livestock insurance, regular deworming, regular vaccination

Consequences: Difficulty in egg collection: due to farmer migration its difficult to count the eggs, minimal transportation due to increased conflict among communities hence transporting eggs and chicken is hindered

Potential adaptations: Adapt battery cage system, introduction of drought resistant breeds (improved breeds, improved kienyeji, dual purpose, rainbow rooster), introduce other bird species, strengthen peace commitees, preach co-existence, online marketing and selling

Consequences: High commodity prices due to law of supply and demand, low market linkage, poor grades due to low quality of grains

Consequences: Reduced cleaning due to lack of water, reduced feeds availability, commercial feeds become expensive, reduced vaccination due to limited funds

Consequences: Reduced egg collection due to high temperature, reduced storage: reduced shelf life due to reduced quality of eggs, frequency of transportation is reduced

Consequences: Difficulty in storage, pest infestation, difficulty in transportation, mechanical brekadown due to high temperatures, reduced produce to be collected

Consequences: Banks cannot lend due to the risk involved(reduced financial capital), reduced extension services, lack of motivation or incentives, reduced vet services

Potential adaptations: Link farmers to financial institutions, electronic extension services, provision of efficient transport and operationalise lab services for veterinary service

Consequences: Low production hence low income, reduced number of land operations, poor germination, withering of crops, low labour productivity

Potential adaptations: Promotion of conservation agriculture, integrated pest and disease management(IPDM), promotion of efficient irrigation

Consequences: Reduced land preparation, reduced acreage for planting, low production, reduced weeding due to crop failure and low production
Ongoing adaptations: Conservation agriculture, promotion of drought tolerant, crop conservation agriculture, diversification of crops and livelihoods
Potential adaptations: Scaling up of conservation agriculture, use of drought tolerant crop, use of certified seeds, use IPM, use early maturing crops, use certified seeds

Consequences: Limited processing due to low milk production, spoilage and high bacterial growth, increased costs on refrigerated vehicles

Consequences: Reduced financial capital, the banker cannot lend funds due to risk involved, reduced extension and vet services

Consequences: Reduced linkage between farmers and buyers, increased need for selling and slaughtering  to avoid losses

Consequences: Less milking, few animals lactating, less feeding due to less pasture, less spraying due to less ticks

Consequences: Decreased production and productivity due to deterioration of pastures hence poor nutritional status of shoats, increased cost of veterinary services

Consequences: Affects milk quality, high temperature increases microbial activity in milk leading to rapid spoilage, thereby affecting its storage quality, increased cooling requirement, increased temperature requires more energy for cooling

Consequences: Production and productivity decreases as a result of less rainfall, there is less quality pastures resulting to poor nutritonal status of shoats, increased cost of veterinary services, there is a lot of vaccinations, treatments against nutritional disorders and secondary infections
Ongoing adaptations: Purchase of hay and feed, use of private veterinary services, introduction of superior breeds, controlling inbreeding, castration of poor performing breeds
Potential adaptations: Promote efficient pasture conservation and storage techniques, strengthen provision and coordination of extension services between the public and private sector, reliable sources of superior breeds, exchange program of breeding material to avoid inbreeding

Consequences: Decline in market demand of shoats and their by products, reduces quality and quantity of by products, shoats of low quality directly translates to by products of low quality

Potential adaptations: Capacity building on the importance of market groups, development of market information systems and implementing it, capacity building on the value of by products, enhancement of disease control

Consequences: Delayed and high cost of farm operations, intense rainfall will distrupt the timing of operations, rapid growth of weeds and high prevalance of pests and diseases, poor nursery development and germination
Ongoing adaptations: Minimum/zero tillage practices e.g use of selective herbicides, use of IPM e.g traps, increased frequency of farm operations, use of raised nursery beds
Potential adaptations: Intensify use of minimum tillage practices, promotion of soil and water conservation structures e.g cod, rod, intensify IPM, practise use of nursery beds, green houses and sheds

Consequences: Delayed farm operations, increased cases of pests and diseases: weeding and sprayng cannot be carried out when there is no adequate moisture, poor seed germination, repeated land preparation and replanting increases labor and costs
Ongoing adaptations: Provision of sheds, mulching, lowering of seed beds, limited farm operations by reducing frequency of weeding, spraying, mulching (cultural practices), use of herbicides, reduced land operations (levelling)
Potential adaptations: Promotion of seed trays, construction of seed multiplication tunnels(centres), use of cultural practices e.g mulching, embracing IPM practices, promotion of water efficient technologies and water harvesting promotion of conservation agriculture (minimum tillage)

Consequences: Delay in harvesting, damage of mature crop, intense rains will hinder the harvesting activities and cause rotting of the fruits, accessibility of farms is reduced, delay in collection and grading, inaccessibility of farms and lack of grading shades will cause delays in collection and grading, costs will also go up
Ongoing adaptations: Manual delivery of produce to the most accessible area, suspend harvesting until rains stop, use of polythene sheets for covering the produce, suspend collection and grading (temporarily)
Potential adaptations: Improve access roads, construction of holding shades, acquisition of rain protective clothes e.g gum boots, rain coats, construction of collection and grading shades at farm level

Consequences: High post harvest losses:  produce of low quality is discarded, poor quality produce, Low yields:  the fruits will be few and small size, quality will be poor due to pests
Ongoing adaptations: Use of natural tree shades, use of combined transport, early harvesting or late harvesting, using plastic containers, cover produce with glass, tree branches
Potential adaptations: Construction of collection and grading shades, promotion/establishment of cottage industries, storage/cooling facilities formation of organised value chain groups along the value chain, construction of cold storage facilities, creation of market linkages, promotion of proper post harvesting techniques( on farm cooling)

Consequences: Reduced fertility: lack of pasture due to decreased rainfall, reduced pasture, stunted growth due to reduced rainfall
Ongoing adaptations: Provision of supplement feeds, animal migration, animal off takes, farmers purchasing seeds, farmers seeking advice from expert offices
Potential adaptations: Seeding of grazing grounds, pasture conservation (paddocking, creating storage facilities, irrigation), strategic pasture reserves, enhance livestock extension services, seeding for bare grazing grounds, study on invasive species e.g ipomea, prosopis juliflora (mathenge), enhance farm forestry e.g fodder trees

Consequences: Decrease in production and productivity of shoats:  less and less rainfall will cause less quality pastures resulting to poor nutritional status, disrupts the schedule of routine farm practices

Potential adaptations: Enhance purchase of hay and feed, Integrated range management, IPM, Enhance paddocking, Enhance pasture conservation and storage, Capacity bulding on routine farm practices to farmers, Capacity building to service providers, Enhanced capacity building on the importance of vector control

Consequences: Delayed supply of fertilizers and pesticides, poor plant growth and nursery development, disruption of planting programs and cancellation of contracts/ agreements, delayed planting due to unavailability of plantiing materials/seeds, transport of seeds / planting hampered by roads flooding in some areas
Ongoing adaptations: Lower lending rates, expansion of repayment periods, suspension of farming by farmers, early supplies of inputs, early purchases
Potential adaptations: Loan products aimed at water harvesting technologies e.g dams, creation of more input supply outlets at farm level e.g  mobile input supply, creation of more centres for supply of planting materials/seeds

Consequences: Low/ reduced purchase of inputs: less farmers will purchase seed/ planting materials, reduced access to credit/financial support: less farmers/ transport traders/ suppliers will be willing to go for credit
Ongoing adaptations: Provision of subsidized fertilizer by government, use of organic fertilizers, provision of incentives e.g irrigation kits at subsdized prices and complete input packages, lowering of interest rates, spreading of repayment periods, development of new loan products for agriculture
Potential adaptations: Promotion of soil fertility management practices e.g compositing, agro forestry, mulching, use of farm yard manure, cover crops promotion of water harvesting technologies at farm level e.g roof catchment, road run off, insitu technologies, kitchen gardening, review of loaning terms by the financial institutions and expansion of loan products by the financial institutions

Consequences: Reduced fodder, increased disease outbreak and pests

Consequences: Stunted growth: stressed animal display poor growth pattern, increased diseases and pests: some diseases and pests thrive well in high temperature (emergence of pathogens in dry spell)

Potential adaptations: Silvopastoral systems, timely vaccination services, well planned calendar of events from veterinary services, decentralise/liberalised vaccine production afforestation, control micro climate, adopt sound land use systems

Consequences: Low quality of pasture: less moisture leads to low pasture/fodder productivity, less animals on heat: moisture stress affects animal breeding cycle hence less AI services

Potential adaptations: Enhanced capacity building on pasture/seed conservation and conservation agriculture technologies, Planting of pasture varieties that can withstand moisture stress, Upgrading animals with breeds that are adapted to high moisture stress, enhance pastoral field school approach

Consequences: Low volumes in the markets and quality is poor, Poor market access

Potential adaptations: Improvement of access roads, market infrastructure development, formation of producer and market groups, formation of value chain organisation, capacity building formation of organised marketing groups and market survey, linking produce to markets (e-markets)

Consequences: Breaching of farming agreements/contracts due to reduced yields and poor quality, the prior agreements are not met consumer/market prices will be high, poor quality produce will fetch low prices

Potential adaptations: Formation of strong product value chain organisation( product and market organisation), Capacity building on value chain groups (wholesalers and retailers), Capacity building on market survey and intelligence

Consequences: Increased disease incidence and animal mortality, less milking: fewer animals are milked since most animals have migrated looking for pasture and water or are dry, increased calving interval

Consequences: Affects body physiology: increased temperature increases absorption of acaricide through the skin of the animal affecting normal functioning, body heat stress on both animal and milker: slows down milking process, affects milk letdown hence low production, reduced herd size
Ongoing adaptations: Fencing as a method of conservation and restricting animal movement, building shelters for milking, dipping/spraying animals early in the morning

Consequences: Less pasture production and harvesting leading to less conserved pasture, low milk availability for cooling/storage

Potential adaptations: Encourage more farmers to engage in commercial hay production, strategic hay reserve at individual and communal level, enhanced capacity building on pasture production and conservation and storage

Consequences: Keeping quality: due to high temperature the meat looses quality, reduced production of biogas: the process of gas production is highly affected by the organic processes  in the digester

Potential adaptations: Pool transport, Refrigerated vans, Availing cooling points decentralise abbatoirs, Refrigeration services refrigeration, Enforcement of public health provision, Cooling facilities provision

Consequences: Decreased milk quality and quantity, high transportation cost to available markets

Consequences: Low fertility: increase in temperature causes stress to the animal hence low fertility, decreased fodder: high temperature affect soil moisture content hence low fodder production

Consequences: Low quality of pasture: increased temperature hardens pasture thereby reducing the quality, High temperature also increases incidences of diseases thus leads to increased production costs

Consequences: Increased veterinary health care requirements, feed and hay scarciity, reduced quality and quantity of feeds

Potential adaptations: Intensify artificial insemination, promotion of on-farm fodder production, research on drought resistant breeds, capacity building on feed rationing and different feeding technologies

Consequences: Poor hatchability and increased cost of brooding, increased costs of feeds, reduced feeds supply, high mortality, increased incidences of pests and diseases, increase need for veterinary care, low productivity
Ongoing adaptations: Destocking, traditional herbs for treatment, free ranging do birds can scavenge for food
Potential adaptations: Promote poultry insurance scheme, promotion of water harvesting schemes, capacity building on poultry disease management

Consequences: Missed marketing opportunities, irregular supply to markets, difficulty in meeting market demand, unstable prices
Ongoing adaptations: Farm gate sales, middlemen to link produce to the market
Potential adaptations: Creation of awareness on vegetable marketing cooperatives, contract growing of vegetables

Consequences: Poor seedling germination rate, formation of hardpans hence tilling becomes difficult, increased water requirement hence increased labour,it increases pests and disease prevalence e.g aphids, termites and ants attack
Ongoing adaptations: Early land preparation, use of minimum tillage practices, irrigation using buckets, use of leaves as mulch
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on manure management and use, use of mechanical tilling equipment, investment in water harvesting and small scale irrigation, promotion of efficient water use technologies

Consequences: Low returns for farmers due to low quantity and quality, decline in supply to the market, home consumption
Ongoing adaptations: Pooled transportation of milk, sales at local market, group marketing, home consumption
Potential adaptations: Improvement of group marketing through capacity building, scale up contract milk farming, improve road markets for easy access

Consequences: Low reproduction, animal and calf mortality, high management costs, emaciation
Ongoing adaptations: Use of indigenous treatment
Potential adaptations: Promote water harvesting, improved livestock health management, investing in weather resistant dairy enclosures, training on farmers on livestock health management

Consequences: High mortality and slow growth rate, feed shortages and increase in price of inputs, reduction in availability of finance for poultry enterprises
Ongoing adaptations: Lengthy procurement process of fund defaults, farmers are online, google and attend shows, field days, group input procurement, on-farm feed production
Potential adaptations: Sensitization of financial institution on loans for poultry producers, purchase of milling and feed mixing machinery, Increased use of media i.e radios, tv and social media, Harmonizing indigenous and modern weather forecast, promote drought resistant breeds

Consequences: Difficulty in acquiring/securing funds because there is difficulty in repaying the loan due to low production, low demand for labour, lack of affordability of seeds and other outputs
Ongoing adaptations: Government (national and county) farm input subsidies
Potential adaptations: Use of drought tolerant and early maturing varieties, improve access to weather information to inform farm operations, enhance drought early warning capacity of meteorological department

Consequences: Poor seedling growth, delayed recharge of soil moisture, difficulty in planning farm operations
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed land preparation, mulching and irrigation with buckets, compost production using leaves of various plants, extension advice on planting dates
Potential adaptations: Water harvesting and irrigation, capacity building on pest and disease management, improvement in access to agro weather advisories for planning of vegetable production operations

Consequences: Poor health of chicks and increased mortality, spoilage of feed, spoilage of vaccines
Ongoing adaptations: Sharing of early warmimg information at fairs, government repair of flood damaged roads, county government provision of day old chicks, sourcing of chicks from private incubators, home feed industries
Potential adaptations: Support to private incubators to scale up operations, capacity building on individuals and cooperatives in on farm feed formulation and storage, sensitisation of financial institutions on loan risk management for poultry growers

Consequences: Reduced quality and volumes of harvest, drought reduces shelf life of vegetables, spoilage during transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Harvesting vegetables in small quantities, selling produce at farm gate
Potential adaptations: Developing cooperatives for vegetables, capacity building on value addition

Consequences: Wilting of seeds while awaiting rains
Ongoing adaptations: Use of muching and irrigation, delayed seed procurement, delayed manure application
Potential adaptations: Promotion of early maturing varieties, local seed bulking, local seedling production

Consequences: Increased prices due to lower supply
Ongoing adaptations: Selling produce at farm gate, home consumption, use of middlemen to link the producer to the market
Potential adaptations: Improvement of access roads to reduce transport times, establishment of contract marketing

Consequences: Poor hatchability, increase incidences of pests and diseases, flood damages to enclosures
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local materials for construction of raised poultry enclosures, government vaccinations and treatment programmes
Potential adaptations: Train farmers on construction of improved enclosures, train farmers on disease surveillance and appropriate vaccine regimes

Consequences: Poor quality produce, storage is expensive, difficulty in timely harvesting, difficulty in aggregation
Ongoing adaptations: Extension advice on harvest times, home consumption
Potential adaptations: Training on vegetable storage and value addition

Consequences: High cost of maintenance at the nursery, loss of seedling (clones): low demand due to prolonged drought, high evaporation rate and lack of regular water supply, no fertilizer supply/application: fertilizers are never applied on tea crops during drought
Ongoing adaptations: Digging of shallow wells to make water easily available, planting of shade trees to minimize moisture losses, application of the prunings on the soil surface to provide fertility, regulating the output per worker to ensure that all workers get some work (tea picking) to do to avoid lay offs, re-deployment of labour to avoid lay-offs
Potential adaptations: Establish large commercial seedling nurseries in designated areas equipped with water supply systems e.g water dams, farmer linkages in order to improve research and selection of drought tolerant clones, conduct research into possibility of irrigating tea as an adaptation to drought risk, insuring labour against the risk of lay-off during drought conditions, develop policy framework for labour stability during lay-off periods, product diversification to keep labour

Consequences: Hailstorms destroys the banana which reduces the value/quality of the banana during harvesting, destruction of storage facility and hinderance to ripening of bananas, hail storms come with strong winds which destoy the storage facilities, difficulty in ripening due to unfavourable temperatures
Ongoing adaptations: Cover the banana with banana leaves from the top to protect from hailstorms, keeping the bananas in the ripening chamber, county government is improving the roads to improve the accessibility to market
Potential adaptations: Maintain covering of the banana using banana leaves from the top, maintaining use of ripening chamber, Kenya Rural Roads Authority should tarmac the feeder roads to improve the accessiblity to market with ease

Consequences: Low supply of tea products in the market, low supply of green leaf, high prices
Ongoing adaptations: Organizations setting new satelite plants to process excess tea during 'glut' and sell/market during period of low supplies, diversification into transporting other tea related products e.g wood fuel
Potential adaptations: Value addition for tea to maximize the use of low produce during minimal production, promote value addition to maximize on low supply of green leaf for enhanced returns, venture into new marketing media to promote robust marketing linkages (e-marketing)

Consequences: Reduced supply of poultry products(meat and eggs), increased demand raises prices
Ongoing adaptations: NA
Potential adaptations: Increased linkage through social media, improved communication network, streamlined marketing channels

Consequences: Low production in quantity and quality of seeds, crops will dry up and poor seed development, poor quality manure: less moisture for decomposition
Ongoing adaptations: Purchase from agro-dealers especially seeds, agroforestry farming practices, rain water harvesting, smart agriculture e.g use of manure, conservation agriculture and irrigation which increases demand for labour
Potential adaptations: Put effort to produce seeds e.g through irrigation, reafforestation, afforestation and or agroforestry farming practices, enhanced water harvesting technologies, use of smart agriculture technologies e.g conservation agriculture, irrigation, mulching

Consequences: Phytosanitary concerns, inadequate availability of clean water for processing, reduced shelf life: deterioration of quality due to unfavourable temperatures
Ongoing adaptations: Reduce processing activities and only sell on demand
Potential adaptations: Put up proper structures, installing of proper system and proper slaughtering facilities, putting up of cold storage facilities

Consequences: Hard ground which requires more time and leads to increased cost of land preparation, delayed planting, no sufficient moisture content for germination, disturbance of root hairs and exposure of roots
Ongoing adaptations: Conservation agriculture especially zero tillage, minimum tillage, adopt good agriculture practices e.g plough at a right depth, addition of manure, rain water harvesting, construction of dams for irrigation purposes, adoption of new technologies e.g greenhouse
Potential adaptations: Enhance  conservation agriculture e.g minimum tillage, enhance good agriculture practices, introduce new/high resistance varieties, enhance water harvesting and use of irrigation, construction of water dams, pans, earth dams, zai pits , adoption of technologies e.g greenhouse

Consequences: Low quality due to early harvesting, drought causes reduced yield and low quality of the product, faster ripening of bananas in the store-it causes over ripening of the bananas which may lead to rotting, inconvenience in sorting the bananas in terms of green, partially ripened and the fully ripened
Ongoing adaptations: Staking the banana tree to support it to maturity, use of ripening chamber, controlled harvesting to control ripening (make harvesting in intervals), transporting the banans before ripening
Potential adaptations: Establishing packhouses for bananas, value addition of bananas by frying, drying, roasting etc

Consequences: Delayed deliveries due to poor rural roads, poor market accessibility, disrupts market/trading processes, high price of poultry products
Ongoing adaptations: Linkage through social media platform(e.g Kericho poultry forum-WhatsApp group), use of alternative mode of transport other than motor vehicles e.g bodaboda
Potential adaptations: Increased linkage through social media, improved communication network, streamlined marketing channels, upgrade the market structures

Consequences: Reduced availability of feeds, leaching of nutrients and soil erosion, increased cost of production, low temperatures will need extra heating/warming leading to extra cost of electricity and equipment, reduced delivery of extension services
Ongoing adaptations: Feeds conservation, improvising using locally available materials, farmer to farmer information sharing
Potential adaptations: Working through organised groups and purchasing inputs in bulk, purchase proper equipment in bulk to lower the cost, e-extension

Consequences: Increase in cost of maintenance of tea clone nurseries, slow growth of clone in nurseries, low demand of seedlings due to lack of moisture, sparing application of fertilzer, low supply of fertilizers, moderate use of labour
Ongoing adaptations: Establishment of supplemental water sources e.g shallow wells and rooftank storage, establishing shade trees to reduce water losses in nurseries, use of tree prunings to the soil surface to improve fertility upon rotting, erosion control to minimize loss of inherent fertility, applying equity principle in labour supply to ensure that all people get some work to do, labour transfer to other operations (excess labour)
Potential adaptations: Establish water harvesting tanks for nurseries during water stress, strengthen research-farmers linkages to adopt drought tolerant clones, carry out research for integrating supplementary irrigation, clones diversification to those that are high yielding and drought tolerant, improve institutional strengthening to ensure labour layoffs are regulated and compensated, product diversification to keep hold of labour

Consequences: Increased cost of production, more feed required to keep the birds warm, increased energy consumption, more vaccination visits
Ongoing adaptations: On farm feed formulation, improvised brooders (jua kali technology), bulk purchase of vaccines to reduce cost, raise chicken houses to avoid destruction by water runoff
Potential adaptations: Implement new designs of chicken housing with considerations of future extreme climatic events, bulk purchase for unavailable feed ingredients, use appropriate technologies, bulk purchase of vaccines by farmer groups, use improved chicken breeds

Consequences: Low supply of seeds/planting materials: reduction in the quantity and quality of seeds, poor decomposition: low quality manure causing scorching effect on crops, reduced farm activities hence low demand for labour
Ongoing adaptations: Collection, processing and preservation of seeds, rain water harvesting e.g roof, run-off water through tanks, water pans and dams, bridging the seasons activities by use of technologies e.g irrigation, mulching, greenhouse farming
Potential adaptations: Commercialise collection of seeds, proper storage, processing of seeds, commercialized manure production, subsidized manure, GAP intensification through green manure, bridge the season for planting to ensure supply of seeds throughout to increase occupation, introduction of new agriculture technologies e.g irrigation, conservation agriculture, climate smart agriculture

Consequences: Increases production cost: prices of feeds likely to be high, wastage of vaccine due to increased temperatures
Ongoing adaptations: On farm feed formation, farmer units in place for efficient vaccination of poultry
Potential adaptations: Keep climate resilient chicken breeds, integrate chicken production with cropping systems to access additional forage, increased frequency in the early warning advisories by the meteorological department, bulk purchase of vaccines by farmer groups

Consequences: Increased cost of feed increased and equipment cost, need for additional water storage facilities, increased demand for drugs for disease control
Ongoing adaptations: Outsourcing of feeds, improved equipments from locally available materials
Potential adaptations: Work through organised groups and purchase in bulk, purchase proper equipments in bulk to lower the cost, proposed e-extension

Consequences: Reduced collection of green leaf, reduced amount of processed tea due to reduced plucking and delivery to factories, factories run undercapacity
Ongoing adaptations: Good agronomic practices to enhance tea leave yield/production (resilience to drought), planting of drought tolerant clone e.g purple tea, 'processing planning' (closing some factories to allow few to process tea at full capacity), value addition e.g green tea granules, pooled transport for tea delivery to save costs, diversification into transporting other tea-related products e.g woodfuel for fueling the tea processing
Potential adaptations: Enhancement of good agronomic practices, promote establishment of drought tolerant tea clones, close some factories to allow those running to operate optimally hence sustaining cost of production, outsourcing transport services to reduce cost

Consequences: Damaging of the planting materials/suckers: hailstorms damages the suckers at the seedbed leading to serious economic losses, leaching of the nutrients in organic manure and delayed decomposition
Ongoing adaptations: Net shed to prevent hailstorms in nurseries, covering of the manure using nylon paper, regular maintenance of tools e.g greasing and keeping them in dry place
Potential adaptations: Shift in planting materials from suckers to tissue culture from recommended organisations, use iron sheet shades (open-sided) and a wall raised to height to be able to prevent runoff

Consequences: Reduced income, low supply of grade eggs, poor quality of meat
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers opt to sell the chicken live to reduce processing costs, improve housing and poultry structures
Potential adaptations: Put up proper housing and related structures, install proper slaughtering facility, putting up cold storage facilities through groups

Consequences: No promotion: no/low supply/high demand, increased prices: low supply/high demand, reduced volume for processing

Potential adaptations: Provision of modelled sites in various sub counties across the county, use of processed vegetables, alternative livelihood to include nderema, pumpkin and other drought tolerant vegetables e.g cowpeas, promote processing and value addition of vegetables, contract growing of vegetables

Consequences: It hinders land preparation through excessive run off that covers the land, rotting of the suckers stems and water logging, destruction of fencing poles, increased incidence of pests and diseases e.g blight
Ongoing adaptations: Drilling the pits and planting the suckers immediately, cut off drain, adjusting planting dates or shifting the cropping area
Potential adaptations: Drilling the pits and planting the suckers immediately, construct check dams where necessary, creation of cut off drains and employ proper timing of season, employ use of life-fencing alongside agroforestry, insurance to manage extreme climate change risks

Consequences: Reduced quantity and quality, low volumes of produce, increased distance between collection points and product loss through insect pests damage/high perishability
Ongoing adaptations: Adoption of technologies e.g irrigation, smart agriculture practices (GAP), sale locally at the nearest market centres, proper handling and loose packaging through even spreading to reduce post harvest losses, harvest only on demand
Potential adaptations: Avail drought tolerant varieties, enhanced adoption of smart agricultural practices, increased production for aggregation of produce in order to make tarnsportation in bulk viable, improve transportation and access to the market by use of refrigerated contained transport (insulated cabinets or containers)

Consequences: Hardening of the ground surface, leads to delayed land preparation and planting, no weeding, disturbs the roots
Ongoing adaptations: Conservation agriculture e.g minimum tillage, zero tillage, mulching, adoption of good agriculture practices e.g use of manure, irrigation, planting along river banks or dams, adjust planting dates
Potential adaptations: Soil and water management through minimum tillage, mulching and use of organic manure, crop irrigation, water harvesting using water pans, diversification through crop mixing to include pumpkin, cowpeas and other drought tolerant vegetables

Consequences: Increased pruning, minimize water loss through evapotranspiration (reducing number of foliage), no weeding
Ongoing adaptations: Use of early warning information to ensure that pruning is done before on-set of drought, this enables the extent of pruning to be reduced, mulching using prunings to suppress any emerging weeds, good agronomic practices to increase capacity of the crop to resist effect of drought
Potential adaptations: Enhances early warning systems on drought situations so that most farmers get right information, use of herbicides to control weeds and hand weeding during drought period, enhancement of good agricultural practices to increase yield, use of irrigation to address shortage of improved tea leaf production

Consequences: Reduced sales, moderate volume of processed tea for auction, moderate cost of production, moderate production of tea
Ongoing adaptations: Diversification into transporting other products e.g wood fuel used in tea processing
Potential adaptations: Value addition for tea to maximize on low supply of green leaf tea, promote new tea marketing channels(e-marketing)

Consequences: Drought affect land preparation directly through hard pan formation, drought delays planting period for bananas, poor germination of banana suckers, delayed decomposition
Ongoing adaptations: Use of intensive human labor to crack the hard pan during land preparation, waiting for the rains and shift in planting season, introduce crop covers through intercropping to enhance optimum water infiltration
Potential adaptations: Mulching to be employed as one way of overcoming the hard pans and conserving water, use of appropriate tools such as augers, provide early warning signs from the meteorological department, provision of better farming tools with ability to crack the hard pans

Consequences: Low sales, drought leads to spoilage of ripe bananas especially in the market especially the open air market, inconvenience in sorting the bananas in terms of green, partially ripened and the fully ripened
Ongoing adaptations: Introducing incentives to make the bananas to be bought faster before they go bad, refrigeration by the able businessmen, market survey to be conducted
Potential adaptations: Encourage formation of cooperatives and farmers to sell through them, network farmers to processing plants, install refrigeration facilities both at vendors level and at the cooperatives, conduct market survey through cooperatives

Consequences: Low consumption by the buyers and low sale turn up due to interference by the rains minimizing contact between sellers and buyers, compromising the quality of the bananas making it difficult for sorting, the bananas are destroyed(insect pests and diseases) lowering their value and quality bringing a challenge in sorting, drop in prices
Ongoing adaptations: Hawking of the bananas to the buyers, varying the prices according to quality, introduce incentives- buy one get one free
Potential adaptations: To build banana bandas to shelter the sellers who do the sorting as the rain continues, strong cooperatives to be formed and farmers to join and capacity build them for collective bargaining

Consequences: Moderate collection of green leaf, reduced shooting of new buds, moderate amount of tea processing, low yields due to moisture stress, reduced plucking regime
Ongoing adaptations: Practice good agronomic practices to enhance yield of tea leaves, establishing tea clones tolerant to water stress conditions, pooled transportation to minimize costs, diversification into transporting other products e.g wood used in tea processing
Potential adaptations: Promote structured and proper extension services for tea farmers, promotion of establishment of drought tolerant clones, moderation and regulations of processing factories, operations to cut cost resulting from under-capacity operations, structuring transport system with intergration of semi-tea industry transporters into tea transportation

Consequences: Higher loses of seeds, wilting of vegetables, spliting of seeds, reduced quality and quantity of vegetables, withering and scorching- when the source and the market distance is far there is a lot of withering and scorching, low volume/lack of enough biomass for processing
Ongoing adaptations: Harvesting at the right maturity period, proper packaging, harvesting in the early morning or late evening, proper post harvest handling e.g wrapping with banana leaves, improved technology-use of refrigerated vans, proper handling- avoid lumping/spread evenly for proper aeration
Potential adaptations: Enhance dissemination of post harvest technologies e.g solar driers, insulated containers, cold rooms/facilities, use of refrigerated vans, proper packaging equipment, increase production e.g enhance smart agriculture, use of new technologies

Consequences: High mechanisation requirement: drought leads to hardening of ground which necessitate mechanised equipment and tools and also energy required to use the tool, drought delays decomposition of organic matter due to lack of moisture, delay in sprouting of the planting material
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers going for lab prepared tissue culture bananas, industrial organic fertilizer, maintenance of farm tools
Potential adaptations: Farmers to change cropping materials during drought season from suckers to tissues culture, to overcome drought the farmer to use water available to make organic manure decompose, irrigation water projects for manure decomposition, maintenance of the tools to keep them fit for farm work

Consequences: Supply is very low and demand is very high hence no need for promotion, increase in pricing
Ongoing adaptations: Capacity building on good agriculture practices during moisture stress conditions, alternative food- use of alternative vegetables e.g omena, cabbage
Potential adaptations: Information dissemination through SMS and other media to enhance promotion, processed/value added vegetables, increased processing through increased production of vegetables

Consequences: Increased cutting of tender leaves, minimizes plant water losses (drying) of branches, minimal weeding, reduced shooting of new buds

Potential adaptations: Integrate early warning systems for enhanced climate information to build farmers capacity, use of herbicides for controlled weeding, promote proper and structured extension services for capacity building on good agricultural practices, use of irrigation

Consequences: Low productivity, low yields, low seedling survival, low adoption of tissue culture technology, low organic or inorganic fertilizer adoption, low yields

Potential adaptations: Composting technology on the farm, soil testing and analysis, establishment and strengthening of satellite hardening nurseries, strengthening of research institutions, blending of crops, use specific fertilizers and low residue pesticides

Consequences: Highly eroded soils results in low banana production, mineral and nutrient loss
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of soil and water conservation structures, sourcing good quality planting materials, use of quality manure and low residue pesticides
Potential adaptations: Construction of conservation structures, enhance the tissue culture production for consistent and uniform production, composting technologies

Consequences: Lack of quality produce to promote, difficult task to link producer to market due to poor farm produce, low adoption of technology and innovation

Potential adaptations: Use appropriate packaging technology, social media platforms and print media advertisements, use of cooperatives, upscaling of technology innovation management practices at the farm level

Consequences: Lack of quality produce to produce, low activities at promotion level, weak linkage to buyers due to poor quality produce

Potential adaptations: Use of appropriate technology and advertising, use of cooperatives, upscaling of technology innovations management practices

Consequences: Untimely preparation and hard pan development, use low quality of planting material because they will not invest in expensive seed, low survival rate, low quantities of poor-quality bunches, delayed maturity period, low income
Ongoing adaptations: Use of machinery to enhace deep soil tillage and structure, use of appropriate technologies and adaptation to ensure moisture retention e.g when cutting the stems, use of recommended planting guidelines e.g spacing and depth, fertilizer application
Potential adaptations: Appropriate tillage techniques, appropriate harvesting techniques to avoid post harvest losses, appropriate planting techniques and technical capacity building and extension on proper planting methods

Consequences: Eroded soils have poor workability, banana plantlets survival rate is low in highly eroded soils, poor-quality bananas, delayed maturity, low income, limited adoption of technology and innovations

Potential adaptations: Use of proper machinery for tillage, using contours technology in sloping areas, construction of roads

Consequences: No business for transporters due to low produce, tideous transportation method, purchase is on farm sorting and grading- poor quality that does not attract market, no business, grading and sorting becomes difficult, and exploitation by middlemen
Ongoing adaptations: Use of proper handling techniques, use of appropriate equipments and skill during grading and sorting, appropriate packaging and marketing of processed products e.g attractive labelling of price
Potential adaptations: Construction of collecting sheds, use of crates during packaging to reduce harvest losses, capacity building on graders on grading and sorting, use of driver to prevent post-harvest losses, value addition

Consequences: Poor quality produce that does not attract high value market, exploitation by middlemen, grading and sorting becames difficult, lack of quality grade for processing

Potential adaptations: Creating and bulking of the procedure and collecting sheds, drying equipment infrastructure to be established and value addition, appointment of qualified sorting and grading teams

Consequences: Extension officers inability to reach farmers, farmers are not available for training, inability to obtain feeds due to impassable roads, destruction of farms, causing loss of feeds

Potential adaptations: Use of e-extension, modern feed conservation and formulation, introduction of modern breeding technology e.g sexed semen and embryo transfer

Consequences: Negative attitude towards extension, unreliable feed supply, poor-quality feeds, expensive feeds, low conception rates, irregular heat cycles, abortions

Potential adaptations: Use electronic extension, introduction of the use of sexed semen, modern breeding technologies e.g embryo transfer, standards and regulation of the feed industry

Consequences: Increased cost of milk delivery, decreased price of milk due to excessive supply

Potential adaptations: Establishment of selling point in major shoping centers e.g milk ATMs and milk bars, enforce dairy cooperative society policy especially setting minimum prices for milk, creation of price stabilization fund

Consequences: Avoidance of small-scale farmers by suppliers, high prices, discrimination in some market segments, flooding of markets by cheap imports

Potential adaptations: Establishment of selling points on main shopping centers e.g milk ATMs or milk bars, enforce dairy cooperative society policy especially setting a minimum buying price for the milk from farmer, creation of a price stabilization fund

Consequences: Causes impassability of roads and insecurities, feeding- bloating because of lush pastures, afflatoxin levels are high during this period, malnutrition, increased vectors that transmit diseases, increased mastitis and pneumonia cases
Ongoing adaptations: Training on modern breeding technology, fodder conservation, disease surveillance and control through vaccination, vector control and observing biosecurity measures
Potential adaptations: Adoption of modern breeding technology, adoption of modern seed conservation and feed formulation technologies, regulation and enforcement of disease control measures and subsidized vaccines

Consequences: Low conception rates, irregular cycles, abortions, unreliable supply of feeds, low production and productivity, decreased fertility of animals, reduced pests and diseases, increased incidence of metabolic diseases

Potential adaptations: Adoption of modern breeding technology e.g sexed semen and embryo transfer, outsourcing feed production and conservation, regulations and enforcement of disease control measures e.g vaccination, subsidized vaccination charges

Consequences: Impacted silage processing, increased milk spoilage during transportation and bulking, rejection of milk from small-scale producers in remote areas due to excessive supply

Potential adaptations: Use of butter fat content in pricing, installation of extended shelf life plants, electronic recording and transmission of milk deliveries to the collectors

Consequences: Increased spoilage from high temperatures and dust, low processing amounts, elevated costs of bulking and collection

Consequences: Inaccessible certified seeds, low yields, untimely delivery of inputs, low production

Potential adaptations: Establishment of seed incubation centers, improvement of infrastructure e.g. good roads, ensuring local availability of inputs, construction of water pans, training farmers on sustainable land management practices (SLM) and soil harvesting

Consequences: Delayed acquisition of certified seeds and crop management, delayed acquisition of fertilizers and pesticides

Consequences: Mechanical damage leading to poor quality and low prices, inflated or exaggerated profit margins

Potential adaptations: Standardization of prices, improve road infrastructure, improve packaging, and mobilize farmers to join cooperatives for collective marketing, consumer lobby groups to advocate for fair prices as per Consumer Protection Act, collective marketing to explore economies of scale from reduced transport costs

Consequences: Increased buyer access to markets, economic losses due to long storage periods

Potential adaptations: Promoting collective marketing and construction of storage facilities, government should create conducive enviroment e.g reducing cost of electricity, promotion of renewable energy, promote aggregation at the collection centers (where buyers and sellers meet)

Consequences: Delay in land preparation, destroyed crops and leaching

Potential adaptations: Establishment of storm water drainages prior to rainy seasons, intensive awareness creation on sustainable land management practices and use of weather reports, sensitization on climate change and adaptation measures, collaborative partnership to enhance capacity building to farmers in promoting sustainable land management practices

Consequences: Delayed farming practices, increased pest and diseases pressure that lead to economic loss

Potential adaptations: Promoting conservation agriculture, building soil structure by manure application, promote indigenous knowledge, farmers sentization not to dehaulm

Consequences: Delayed sorting and grading, delayed transportation of potatoes to market

Potential adaptations: Capacity building on potato storage to preserve quality, establishment of community storage facilities by cooperatives, improve road infrastructure and provision of storage facilities, ensure dehaulming is done before harvesting, ensure the foliage drys before harvest

Consequences: Economic gains due to reduced crop losses, less labor-intensive conditions, lower transportation costs, and avoidance of rotting

Potential adaptations: Promote use of grader which reduces costs, collective marketing to explore economies of scale, encourage farmers to form cooperatives that utilizes economies of scale, establishing collection centers

Consequences: Housing require raised foundations and waterproof thus increasing housing cost, flooding leads to delayed feed supply due to poor road networks thus increasing feeding cost
