Potential adaptations: Formation of permanent cages that can last for long periods thus reducing startup costs, purchase of feeds before onset of rains, construction of raised structures with good drainage

Consequences: Increased housing and feed costs, increased need for capital
Ongoing adaptations: Use of ventilation, use of self-milled feeds
Potential adaptations: Installation of mechanized cooling system, bulking of feeds for storage at household level, purchase of mechanical ventilators to last for a long period

Consequences: Decreased supply, increased prices, loss of buyers
Ongoing adaptations: Individual selling, bargaining on price
Potential adaptations: Uniting farmers so that they can access the market using one means of transportation during flooding, government intervention to introduce policy to regulate prices

Consequences: Lowered production, increased cost of chicken
Ongoing adaptations: Individual selling, which affects prices
Potential adaptations: Formation of cooperatives to ensure a steady supply to the market

Consequences: Feed rationing due to poor road networks that delay feed supply, increase in cost of hatchering since good structures are required to withstand flooding
Ongoing adaptations: Feeds rationing, poultry rearing in small scale and relying on natural breeding, use of vets at an individual level
Potential adaptations: Bulking of feeds, need mechanical brooding to curb the cold during flooding, formation of cooperatives to lower the cost of veterinary services

Consequences: Decreased productivity, lower brooding costs, improved health status of poultry
Ongoing adaptations: Giving more water to the flock to complement the feeds, natural brooding
Potential adaptations: Feeding the birds with vegetables e.g kales, mechanized heat regulation for brooding, veterinary inspection during heat stress

Consequences: Delayed collection since some roads are inaccessible during flooding
Ongoing adaptations: Use of a free-range storage in an open room (whole chickens), use of trays for eggs, use of motorcycles for transport
Potential adaptations: Adapting to battery cages for easy collection of eggs even during floods, good drainage around the storage room and air regulator to increase warmth, request for good infrastructure for better accessibility in rural areas

Consequences: Prolonged collection period, increased difficulty with transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Collection at household level rather than collection centers, use of open rooms with shades, transportation on motorcycles
Potential adaptations: Improved collection at the household level to prevent breakage of eggs and early brooding, improved cage systems to prevent overcrowding and preserve biosafety, installation of well-ventilated structures on motorcycles and pick-up vans

Consequences: Loss of pasture/fodder, loss of animal/breedy stock, increased costs of routine practices, high costs of feed, loss of breedy stock
Ongoing adaptations: Use of cattle feeding regime, growing of drought tolerant fodder, harvesting and conserving pastures, feed supplementation, use of crop residues for feeds, access to advisories from early warning systems
Potential adaptations: Selection of efficient feed converting animals (breeding herd), access to livestock insurance schemes(cushion loss of livestock at household), training on enterprise diversification(cereal production/poultry keeping), construction of hay storage structures, proper demarcation of grazing land

Consequences: Loss of pasture/fodder leading to malnutrition, low breeding success rate, increased pests and disease incidences, increased animal production costs(feeding, deworming), high mortality rates
Ongoing adaptations: Harvesting flood waters, construction of on farm drainage structures(tunnels, furrows) for pasture establishment, synchronized cattle breeding, increased drugs and vaccines use, increased production costs(housing, breeding, feeding)
Potential adaptations: Harness flood waters, animal insurance schemes, access to alternative feed supplements(crops biomass), access to improved/modern vaccines

Consequences: Water logging, delay in planting calendar
Ongoing adaptations: Terracing and furrows, formation of women groups to provide pooled labour, intercropping, crop rotation, enterprise diversification
Potential adaptations: Construction of dams to control floods, upscale of household/community tuber planting(increase acreage), awareness campaigns on crops importance to food security

Consequences: Poor milking regimes(inaccessibilty to milking pens), poor milk storage due to damaged storage structures, milk storage in metal and plastic cans
Ongoing adaptations: Low quantity and reduced milk quality, poor storage facilities leading to milk contamination, store milk in cans and plastic containers, mik for household consumption
Potential adaptations: Micro storage plants, construction of bridges, capacity building on proper husbandry practices while milking

Consequences: Increased prices, reduced market activities, inconsistency in supply linking farmers to potential buyers
Ongoing adaptations: Low quantity and quality of marketed tubers, improve and strengthen market information on markets and prices, formation of processing groups
Potential adaptations: Formation of producer groups(facilitates market pricing and marketing activities), establishment of collection and storage centres to stabilize prices

Consequences: High incidences of animal diseases, low fodder productivity, increased demand for extension and vet services
Ongoing adaptations: Mass vaccines prior to expect floods, training and awareness, creation of ways of coping, conserve and store fodder and pasture, water harvesting(flood water harvesting for fodder production)
Potential adaptations: County support in introduction of new water harvesting structures(dykes, canals), use of cost effective oil based vaccines, provision of dairy input as relief, access to  improved animal breed varieties, mechanization of fodder conservation, and construction of mega purpose dams, improved access to extension services

Consequences: Soil degradation(hardening of sandy/loamy soils), delayed planting, drying of planting material, increased labor costs, poor stand establishment and poor crop vigour, increased incidences of pests
Ongoing adaptations: Early land preparation, early/staggered planting, planting clean and certified tubers, use of ash(prevents ants), tree planting for providing shade, intercropping, crop rotation, mulching(with crop residues), water harvesting and storage, mapping soils for suitability of growing cassava
Potential adaptations: Use of soil rippers(break hardpans), enterprise diversification(to grow other crops), access to affordable pesticides/insecticides, promote water conservation structures(dams/pans)

Consequences: Depleted food stocks, high maintenance, increased milk and meat contamination(dust/dirt), increased cost of milk storage and packaging, milk spoilage and shrt shelf life
Ongoing adaptations: Transportation through refigerated tanks, processing into fermented milk, charcoal cooling for milk storage, construction/location of storage cooling facility under shade tree, water bath storage, reconstitution of powder milk
Potential adaptations: Interest in renewable sources of energy (cheaper), direct sales to minimize storage costs, construction of community operated milk processing plants, increased processing of value added products(milk powder)

Consequences: Increased consumer prices, increased cost of packaging material, high costs in distribution increased consumer price, increase costs of transport, increased cost of distribution
Ongoing adaptations: Milk scarcity and increased demand, external milk imports(local traders/processors), market price exploitation due to poor milk quality, reduced market and marketing opportunities
Potential adaptations: Dairy farmer groups(for milk pricing)

Consequences: Poor quality of harvested chillies, increased storage durations(collection hampered by lack of access to farms), increased labor (sorting and grading)
Ongoing adaptations: Use of bad quality chilli as poultry medicine, disposal of rotting chillis, use of family labor for sorting and grading, crop abandonment in case of severe crop failure, use of chilli solar driers
Potential adaptations: Offering IPM technologies(pest and disease control), capacity building on chilli value addition technologies(as poultry drugs), access to improved storage materials(canvas and wooden crates)

Consequences: Poor quality and quantity of harvested produce, increased labor needs for sorting and grading, increased incidence of pests(weevils), loss of flavor(overdrying)
Ongoing adaptations: Use of manual(household) labor for sorting and grading, construction of drying and storage sheds, storage in gunny bags and traditional sisal vessels(reduce loss of flavor)
Potential adaptations: Improved access to storage facilities, farmer capacity building on best practices for chilli storage to prevent loss of flavour

Consequences: Lack of access to clean and improved planting cuttings, water logging, erosion, leaching, cassava cuttings: rotting, eroded
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local/traditional root varieties, use of traditional pest control inputs e.g. ash
Potential adaptations: Local seed bulking, germplasm maintenance

Consequences: Drying of planting materials, scarce labour and increased labour costs
Ongoing adaptations: Recycling of planting materials or cuttings, pooled labour, access to inputs(seed, fertilizer and extension services) through development/aid agencies, farmer grouping (facilitate access to inputs/extension services)
Potential adaptations: New drought and pest tolerant tuber varieties, local root nurseries, conservation of cassava germplasm

Consequences: Quality of feeds deteriorates/goes bad, scarcity of feeds, more use of vaccines/drugs, high cost of maintainance
Ongoing adaptations: Use of alternative feed supplements(kitchen waste/ horticultural afterharvest products)
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on alternative feed sources, feed formulation, feed conservation, provision of improved chicken breeds/crossbreeds

Consequences: High maintenance costs, increased feed prices due to feed scarcity, more use of drugs/vaccines due to high prevalence of diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Use of feed supplements, enhanced irrigation to grow crops which provide feeds, use drought tolerant crops, use of thermo stable vaccines, allow birds to scavenge for food, farmer grouping to allow access to inputs/ extension services
Potential adaptations: Capacity builing on alternative feed sources/supplementation using local available materials, research on alternative vaccines like traditional herbs, use of modern poultry vaccines(support by the county), provide improved chicken breeds

Consequences: Reduced volumes of birds to sell, high poultry products demand and low market supply, poor infrastructure for transportation(drainage and roads) to market
Ongoing adaptations: Low market prices(by farmers), high poultry products demand and low market supply, poor transportation(contamination by misture/dirt)
Potential adaptations: Formation of cooperatives within the region to facilitate marketing, introduction of poultry off-take programs(government supported mass chicken sale), country support to explore external markets, establishment of specific local chicken auctions

Consequences: Minimal or no harvest, low quality cassava due rotting and improper drying storage:afflatoxins
Ongoing adaptations: Farm gate sale of roots, use of roots as livestock feed, post harvest value addittion(drying to reduce perishability)
Potential adaptations: Community storage centres, traditional household post harvest value addition and conservation practices(flour making)

Consequences: Poor quality and reduced quantity of harvested roots, increased incidence of storage pests, drying of stored roots
Ongoing adaptations: Use of household labour for harvesting, use of cereal stores, divert root harvest to household consumption, sale of root at farm gate to avoid storage
Potential adaptations: Community storage centres, traditional household post harvest value addition and conservation practices(flour making)

Consequences: Reduction in immune system strength, increased use of vaccines/drugs, reduced feeding due to high cost of feeds, increased water intake, high mortality rate
Ongoing adaptations: Water harvesting and conservation practice to establish poultry feeds, regular poultry vaccination, free foraging flocks, access to advisories from early warning systems, enterprise diversification(fishing/employment)
Potential adaptations: Insuring poultry against drought risks, promotion/upscale of water harvesting, enforcement of disease control measure during outbreaks, improved access to extension services

Consequences: High costs on veterinary service, high incidences of diseases and pests, loss of fodder/pasture, unavailability of breeding stock
Ongoing adaptations: Putting up shelter (shade trees, animal shade), growing grass/napier under tree canopy, delivery of water through water boursers, water pans, use of water retention technique e.g Zai pits, fodder purchase locally or externally, rearing drought resistant animal breeds, cross breeding
Potential adaptations: Fodder bulking, reseeding of natural pastoral lands, use of hydroponics to grow animal feeds, increase artificial insemination services

Consequences: Increased price of consumer price, reduced market activity(inaccesibility of roads), milk scarcity on the market and increased demand
Ongoing adaptations: External milk imports by traders and processors, reduced market and marketing opportunities
Potential adaptations: Formation and support of dairy farmer groups/cooperatives(marketing and milk pricing activities)

Consequences: Reduced meat quality and low weight of poultry products, poor storage facilities
Ongoing adaptations: Household slaughter/dressing of poultry carcasses, meat storage(polythene bags), manual labour(slaughtering)
Potential adaptations: Provision of improved meat storage structures(moisture free and cold storage), government support to access small scale refrigerators, community access to modern slaughter equipment, farmer training on chicken poultry standards(feeding, slaughter, storage)

Consequences: Low quantity and reduced meat quality, low egg production, poor storage facilities, reduced weight, spoilage of bird carcasses
Ongoing adaptations: Household slaughter/dressing of poultry carcasses, meat storage(polythene bags/hanging above ground), manual labour(slaughtering/searching for layed eggs)
Potential adaptations: Provision of impoved meat storage structures(cold rooms)

Consequences: Low seed germination, poor stand establishment, loss of plant vigor, loss of soil quality(hardening), increased labor needs, wilting/drying of planted crop
Ongoing adaptations: Replanting/staggered planting, mulching(cereal crop residues), drip irrigation after establishment, crop rotation, planting trees(shade/windbreak), enterprise diversification(poultry/cereal production), integrated pests management(pest control kits from ICIPE), intercropping(mangoes and pawpaw), sunken beds, water holes for water harvesting
Potential adaptations: Widespread access and use of drip irrigation kits, research on improved crop rotation practices, IPM practices, continued support from research agents(for pest control and management)

Consequences: Increased nursery seed loss, labor scarcity, lack of water
Ongoing adaptations: Use of drip irrigation kits, growing seeds in nurseries(before transplanting), pooled labor through farmer groups, acess to inputs(pest and disease control), use of traditional pest control(herb sprays), farmers to dry their own chillies to get seeds rather than being given free of charge
Potential adaptations: Research to improve drought tolerance, access to modern pesticides, access to greenhouses(materials and structures), access to irrigation equipment, access to extension services

Consequences: Low prices of live birds, reduced volumes of birds for sale, high transport cost, live birds die due to dust and heat stress
Ongoing adaptations: Divertion of chicken products for household consumption
Potential adaptations: Formation of poultry producer cooperatives(facilitate marketing), introduction of poultry off take programs(government supported mass chicken sale)

Consequences: Increased root demand and low supply, flooded markets leading to less marketing activities, increased market prices
Ongoing adaptations: Low quantity and quality of marketed roots, low market prices, reduced marketing activities by traders, market scarcity leading to abandonment
Potential adaptations: Formation of producer groups(facilitates market pricing and marketing activities)

Consequences: Increased incidence for seed loss at nursery stage(rotting, wiping away), scarcity of labour and inputs(access challenges due to damaged roads)
Ongoing adaptations: Pooled labour(formation of women groups to provide cheap labour), establish farmer owned nurseries, use of pesticides/insecticides
Potential adaptations: Research on moisture tolerant chilli varieties, county support in giving input aid during floods, offering access to extension services

Consequences: Low market prices(low quality chillis), loss of markets/marketing opportunities, shift in market focus
Ongoing adaptations: Low market prices, farm gate sales to avoid storage expenses, sale to local markets(traders, hotels, institutions)
Potential adaptations: Formation of farmer groups(facilitate contracting), contracted farming(supporting producers in input provision/storage/negotiated prices)

Consequences: Increased incidence of disease outbreaks, elevated use of vaccines/drugs, high maintenance of poultry houses, poor growth rates, high mortality rate
Ongoing adaptations: Use of modern and traditional drugs for disease control, mass vaccinations in disease outbreaks
Potential adaptations: Enforcement of vaccination(disease outbreaks), enterprise diversification(to crop farming/employment)

Consequences: Water logging of seedlings at planting, deteriorated soil quality(poor germination/seed rotting), loss of applied inputs(fertilizers/chemicals), low stand establishment, loss of crop vigour, increased disease incidence
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of raised seed beds, use of green houses, construction of water drainage controls(terraces, canals, furrows), use of chemicals for pests and disease control, enterprise diversification(to horticulture/banana farming), intercropping with cereals and tuber crops
Potential adaptations: County support in introduction of new water harvesting structures(dams, canals), use of improved pesticides/insecticides, training on enterprise diversification(poultry keeping/business)

Consequences: Reduced market supply(high demand), increased market prices
Ongoing adaptations: Sale to local markets, produce offered free of charge to neighbors/friends
Potential adaptations: Producer groups(facilitating production, pricing, marketing), contract farming with market buyers, support in external market access

Consequences: Poor accesibility to information, damage on road infrastructure affects flow of required agronomical information due to inaccesible farms, poor accessibility to the nurseries- affected road networks poses a challenge to access the centralized nursery system, poor accessibility of organic and inorganic fertilizers due to impassable road networks, obstacles to transportation and technical support services
Ongoing adaptations: Use of broadcast, print and digital machines (radio shows, WhatsaApp), use of animal transport and small transport machine like motrocycles, tuk tuk, farmers practising mixed farming (avocado and animal rearing) to produce organic manure on site
Potential adaptations: The avocado cooperative to have an inhouse agronomist to advise on recommended seedlings, fertilizers and agrochemicals, the cooperative society and its members will be empowered to own certified avacado nurseries, the cooperative society may procure fertilizer in bulk and distribute to farmers

Consequences: Greater access to information by farmers, diminished quality and inadequate supply of seedlings, low volumes of business due to unwillingness of farmers to plant during dry spells
Ongoing adaptations: Use of farmers' barazas to avoid overcrowding, partnering/sourcing seedlings from certified nurseries, use of crude method of irrigation e.g watering cans
Potential adaptations: Digitization of extension services, train farmers on the production of certified high qualified seedlings of recommended variety, install irrigation systems at the avocado nursery, farmers install drip irrigation systems to provide supplementary water during dry seasons

Consequences: Emergence of middlemen due to poor farmer-buyer linkages, low prices due to perishability of the produce with uncertain market resulting to desparate disposal of avocadoes, hindered promotion services as trade relations suffer strain from unmet contractual obligations
Ongoing adaptations: Selling to licensed exporters, partnering with the licensed exporters for stable prices/reliable markets, partnering with the licenced exporters for consistent market access
Potential adaptations: The avocado cooperative society to have their own packhouse and direct market channel to the international market, value addititon of avocado e.g processing extraction of avocado oil, digitalization of promotion of services

Consequences: Loss of market due to low quality and quantity, loss of business trust and confidence, low supply will lead to high prices
Ongoing adaptations: Produce sold as animals feeds such as for pig farming, contractual farming for stable pricing, focus on the local market which has less strigent marketing requirements
Potential adaptations: Capacity building of the cooperative society to enhance quality control, value addition e.g reduce losses resulting form poor quality fruits, expand the area under avocado production by implementing water harvesting and irrigation techniques so as to enhance the supply of fruits during the day season, research and development to come up with the most suitable avocado variety for the growing area and as per the market tastes and preference

Consequences: Poor workability of the farms,  delayed or displaced harvesting heavily affected by heavy rainfall
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers engaging on sustainable land management on drainage to improve soil workability, crude timing of the varying season to plant before rains, crude timing of harvest time when not raining
Potential adaptations: Use of mechanization e.g hand held soil augers, use of  mechanization to enable farmers to plant even during harsh weather, mechanization of harvesting activities, use of protective clothing to guard against harsh weather

Consequences: Land preparation operations decreases due to uncertain rains, no planting, low volumes of avocados produced
Ongoing adaptations: Rotational farming with drought resistant crops to perservere the harsh climate conditions, diversification of crops to bridge the gap during dry season
Potential adaptations: To ensure certainity of planting water harvesting and irrigation techniques may be harnessed such that land preparation may access water harvesting and installation of irrigation system may optimize planting operation, expand the area under avocado production, install irrigation and water harvesting systems to increase volumes of fruits during harvesting

Consequences: inaccessible farms due to damaged road infrastructure, low volumes leading to loss of business, delayed delivery due to adversely affected infrastructure
Ongoing adaptations: Use of locally non-motorized transport (animal carts e.t.c), forming farmers cooperatives to aggregate produce, exploration of the local market
Potential adaptations: Mechanization to access farms, scaling- up the area under avocado production, use of all weather means of transport such as rail transport, air transport

Consequences: Low volume of fruit collected, low volumes hence low productivity and poor quality, business losses due to low volume

Potential adaptations: Expand area under avocado production while implementing water harvesting and irrigation techniques so as to increase fruit volumes collected and actualize avocado planting even during the dry season, thus transport business will continue

Consequences: Organic/inorganic fertilizer- leaching, workability, loss of value, poor attendance and timelines of extension messages
Ongoing adaptations: Improving drainage to reduce leaching, composting, nursery harvesting, use of fodder strips comprised of brachiaria grass, careful and appropriate timing of field operations
Potential adaptations: Leaching- plant deep rooted to enable recycling of lost nutrients, nitrogen fixing plant incorporated, collective input procurement, soil testing kits, poor attendance, use of mass media and IT technology, field workability- promote mechanization of field operations, use of weather forecasts to pre determine activities

Consequences: Delayed application, low demand, more audience available, delayed order of inputs
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed use of inputs, low demand to agrodealers, stocking levels is sychronized to demand, alternative products i.e foliar fertilizer, offer prices, low demand for planting materials, use of irrigation to cope with planting need, support use of hardening nurseries, delayed order for inputs- agro stockist delay order from suppliers, stocking level reduce, agrodealer association
Potential adaptations: Delayed use of inputs, low demand by producer, offer promotional pricing, agrodealers to seek weather forecast before stocking for a season, low demand for planting materials, establish hardening nurseries in every subcounty, delayed order for inputs- mobilize agrodealers to work with producers and jointly, use weather forecast information

Consequences: Less opportunity due to low audience, delayed linkage, low access to markets
Ongoing adaptations: Loss of opportunity- low volumes demanded, step up value addition process, explore other markets i.e linkages, Delayed market linkage, loss of market access , lobbying of more market outlets, promotion of banana produce, contractual marketing, Loss of sale, post harvest losses, competitor produce in the market, promote banana and its products for consumer, diversify consumption forum, enact policy aganist waste
Potential adaptations: Loss of opportunity - low volume demanded, ecourage contractual engagements for producer and buyers, use of IT and market information on media, Delayed market linkage, loss of market access, contractual marketing, step up value addition at large scale (industrial), Loss of sales, post harvest losses, competitive produce in the market, contractual marketing, support policies that will favour marketing produce, explore external markets, mobilize producer into groups/cooperatives

Consequences: Timely promotion, more produce demand, Increased linkage to market, produce demand on the increase, loss quality requirements
Ongoing adaptations: Due to shortage there is more demand than supply- market agreements to protect the produce procurer, Agreements and linkages to suppliers, Linkages to best offers despite the low volumes are sought
Potential adaptations: Marketing model to synchronize the quality and quantity of produce demanded, to remain in market fixed terms on TOR should prevail any season, to benefit producer export market should be exploited

Consequences: Hard soil pans, increased costs, leaching, loss of value, ineffective uptake of extension information and services, delayed harvests, low crop productivity, post-harvest infections
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed farm operation, timely farm preparation before rain onset, use of zero tillage to reduce hard pan, quick weed developed, use of herbicides, mulching, low banana production, pest and disease build up, establish appropriate cultivars, good crop husbandry practices
Potential adaptations: Promote farm mechanization, chemical weeding, timely use of weather forecast, promote tissue culture bananas, use of appropriate cultivars- disease resistant

Consequences: Effective operation capacity readily available, delayed fertilizer application, poor uptake, soil caking, soil dehydration, delayed maturation, low production, poor-quality bananas
Ongoing adaptations: Effective farm operation, dust blowing wind affect banana quality, dehydration of the banana fruit, bagging of banana, Delayed organic/inorgainic fertilizer use- use of irrigation to facilitate use of manure and fertilizer, Delayed crop maturation, poor quality bunches, low production- irrigation from water harvest sources, mulching, desuckering if appropriate
Potential adaptations: Blowing of dust by wind, establish wind cover trees around crop field, explore use of fertigate in fertilizer application and drip irrigation for effective fertilizer uptake to new crop, solar irrigation, drip irrigation, solar powered irrigation

Consequences: Inaccessible roads, produce affected, spoiled quality, delayed delivery, delayed processing, high cost due to drying, delayed ripening due to high humidity and deteriorated quality, reduced consumption as other competitive products gain an advantage
Ongoing adaptations: Inaccessible roads, quality of produce due to soiling, use of motor bikes and ox carts, use of plant packaging material, use of solar driers, hygiene harvest practice, ripen fully matured bananas, use of ripening chambers
Potential adaptations: Lobbying of better roads by producer associations, promote post harvest practices for healthy producer, fibre extraction, sychronize product demand to processing capacity, diversify value added products, use of ethylene to enhance ripening

Consequences: Effective transportation, sunscorching, timely delivery, favourable weather, less cost for drying, timely processing, reduced access to produce for ripening, lower quality produce
Ongoing adaptations: Bagging, use of plant-based packaging materials, controlling temperatures through ripening rooms with adjustable ventilators, forming and mobilizing
Potential adaptations: Establishment of shaded collection centers in marketing, introduction of reusable packing material, creation of investment policies, innovation assisted by the Kenya Industrial Research and Development Institute (KIRDI) to design a controlled ripening chamber, proper timing of the harvest regime to meet the transport and market threshold

Consequences: Shortage of fodder, low temperature affect growth of fodder, reduced business- AI services, few animals coming on heat

Potential adaptations: Strengthen producer organizations to source fodder in bulk to reduce operational cost, planting fodder in large scale e.g South Ngariama, capacity build the farmers on heat detection and animal nutrition, technology for heat detection, government subsidy on veterinary services

Consequences: No fodder for dairy animals, Low demand for artificial insemination

Potential adaptations: Use of irrigation in fodder production, Producer organizations to train farmers on heat dectection and nutrition, Government subsidy on vet services, producer organizations subsidy

Consequences: Scarcity of milk due to decrease in milk production, Low turnout- few people attending various forums due to low temperatures

Potential adaptations: MOU  with neighbouring counties on processing, Promote milk consumption in schools, adveritise widely in all modes, Intensify use of social media to reach farmers

Consequences: High input on sustainability and low turn over, no motivation for promoters, no finances to fund promotional  activities

Consequences: Low growth rate of fodder at the farm, decreased milk production, high operational costs- dairy animals feed a lot to keep/maintain warmth

Consequences: Scarcity of fodder- due to drought and no feed to conserve, Inadequate fodder for the dairy animal

Consequences: Minimal transportation business- there is decreased milk production so some transporters lose business, Processing under capacity due to low milk production

Potential adaptations: Cost of fuel to remain low, use of motorbike and Tuk Tuk in milk collection, Policy- lobby for electricity tarrif reduction for milk processors, Introduce satellite coolers in collection centers

Potential adaptations: Lobby for fuel prices reduction, Lobby for reduction of power tarrif for processors, Introduce satilite coolers in milk collection centers

Consequences: Flooding and destruction of chicken houses, Delayed supply of equipment due to poor accessibility, Delayed veterinary services, Reduced availability of drugs and vaccines

Potential adaptations: Construction of well designed chicken houses that have high floors and flood proof, planning ahead and procure equipment in good time, planning vaccination and drug administration ahead before rainy season

Consequences: Poor housing designs materials used can cause low production and growth rate, Feeds quality can be affected- deterioration

Potential adaptations: Use of well designed poultry house that are well ventilated, Training farmers on home made chicken feeds and good storage, Utilize the veterinary services, procurement of the correct vaccines and drugs from right sources

Consequences: Reduced sale of live birds due to poor accessiblity to market, Reduced sale of eggs due to poor accessibility to the market

Potential adaptations: Establishment of cooling facilities for storage of meat, value addition through slaughtering on the farm and storing in refrigerators, Establishment of an egg aggregation center to ensure good storage of eggs, Using PSP that is participatory scenario planning ahead in order to store manure for well

Consequences: Reduced sales due to mortality, Reduced sale of eggs due to low quality

Potential adaptations: Transport using modern facilities that have good aeration and cooling facilities, value addtion strategies at home i.e slaughter at onfarm and transport, start a chicken processing plant, Use modern technologies to store the eggs using trays, crates and a cooling facility, Training on composting and use of digesters

Consequences: Can lead to feed spoilage (aflatoxins), the hygiene of chicken house goes down due to flooding, muddy conditons
Ongoing adaptations: Feeding chicken with kitchen leftovers and animal produce direct from store or farms, Free range rearing and use of available litters, ash and wood shelves Establish incubation site in kitchen where it is warm and lay on soft clothing that increases the warmth
Potential adaptations: Construction of good modern storage facilities to ensure feeds are kept in good condition, Construct a good chicken house with good designs and site to avoid flooding occurrence, Construction of incubators to regulate the temperatures to ensure good hatchery during low temperatures

Consequences: Reduces the uptake of feeds thus reducing production and growth rate, Reduced workmanship due to uncomfortable conditions thus deterioration of farm hygiene leading to high accumulation of ammonia

Potential adaptations: Use of boosters like multivitamins, Putting up hygiene measure like foot baths, good siting of the house, use of washable equipments like plastic, Use of incubators to regulate temperatures for good hatchery and brooding

Consequences: Delayed collection and trransportation of eggs due to poor accessibility

Potential adaptations: Establishment of accesible aggregation centers for the collection of eggs, Establishment of accessible cool rooms to store the slaughtered birds, Using weather forecast to plan ahead on the suitability on when to slaughter i.e correct timing

Consequences: Deterioration of egg quality, Causes stress on live bird that can lead to low production and death

Consequences: Low sales: when accessibility is affected, sales are low because of market penetration high prices: reduced supply occasioned by extreme rainfall leads to high demand hence high prices

Potential adaptations: E-marketing platforms, market products in groups and exporters as this improves bargaining power of the producers, farmers to have a communication platform

Consequences: Affects planning for the promotion activities, price fluctuations

Potential adaptations: Organise field days, farmer groups and cooperatives, product certification and value addition

Consequences: Eroding of top soil layer, increased incidences of diseases (arborition, RVF, foot rot), drowning, inadequate and expensive labor
Ongoing adaptations: Terracing, planting of trees and grass, fencing, vaccination, surveillance of diseases, control livestock movement, farmers opting to do the farm work which limits the work done
Potential adaptations: Mechanized sub soiling, oxplough subsoiling, planting of trees and manure application, Routine disease surveillance, vaccination, Mechanizing some of the operations e.g fencing

Consequences: Overgrazing, bushfires, low fertility and health deterioriation, increased costs of production

Potential adaptations: Mechanization, fencing, improved pastures, subsoiling, Improved feeding programs, use of modern breeding methods such as A.I, cross breeding, Paddocking, stocking animal feeds in advance

Consequences: Increased costs, poor access to the market, inaccesibility to the slaughter houses, losses to traders

Potential adaptations: Improved market facilities e.g fencing, shading, Improved slaughter houses facilties, accessible slaughter houses, Link farmers to bulk buyers

Consequences: Fluctuations of prices, Low buying power from consumer

Potential adaptations: Market linkages, Loans from financial institution and cooperatives, Installation of solar freezers, direct linkage to consumers

Consequences: Decreased leasing time due to biting flies e.g tsetse flies caused by heavy rainfall, poor accessibility to the farms plus disinterested farmers engaged in planting activities
Ongoing adaptations: Utilization of conserved fodder, pellets, use of pour-ons, Advice through SMS and calls, googling, use of traditional methods and practices
Potential adaptations: Stocking fodder by preservation or storage, use of commercial pelleted feeds, Formation of extension- farmer field schools, Early construction of houses- all activities done before rainfall

Consequences: Lack of nutritional balance, Reduce extension services because of inability to pay

Potential adaptations: Supplementation, Government subsidies-zero taxing and agro-products

Consequences: Poor body score- goats loose condition, likelihood of disease transmission, poor road networks

Potential adaptations: Use of commercial supplementary feeds, concentrates and mineral licks, Livestock inspection- vaccination (routine), isolation before aggregation, Well planned programs for road improvements and maintainance

Consequences: Forced destocking to cater for finances, high cost of living, dusty roads

Potential adaptations: Planned culling-seasonal based, Cooperatives (formation), linkages, Regular road maintainance, sprinkling water on roads regulary

Consequences: Unproductive land, low yields and poor crop performance, no planting/delayed planting, reduced or skipped spraying

Potential adaptations: Intensify water harvesting, use of conservation agriculture, Integration of both traditional and modern forecasts, certified and early maturing seeds, Agrodealers diversify their source of income

Consequences: It kills micro-organisims, salinity increase due to evaporation, deterioration of quality

Consequences: High commodity price, Low linkage due to low harvesting quantity

Consequences: Low pricing, may not get the ideal market, not easy to get buyers

Consequences: Difficult to prepare the land, affects performance of the pesticides- crop injured/drying, wilting

Consequences: Low germination rate, affects the efficieny of the chemicals, scorching of crop

Consequences: Low volume processed, High storage cost

Consequences: High cost of construction materials, increased invasion of extra parasities and predators, reduced performance, increased water intake, reduced feed efficiency, reduced general productivity

Consequences: Increase in predation thus requiring frequent repairs, drought withdraws resources that are made for chicken repair and construction, less capital for breeding stock

Potential adaptations: Proper housing and fencing, availability of credit services/link to financial service providers, establishment of a breeding unit, feed formulation, breed improvement

Consequences: Increased supply in the market hence lower quality and prices, Increase in market supply at low prices

Consequences: Increased production, reduced egg production, increased transportation costs to the market, increased disposing of stock

Consequences: Little processing no storage

Consequences: Uncertain extension services, uncertainity in choice of the right variety of seed, low supply of seed, low supply of fertilizers, late purchase of fertilizers

Consequences: Compromised fruit quality: undersize fruits, poor colour, poor shape, shrink, shapeless, reduced access to market, loss of premium prices, unfulfilled contracts
Ongoing adaptations: Non differentiated marketing, creating contacts with traders, middlemen, reliance mixed cropping with low lying crops (cow peas), target quantity other quality fruits
Potential adaptations: Gazettement of mango by county government as a cash crop, contractual market arrangement with finalized contracts supported by policy development and implementation, contract agreement between farmers and buyers, value addition mechanism

Consequences: Poor setting up of orchards: drying up of seedlings, overgrown seedlings, poor planning of spraying regime: ineffective fertilizer and pesticides uptake, low efficacy
Ongoing adaptations: Doing bottle irrigation, basin formation/terraces, reduced number of sprays per season, no grading, no sorting as all fruits are sold at the same price, no standard measure at selling
Potential adaptations: Enhancing water harvesting techniques, supporting farmers in self regulation in the mango value chain, coordination of all service providers, government and private contract agreement between traders and recognised farmer groups

Consequences: Reduced production of clean planting materials, poor viability of seedlings, poor germination, high incidence of problematic pests and diseases, rapid multiplication, cross resistance
Ongoing adaptations: Small non viable group nurserie, natural pests and disease control without human intervention, use of fruit fly traps but at low levels, leave the fruits to mature to control the sizes
Potential adaptations: Promote/establishment of commercial certified fruit nurseries through policy support, enhanced IPM practices, fruit thinning to manage undersized fruits due to moisture stress

Consequences: Poor quality deisired products: incomplete drying process, loss of market, increased post harvest spoilage, impassable roads, high cost of transportation, added cost of hiring more labour
Ongoing adaptations: Selling raw instead of processed mango products, traders reduce prices to the farmers and high sell to consumers then take care of losses in between, overloading of trucks to cover losses, uncoordinated mango sourcing plans
Potential adaptations: Investment on better processing facilities, investing in specialized mango transporting trucks, usage of crates, developing and implementing reliable governing, transporting and marketing mangoes, well equipped aggregation centres, enacting laws governing mango sourcing from products that it must be through aggregation centres

Consequences: Unavailability and high cost of seeds, affects growth, perfomance and yields, limited access to agrochemicals, flooding will impede transport
Ongoing adaptations: Recycling seeds, traditional practices e.g use of ash, smoke, spraying with pepper solution
Potential adaptations: Use of subsidized certified seeds, subsidized recommended pesticides, crop rotation, use of manure and proper stored manure

Consequences: Unavailability of seeds: drought will discourage stockists from stocking the seeds, low sales: most farmers will not purchase agro chemicals due to lack of rains
Ongoing adaptations: Recycling the seeds, agro dealers breaking down the bulky and selling in small packages, farmers pile their manure for use in the next season
Potential adaptations: Seed bulking, subsidized agrochemicals, farmers to be trained on proper preservation and storage of manure

Consequences: High cost of transportation leading to low returns, irregular/inadequate supply of markets
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers have centralised selling points in nearby shopping centres, farmer to farmer engagement, announcement in barazas and churches, use of middlemen
Potential adaptations: Formation of cooperatives, construction and management of aggregation centres, improvement of infrastructure, use of local media, use of electronic gadgets e.g mobile phones, form websites for market lnkages

Consequences: Dairy cattle especially spend more energy to regulate temperature than to produce milk, this will lead to reduction in milk products, irregular cycle/silent heat, animal heat stress, increased costs of production for milk cooling
Ongoing adaptations: Use of bulls for breeding, awareness of simple husbandry practices(hoof trimming, dehorning, deworming)
Potential adaptations: Upscale use of total mixed rations, farmers to plant fodder crops i.e leukena, calliandra, mulberry, use of sexed semen, use of embryo transfer technology, synchronised heat and services, carrying out pregnancy test on dairy cows, use of disinfectants during cleaning, use of aluminium cans for transporting milk

Consequences: Less milk, prices go up, demand increases, the amount sold is less hence less income
Ongoing adaptations: The dairy cooperatives and individual farmers set the prices, use of milk bars as selling points, selling milk from aggregation centres
Potential adaptations: Contract farming whereby the farmers agree on a constant price for their milk at all seasons, use of milk dispensers, selling packaged milk i.e value added milk,  KEBS standardisation mark to be provided to the certified dairy cooperatives, provide financial loans to equip local milk consumers, introduce agricultural shows/exhibitions in the county

Consequences: Soil moisture stress, shifts in planting dates and plant maturity period, increased costs of inputs and labour for land preparation(weak draught power)
Ongoing adaptations: Use of drought tolerant seed varieties, recycle seed from previous cropping seasons, capacity building of producers on use of both organic and inorganic fertilisers
Potential adaptations: Research water efficient seeds, use available nutrient resources such as manure

Consequences: Reduced vegetative growth, wilting, flowers abortion, early shattering of pods, crop failure
Ongoing adaptations: Conservation agriculture
Potential adaptations: Ensure access to land for production through land sub division, promote irrigation and water harvesting techniques, crop rotation, minimum tillage, cover crops

Consequences: Late land preparation and less area ploughed, low use of improved varieties and fertilizers
Ongoing adaptations: Sub division of family land and land leasing, conservation agriculture and water harvesting, weeding, use of herbicides, oxen power
Potential adaptations: Kitchen garden technology adoption, adjudication of land and sub division to ensure access and use of land, mechanisation e.g planters

Consequences: Prices will tend to go high, demand will go up and selling becomes easy
Ongoing adaptations: Dairy cooperatives and individual farmers, milk traders-unclear, use of milk bars as selling points, selling milk through the aggregation centres
Potential adaptations: Contract farming whereby farmers agree on a constant price for their milk throughout the season with the buyer, use of milk dispensers, sale of packaging milk

Consequences: Reduction of quantity and quality of feed, farmer is forced to spend more to balance the ration, costs will slightly increase, water shortage, increased animal pests and diseases incidence
Ongoing adaptations: Fodder conservation through silage and hay bailing, the farmers have been trained to carry out the simple treatment level practices e.g hoof trimming, dehorning, deworming through radios and barazas, use of certified vaccines
Potential adaptations: Establishment of the drought resistant grass and fodder, employ more extensions workers, increase use of low cost systems for pastures conservation(hay, silage)

Consequences: Poultry feed and water scarcity, heat stress on chicks, poor poultry house ventilation, reduced breeding
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers get breeding stock from outside the county e.g KALRO Naivasha, access drug from agrodealers and service providers, using locally available materials to construct poultry houses
Potential adaptations: Establish breeders within the county, capacity build on local field formulation, establish food processing plant in the county, design and disseminate vaccination programs, establish woodlots to supply construction materials

Consequences: Voluntarily feed intake remains the same, water intake goes up, milk production goes down has insignificant effect
Ongoing adaptations: Concentrates use, use of rations which are not properly mixed in the right proportions, use of bulls for breeding purposes, AI, use of plain water for cleaning purposes
Potential adaptations: Upscale use of mixed rations, farmers for plant fodder crops as protein sources, use of sexed semen, adoption of embryo transfer technology, use of water and dis infectants for cleaning purposes, create awareness to farmers, use of aluminium milk cans for milk transportation

Consequences: Quantity and quality reduce and feed prices go up, cost of the services increase
Ongoing adaptations: Fodder conservation through hay baling and silage making, farmers have been capacity built on how to carry out simple treatment through radios and barazas, magazines and internets
Potential adaptations: Establishment of the drought resistant grass varieties, government to employ more staff and deploy them where the farmers are located, train more of the community, employ more extensions workers, start agricultural show for Makueni county

Consequences: Milk spoilage is fast and shelf life is reduced, costs will increase for transporting less milk the same distance, economics of sale
Ongoing adaptations: Use of water baths to avoid wastage, use of shade nets to bring about cooling, use of charcoal coolers, use of bicycle, foot, PSVs, bodaboda, pick ups and donkeys, use of charcoal and firewood as energy sources to boil milk
Potential adaptations: Use of biogas to provide energy for cooling purposes, use of freezers and coolers, use of tankers to ferry milk from one period to another, use of coolers for refrigeration purposes, use of pasteurizers

Consequences: Escalated incidences of poultry diseases, increased frequency and cost of vaccination, stunted growth and reduced production, high costs of production
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers on highlands rely on purchase of feeds, low land farmers practice free range, reducing of stock, supplement using commercial feed, use of herbal formulations to treat common diseases
Potential adaptations: Enhance local production of feeds, capacity build on feed production, sensitise on storage of feeds, follow vaccination programme, keep improved poultry breeds

Consequences: Reduced animal draught power due to weak animals, reduced capacity to purchase inputs
Ongoing adaptations: Use new adapted seed varieties, seed production, use of animal manure
Potential adaptations: Introduce water use efficient varieties, develop fertiliser recommendations based on local soil tests

Consequences: Goes bad easily, shorter shelf life of milk, reduced milk quality
Ongoing adaptations: Use of shade nets to bring about cooling, use of charcoal coolers, use of water baths for purposes of cooling the milk to avoid milk wastage, use of bicycles, fast PSVs, bodabodas, pick ups and donkeys, use of charcoal and firewood as energy sources for boiling milk
Potential adaptations: Use of biogas to provide energy for cooling purposes, use of freezers and coolers, use of tankers to ferry milk from one point to another, use of pasteurizers

Consequences: Poor market linkages due to low volumes produced, low farm gate prices due to low quality produce
Ongoing adaptations: Grain banks at farm community level
Potential adaptations: Contract farming opportunities

Consequences: Poor market prices, loss of income
Ongoing adaptations: Sell at farm gate, some aggregate and sell as groups, scouting to identify for best market for produce
Potential adaptations: Form cooperatives to aggregate and bulk purchase of inputs, initiate credit facilities for bulk input purchase, introduce policy measure to improve available marketing

Consequences: Low aggregation of fruits at local markets, low prices due to poor quality, reduced product shelf life-fruit rots in storage
Ongoing adaptations: Use of contract farming to improve aggregation and pricing, formation of groups for collective marketing and pricing, early market scouting and setting of price with dealers
Potential adaptations: Conduct market survey to establish market needs and opportunities for farmers, provide credit facilities for local mango trading and transport enterpreneurs

Consequences: Reduced productivity, increased flower abortion, delayed flowering, poor plant establishment, uncontrolled use of banned pesticides(not approved), reduced tree growth rate and vigour
Ongoing adaptations: Use drip irrigation, water harvesting, mulching/use of manure, use early land preparation, conservation agriculture
Potential adaptations: Create local schemes to support and improve farmers capability in good agricultural practices(GAPs) to meet global market needs, crop diversification, agroforestry systems

Consequences: Reduced yields and quality, poor post handling storage and processing, winnowing, sorting, increased post harvest costs of labour(low volume, disease infested produce)
Ongoing adaptations: Use labour intensive post harvest methods like winnowing, air drying
Potential adaptations: Bulk commodity through societies to benefit from economies of scale, construct storage facilities equipped with post harvest machines at community level, introduce policy measure to subsidize investment in mechanisation

Consequences: Low volumes, yield loss
Ongoing adaptations: Manual threshing and winnowing, manual sorting, manual dusting and packaging
Potential adaptations: Set up facilities for mechanical threshing, winnowing, grading and packaging, warehouse reseeding system and storage fertilisers

Consequences: Reduced fruiting and fruit yields, reduced plant population, low fruit quality harvested
Ongoing adaptations: Transport mangoes at night to avoid fruit deterioration in high day temperature, county government subsidy for transport of mangoes, cottage industries set up for local fruit processing
Potential adaptations: Design and install fruit holding containers with cooling facilities, transport in trucks with cooling systems and using fruit crates, local value addition into diverse mango products

Consequences: Cause damage to poultry houses, reduced quantity and quality of local feed processing farm poultry rations, renders road infrastructure impassable
Ongoing adaptations: Use of charcoal to provide heat, practise early vaccination, use of herbs
Potential adaptations: Establish modern houses with power/heat sources, sensitize more on early vaccination and use of vaccination programmes, use of recommended feeds and drug enabled by access to credit, introduce local improved poultry breeds

Consequences: Inadequate supply to the markets, loss of market, low volumes yet high costs of promotion
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are linked to local traders, prices not determined, no measures/weights, no proper promotion
Potential adaptations: Establish commercial linkages, supermarket, processors establish prices based on weight, identify external markets, value addition, branding, establish channels of poultry products promotion

Consequences: High cost of foods, low income, high cost of production, reduced and stunted growth rates
Ongoing adaptations: Leave birds for scaveging, practice a little supplementation, use of herbs, use of improved breeds
Potential adaptations: Capacity build on feed production, water harvesting and storage, practice semi intensive rearing, use of vaccination program, facilitation to access improved breeds, use technologies, incubation, serials/synchronised hatching

Consequences: Reduced seedling vigour, increased incidences of pest attack, reduced soil moisture
Ongoing adaptations: Increased surveillance of stockist to ensure stocking of approved pesticides, supplement soil moisture using water harvesting technologies, soil conservation, agroforestry, conservation agriculture
Potential adaptations: Introduce IPM and crop management techniques to support commercial fruit production, install large water harvesting farm ponds

Consequences: Very little to collect, high cost for collecting, high cost of transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Collection centers are at group level, use of private motorvehicles, use of middlemen, sell at farm gate
Potential adaptations: Establish collection points at subcounties, cooperative to establish a major bulking point, improve on transportatioon carriers, cooperative to provide motorvehicles for transport, establish clear rules for chicken transportation, introduce value addition infrastructure

Consequences: High mortality rates, impassable roads, high costs of transportation due to low volumes and increased perishability
Ongoing adaptations: Ensure ventilation of the products during storage and transport
Potential adaptations: Improve infrastructure, improve on farm feed storage facilities

Consequences: Poor linkages as a result of low volumes of sale, low egg prices, delayed access to market
Ongoing adaptations: Reduced linkages due to low volumes, willing seller willing buyer agreement at farm gate
Potential adaptations: Enhance production technologies, enhance feed production and storage, introducing pricing based on determined weights

Consequences: Lack of availability of seeds, reduced purchase of pesticides and other farm inputs
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local more drought resistant varieties, use of ash in place of IPM with neem tree, capsicum and hot peppers
Potential adaptations: Capacity build farmers on more IPM, seed bulking, capacity building on local certified seed production

Consequences: Loss of market value (low prices), loss of livestock loss of transport business due to lack of livestock for sale
Ongoing adaptations: Slaughter at household level, sales of roasted goat meat, drying/smoking
Potential adaptations: Establish shaded holding grounds and cold storage facilities, construct abattoirs

Consequences: Leads to poor quality produce leading to poor promotion of the produce, there is reduced or less linkage of farmers to buyers
Ongoing adaptations: Promotion of tomato value chain, use of middlemen to link the produce to the market, farm gate sales to reduce chances of spoilage before sales
Potential adaptations: Capacity building of tomato farmers on increased promotion, construction of shaded vegetable marketing centres

Consequences: Quality of stock is affected due to poor body condition, low breeding, increased distance in search of water/pasture, high maintenance cost (labour, water, feeding, herding), increased pests and diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Water trucking by government, construction of underground tank, individual water pans, mass treatment and deworming, movement of herd to water sources
Potential adaptations: Research on resilient breeds and improved grazing management, consolidated herding, upscaling of water harvesting techniques, training of community disease monitors

Consequences: Reduced market value of stock, reduced volumes for processing, household consumption
Ongoing adaptations: Increased offtake(destocking), home slaughtering and consumption, meat drying
Potential adaptations: Support value addition activities(meat drying), construct abattoirs and cold storage facilities, capacity building on appropriate destocking

Consequences: Most of it utilized at household level hence there will be nothing/little to sell to the market hence promotion activity will be none or minimal, shortages on local markets, low returns for farmers and traders
Ongoing adaptations: Household consumption, farm gate and local market sales, marketing at agricultural shows and demonstrations, sharing market information from farmer to farmer
Potential adaptations: Support access to external markets, improve feeder roads, establishment of sorghum marketing association

Consequences: Delay in land preparation, washing away of the seedlings or may die due to the excess water in the soil
Ongoing adaptations: Local drainage for draining water away from the farms, pest and disease control, raised seed bed, increased frequency of farm operations
Potential adaptations: Land drainage infrastructure in the areas prone to flooding, innovations and research towards specific pests and disease affecting tomatoes (red spider mites), the use of trays and treated cocopits for better nursery establishment to avoid soil borne disease, promotion of green house farming

Consequences: Activities reduced since heat affects farm labour, reduced seedling germination rates, frequent watering resulting in increased labour and financial requirements, increased cases of pests and diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Ploughing during cool hours (early in the morning and the evening), mulching, irrigation
Potential adaptations: Promote water harvesting and drip irrigation, capacity building on tomato shading, promotion of conservation agriculture(mulching, minimum tillage and intercropping)

Consequences: Unpredictable supply and availability of seed, fertiliser and other inputs due to uncertainty in season start, loss of planted seeds, limited purchase of pesticides and other agrochemicals
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local drought resistant varieties, seed selection from previous harvests, seed preservation and storage using ash, IPM with neem tree, capsicum and hot peppers
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on seed conservation and bulking, capacity building on appropriate seed selection(short season and early maturing varieties), capacity build more farmers on IPM, improve agrometeorological information

Consequences: Low prices of livestock for farmers, low volumes traded, low linkages, livelihoods affected
Ongoing adaptations: Brokerage by middlemen, local sales and consumption
Potential adaptations: Contract farming, use of auction system, upscale value addition

Consequences: Reduced livestock volumes, reduced prices leading to reduced incomes, low market linkages, low income to farmers
Ongoing adaptations: Slaughtering, brokerage/middlemen
Potential adaptations: Promotion of the product, linkage of farmers to external markets and butcheries, establish market information system for goat meat

Consequences: Reduced feed consumption resulting in slower growth, increased water needs, increased pests and disease management requirements
Ongoing adaptations: Water trucking, movement of herd to water sources, culling of weak or ageing animals
Potential adaptations: Train farmers on construction of goat enclosures, water and fodder cost sharing system between farmers

Consequences: Increased cost of feed, poor quality of feeds, reduced breeding
Ongoing adaptations: Feed supplementation and fodder production and storage
Potential adaptations: Training on silage production and feed conservation, dissemination of feed formulation technologies and information, promote drought tolerant breeds

Consequences: Less production of tomatoes due to intense rains leading to decreased promotion, mobility is affected and not efficient due to impassable roads
Ongoing adaptations: Sales to middlemen, lowering of prices for low quality produce, producer will deliver produce manually to the most accessible point, middlemen determine the product prices, combining of transport to collection centres
Potential adaptations: Farmer capacity building on tomato marketing, repair and construction of access roads, capacity building of cooperatives in marketing and sales

Consequences: Spoilage when harvested and during transportation, high temperature increases losses, faster deterioration of quality of the produce
Ongoing adaptations: Transporting during cool hours in the morning and in the evening, selling at the farm gate to avoid wastage, shading of produce with grass
Potential adaptations: Construction of tomato processing plant in Mandera county, construction of shaded collection and grading centres, training on tomato storage and value addition

Consequences: Feed and browse scarcity, animal death, higher feed requirements and costs, reduced breeding
Ongoing adaptations: Zakkah migration in search of pasture and water, tracing of the farmers by the extension officers, local inbreeding
Potential adaptations: Managing of grazing land, reafforestation, natural resource management, promote AI and feed and fodder produuction

Consequences: Reduced moisture content affects viability/losses viability resulting to poor germination, wilting and death of some seedlings
Ongoing adaptations: Obtaining seeds from government or research organisations
Potential adaptations: Conservation agriculture, research for drought tolerant seeds specific for Mandera county

Consequences: Roads not accessible, produce reaching the market is affected, spoilage of produce in the farm due to improper storage facility
Ongoing adaptations: Delay harvesting until rain stops, use of polythene sheets for covering produce, suspend collection until rain stops
Potential adaptations: Improved construction of farm access, construction of modern storage facilities, investment in tomato processing plant in the county, construction of raised and covered sheds on farm

Consequences: Low availability of stock for replenishment of herds, scarcity of forage and feed, scarcity of water
Ongoing adaptations: Water troughs near breeding stock, fodder production, feed supplementation
Potential adaptations: Training on production and conservation of homemade feeds, promote drought tolerant breeds, enhanced drought early warning system

Consequences: Reduced income for farmers, on farm consumption, reduced quantities available for sales
Ongoing adaptations: Household consumption, farm gate and local market sales, marketing at agricultural shows, bazaars and demonstrations, sharing market information from farmer to farmer
Potential adaptations: Support access to external markets, improve feeder roads, establishment of sorghum marketing association, link farmers directly to processors(rather than middlemen)

Consequences: Unavailability and high price of the stock, animal death due to lack of pasture, high prices of feeds
Ongoing adaptations: Water trucking, migration of animals in search of water and pasture
Potential adaptations: Drilling of boreholes, underground water tanks, rain water harvesting, managing of grazing lands avoid cross border interaction of animals to minimise spread of disease

Consequences: Low milk production, low supply of milk hence poor collection, high cost and time for transportation of milk, heat and pressure build up in milk containers
Ongoing adaptations: Awareness raising on milk hygiene, milk collection and sales using jerricans, consumption of milk at household level
Potential adaptations: Use of aluminium containers for transportation, capacity building on milk handling and distribution of modern milk handling equipment, construction of milk collection and cold storage facilities along strategic livestock routes

Consequences: Disruption of milk market linkages, reduced income for farmers, increased price of the commodity for consumers, less volumes available for sale
Ongoing adaptations: Individual sales at local market or to vendors, use of informal/passenger vehicles for transport to the market
Potential adaptations: Use of local FM stations to promote the milk, use of portable fridges, construction of milk sale sheds, support camel milk producer groups

Consequences: Reduced produce storage, low demand of storage chemicals, reduced volume of crop produce for processing, low value addition
Ongoing adaptations: Use of bakaras, traditionsl cribs and kodos for storage, use of ash for preservation, use of traditional mortal and pestle for dehusking grains, grinding using traditional grinders for sorghum, home winnowing and beating
Potential adaptations: Concrete underground structure for storage, use of silo, use of gunny bags and plastic bags, modern raised grannaries, use of mechanized dehuskers and shellers, use of posho mills, capacity building on product sterilisation and marketing

Consequences: Low storage of farm produce due to poor yield, storage equipment demand is low, increased post harvest weevil infestation, no crop produce for processing, low income from value addition
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local storage e.g use of crib (kodo), use of ash to control weevils, dehusking and grinding using mortal and pestle, early harvesting to avoid losses to pests
Potential adaptations: Promote modern storage structures (raised or underground), silos, plastic bags, promotion of dehuskers and posho mills, promote aided drying of produce using driers

Consequences: Intense rains leads to flooding, increased price of the seeds, reduced acess to seeds and other inputs, flood damage to seeds and seedlings in nurseries
Ongoing adaptations: Flood control through construction of gabions, distribution of certified seeds, use of raised seed beds for seedlings
Potential adaptations: Construction of a mega dam to control floods, provision of enough certified seeds to farmers, repair and construction of access roads

Consequences: Difficulty in collecting milk for bulking, low volumes for bulking, high costs of transportation-buyers need to travel further into the interior to look for milk
Ongoing adaptations: Use of jericans for milk collection and sales, consumption of milk at household level
Potential adaptations: Use of aluminum containers for transportation, capacity building on milk handling and distribution of milk handling equipment, construction of milk collection and cold storage facilities along strategic livestock routes

Consequences: Reduced access to market information, inconsistent milk supply, low prices for farmers
Ongoing adaptations: Group sales and marketing, using motorbikes to transport milk
Potential adaptations: Promotion of animal products in radios and tvs, use of local fm stations and tvs for advertisement, construction of milk shades for the sellers, support milk producers and seller groups countywide financially, promotion of refrigerated milk transportation

Consequences: Low breeding success, low productivity, no vaccination/deworming is done during high temperatures since animals are weak from heat stress and cannot withstand vaccines, more time spent in tracking animals which have moved in search of fodder, difficulty in managing livestock health
Ongoing adaptations: General livestock health management- deworming and hoof trimming
Potential adaptations: Capacity building of the farmers to maximize breeding when temperatures are conducive, tree planting for shade

Consequences: Reduced milk production, low breeding success, animals are weak and hence cannot be vaccinated, more time spent in tracking animals that have moved in search of fodder, browse and water, difficulty in managing livestock health due to far distances animals migrate
Ongoing adaptations: Local breeding, government mass vaccination deworming/treatment, movement of herd to water sources and better pastures
Potential adaptations: Drilling of boreholes, underground water tanks, rain water harvesting, managing of grazing lands avoid cross border interaction of animals to minimise spread of disease, capacity building of community livestock health workers

Consequences: Extra labour and costs in land preparation, low seed germination rate, wilting of crops, crop failure
Ongoing adaptations: Farming along laggas(where water collects naturally), use of conservation agriculture practices(minimum tillage), in field soil and water conservation methods, early dry planting
Potential adaptations: Construction of check dams and stone bunds to increase water infiltration, promote intercropping with cowpeas, capacity building on appropriate spacing and plant density to minimise competition for water

Consequences: Farmers will lag behind in land preparation activities, few farmers will plough the land, untimely planting leading to poor yields, reduced acreage under crop production, uncertainty in planning farm operations
Ongoing adaptations: Infield basin construction, contour farming on hilly land, staggered planting, early weeding, use of indigenous knowledge to inform seasonal activities
Potential adaptations: Construction of check dams and stone bunds to increase water infiltration, investment in mechanized ploughing using tractors, mechanized planters and mechanized drying using dryers, improve access to extension advice(planting dates)

Consequences: Accelerated perishability, high moisture loss after harvesting reduced volume of produce,  low production per unit area
Ongoing adaptations: Harvesting in the early morning and late evening, soak in water after harvest bulking, use of plastic bags and transported on wheelbarrows to collect points transported in plastic bags on motor cycles, bicycles and vehicles
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on post-harvest handling, establish cold rooms at bulking sites, road infrastructure development and maintenance

Consequences: Impaired market information access: few people engaged in the value chain due to low production, high cost of promotion: while assuring the freshness of the produce
Ongoing adaptations: Use of mobile phones to get market information, use of word of mouth to promote their products sale as individuals and small groups
Potential adaptations: Investing in use of mass media (local dialect), use of mass media, promotion on utilization of kales and value addition technologies like solar drying, support formation and capacity building of new and existing marketing associations

Consequences: Low production, high cost of promotion: consumers demand is high due to limited supply, poor quality kales are hard to sell
Ongoing adaptations: Use of mobile phones to make orders, use of word of mouth during selling, sell as individuals and small groups
Potential adaptations: Use mass media to share market information, Promotion on utilization and value addition, formation of large marketing groups (cooperatives), Training on commercial village model

Consequences: Reduced working hours: high temperatures affect working hours, tractors boiling etc high transpiration and evaporation rate, increases in irrigation water loss and plant transpiration
Ongoing adaptations: Start early in the morning and do few hours per day, reduced watering intervals, mulching and watering during cool hours, use of cultural methods to control pests and diseases
Potential adaptations: Support to subsidized mechanized land preparation for faster tilling, support use of water efficient technologies e.g shed net, greenhouses, drip irrigation, support capacity building on solarization of soil and IPM

Consequences: Shortage of seeds: reduction in stocks of suppliers due to low demand, reduced extension service delivery:  low activity in the farm and migration among agro-pastoralism
Ongoing adaptations: Purchase from stockists, information through mass media and mobile phones, purchase from input suppliers
Potential adaptations: Saving and sourcing through cooperatives, capacity building of stockists, establishment of farmer field schools, savings and sourcing through cooperatives

Consequences: Increased loss of vegetable: high moisture loss leading to reduced quality, increased field heat during bulking due to high temperature during day time aggregation
Ongoing adaptations: Harvesting done during cool hours and sprinkle water during hot hours, use of plastic bags by individual farmers, using various means to collect points transported in plastic bags, using motor cycles, bicycles and vehicles to the market
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on post harvest handling, support of equipments for drying of vegetables, support establishment of cold chains in established production sites, support feeder road construction and maintenance

Consequences: Increased vet costs: more vet service required (drugs for stress), Spoilt drugs spoils some equipments e.g. knapsack sprayers
Ongoing adaptations: Storage of drugs at home and traditional treatment practised, traditional ways of spraying/handressing sprinkle using tree branches, borrowing of equipments, division of labour( different members of family are assigned at different task/duties, increase watering intervals of animals
Potential adaptations: Provision of drugs store/storage equipments at convegence zones, implementation of mobile clinics, implementation of modern methods of spraying e.g use of dip, spray race, capacity building on proper use of modern equipments, practice to keep managable number of animals, use of modern techniques e.g generator to pump water, capacity building on drought

Consequences: Poor access of vet services: lack of resources to afford vet services and migration from nearby vet officers, equipments are unaffordable due to low income(poor prices)
Ongoing adaptations: Storage of vet drugs at home, reuse of disposable equipments, increase animal watering intervals at wells, youth/middle herding, women and children feeding the weak at home (division of labor)
Potential adaptations: Establish drugs store within reach and mobile clinics at watering points, training on benefits of reusable needle and syringes, improve water services (boreholes, dams), reduce livestock population through training of destocking

Consequences: Reduced acreage due to high labor requirements, harsh working conditions due to high temperatures, low affordability for labour services, reduced and weak family labour, insufficient water for irrigation: low yielding of aquifers and high temperature rates
Ongoing adaptations: Start early before the season and early in the day, using family labor, using of harvested water from micro-catchment, use of traditional methods/ biological control
Potential adaptations: Subsidized machinery services to farmers with assorted implements, construction of mega water harvesting structures, support on capacity building on IPM

Consequences: Farmers not able to access inputs(seeds) from the market due to inaccessibility of roads, farmers not able to access extension officers due to poor road conditions rendering them impassable
Ongoing adaptations: Use of stored seeds from previous crop harvest, use of indigenous technical knowledge, use of own resources (land, preserved seeds, labour)
