Potential adaptations: Provision of certified seeds to farmers during dry spell, research on suitable seed variety, provision of extension services to farmers during dry spell, establish of financial package suitable for financing teff farming

Consequences: No effect on seeds: seeds/planting materials are available from previous season, low dissemination of extension information: farmers are not available for extension services for they have moved in search of pasture and water for livestock
Ongoing adaptations: Use of seeds stored from previous seasons, use of their resources (seeds, tools, labour)
Potential adaptations: Provision of drought tolerant certified seeds to farmers, development of training materials, establishment of demo farms, establishment of financial product suitable for supporting teff farming

Consequences: Inaccessibility of other markets: difficulty to access markets due to poor road network, hiking of prices; low supply of the product
Ongoing adaptations: Store the produce, increase price due to low volumes, purchase from other markets
Potential adaptations: Upgrading of roads connecting to other markets to be all weather roads, support traders financially to procure teff from Ethiopia and other markets

Consequences: Reduced prices due to poor body condition, uncertainty in availability and prices for consumers, reduced markets for skin, poor quality hides, low prices for goats
Ongoing adaptations: Watering interval reduced to improve body condition, immediate selling of skin, selling to the local markets without facilities and at low prices
Potential adaptations: Provision of improved facilities (processing, storage, value addition), building capacity in slaughtering, processing and storage, provision of favourable conditions in the market and storage facilities, organised marketing channels with market facilities, setting aside marketing days

Consequences: Reduced seed viability, high temperatures in the stores, reduced extension delivery; reduced contact time with the clients, few hours taken to disseminate the message
Ongoing adaptations: Preservation of local variety seeds, use of massmedia and phones to share information, individual procurement from input suppliers
Potential adaptations: Encourage savings by producer members in their associations for purchase of seeds during drought, support farmer field schools extension model, support capacity building on savings and loaning system to boost purchasing power

Consequences: Rotting of seeds, Wash away of seeds: seeds rot and fail to germinate/ seeds washed away by runoff, regeneration of weeds and difficulty in weeding: weeds regenerate very fast if farm is left unweeded
Ongoing adaptations: Sow seeds after onset of rains (2 weeks after) or wait till first torrent rain are over, wait for weeds to emerge after rains and then prepare land and sow teff seeds, cut and dry on beds arranged in apex form
Potential adaptations: Establishment of onfarm retention ditches, cut off drains and other soil conservation structures during dry spell, use of pre-emergence chemical weed control, timely and mechanization of harvesting, use of driers

Consequences: Delayed planting: farmers will delay planting while waiting for the rains, delay in weeding: farmers fear weeding during dry spell
Ongoing adaptations: No planting, no weeding to prevent excess moisture loss, timely harvest
Potential adaptations: Early/dry planting, establishment of micro water harvesting structures, use of pre emergence chemical weed control, mechanization of harvesting

Consequences: Low volume available for processing: no harvesting takes place and roads to transport for processing are inaccessible, rotting of produce: poorly stored produce gets affected by water
Ongoing adaptations: Processors source produce from alternative markets, store on straw i.e delay processing, use of donkeys to transport
Potential adaptations: Establishment of cottage processing centres near the farms, provision of pottable processing machines to farmers, establishment of good storage facility during dry spell, improvement (construction) of all weather roads

Consequences: Low volumes available for processing: low production causes low volumes available, no effect on storage:  drought is a favourable environment for storage
Ongoing adaptations: Source produce to process from other market,s no storing-sell direct to consumers, use of available means of transportation which are donkeys
Potential adaptations: Provision of portable processing machines to farmers, packaging and labelling, construction of appropriate storage facility, establishment of cottage industries for processing near the farms

Consequences: Reduced gutting activities hence reduced incomes for people who do gutting, reduced number of fish from gutting, high maintenance cost: ice in cold chain melts faster
Ongoing adaptations: Going to deeper waters to catch more fish to increase gutting, increase of cold chain facility with high efficiency, bulk transportation of fish product to market
Potential adaptations: Research and invest into predicting where fish population will move, reduced cost to increase efficiency, invest in high efficient cold chain facility, processing of fish within the area to increase shelf life, improve sanitation landing site

Consequences: Reduced use of gutting slabs: number of fish for gutiing reduces hence reduced activity, increased ice melting: drought predisposes high temperatures which increases melting
Ongoing adaptations: Reduction of labour and closing of gutting slabs, drying of fish on site, development of cold rooms on-site, marketing by fisherfolk as opposed to transporting to terminal market, formation of cooperatives
Potential adaptations: Purchase of gutting equipments to enable standardization of processing and increase value, developing cold room/chain along all fishing landing site, enable bulk transportation, strengthen of cooperatives and supporting them with equipment and training needs

Consequences: Lack of feed: not enough feed (depleted pastures), lack of water, no breeding (mating) due to poor body condition: weak goats dont come on heat
Ongoing adaptations: Migration to areas with feeds, natural and uncontrolled pastoralists treat the goats on their own, intervention based vaccination by government
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on grazing planning and fodder bulking, introduce superior breed adopted in the area (galla), controlled breeding, evidence based treatment, routine vaccinations should be implemented

Consequences: Increased slaughtering, meat spoilage, reduced transportation, goats die during transportation, increased number of days/labour while trekking of goats
Ongoing adaptations: Early and late evening and night transportation, early slaughtering of goats when temperature are cool, trekking of animals at morning, nights and late evening
Potential adaptations: Construction of improved holding/resting areas, establishment of feedlots at strategic points, improve slaughtering facilities e.g storage, provision of market channels, improved transportation and transportation of carcasses under refrigeration

Consequences: Drop in price: poor animal body condition, uncertainity and high prices, lack of market for by-products such as hides, no market for skin, poor quality skin
Ongoing adaptations: Selling direct to buyers and by pass middlemen, used at home as saddle, home utilization, selling the goat in other markets other than the conventional markets at lower prices
Potential adaptations: Sale by weight or introduce standardization system, introduce livestock auctions, value addition to the by product, develop industry for the by product, access market information, introduce the market days in all livestock market

Consequences: Poor quality of feeds: dry fast, reduced mating: due to stress and poor body condition, less feed is available
Ongoing adaptations: Migration to points where there are forages, send selected agents to look for reliable grazing zones, cutting down of tree branches, depend on natural mating/uncontrolled breeding system, non evidence based treatment by pastoralists, irregular intervention by government (vaccination)
Potential adaptations: Conservations of grazing zones/mapping of rangeland, empowerment of grazing management committes, encourage practice of keeping minimal number of animals, control breeding/modern methods, upgrading of goat breeds (galla), evidence based treatment (laboratory diagnosis), provision of mobile vet services at grazing convergence zones, improved drugs storage facilities

Consequences: Reduced market access due to reduced shelf life and increased refrigeration costs, high costs of truck maintenance, little to market: little catch leading to less marketing activities
Ongoing adaptations: Drying of fish on site and transport to destination market, rely on traditional fish marketing systems, dried fish transported to Kisumu and Western region (bulking of daily catch could take up to 2 weeks)
Potential adaptations: Access high value markets, research and investment technologies value addition, diversification of product development of fish industries and direct export to market expansion to other markets, diplomacy interventions

Consequences: Reduced catch value: reduces volume of the catch as fish moves to deeper waters, low breeding: high temperatures leads to slow sexual activity among the fish
Ongoing adaptations: Fishing done in the morning/evening due to high temperatures during the day, allow children to cnduct fishing along the shores, fishing in deeper offshore waters
Potential adaptations: Use of motorized boats with cool boxes/ice packs, controlled fishing in breeding areas by institution responsible, use of standardized fishing net size, routine inspection undertaken by BMVs and KWS and fisheries staff

Consequences: Reduced bulking due to migration and lack of access, increased slaughtering, increased demand for food, poor prices for the live goats
Ongoing adaptations: Collection of goats to one site and herd them to sale, slaughtering young animals, slaughter for business and home use, trekking and lorry not organized transport
Potential adaptations: Construction of holding area (to accomodate goats during bulking), establishment of feed lots at different strategic points, slaughtering mature animals that have attained good market weight, improvement of slaughtering facilities, provision of market channels, organization of mobile market during drought at grazing points, provision of security

Consequences: Increased maintenance cost for refrigerating equipment: high temperatures contributes to high maintenace cost of refrigeration, low promotion activities: when the catch is low, marketing or promotion activity is low
Ongoing adaptations: Drying of fish when transporting them which leads to loss of value, awareness creation and promotion of fish eating culture, fish eating campaign, procurement of cold chain selling at the local market
Potential adaptations: Encourage uptake of cluster transportation to reduce the loss, gap identification of terminal market/high value market, value addition, advertisements, diversification of markets and product information services for anticipation of price and market shock policy

Consequences: Low acquisition of fishing gear, hence supplier getting less, affects training: all resources re-directed to emergency and recovery
Ongoing adaptations: Use of dhows since the other equipment get expensive, traditional way of passing message in groups especially in the morning and evening, borrowing from family members
Potential adaptations: Use of engine boats/trailers/modern nets, training on modern technologies, modern halls, maintenance, fishing business/marketing, borrowing from recognized financial institutions and assistance from faith based organizations/NGOs

Consequences: Reduced catch, since fish migrate to deep waters, fishing in breeding site: invasion of breeding sites is illegal
Ongoing adaptations: Fishing at night during cool hours of the day, do fishing in breeding zone illegally, no standardized nets among fishing community, doing business as usual by using the traditinal unstandardized nets
Potential adaptations: Done at night by use of motorized boat and use of modern gear, BMV and fisheries staffs involved in breed site protection, KWS and marine deployed at Sibilio National Park, modernized net with good catch, controlled fishing sizes, contol pollution of the lake

Consequences: Low linkage: little produce is available for outside markets, price hiking: prices increase due to low supply of the produce
Ongoing adaptations: Sell to available markets, locally sell to the best market/buyer, source best prices/market
Potential adaptations: Formation of farmer cooperatives to enhance marketing, establishment of insurance policy to cover farm losses, subsidize inputs to reduce production cost, employ sales promotion strategies (advertisement, posters), target institutions e.g hospitals, schools

Consequences: Demand for fishing gear increases making it expensive,  degradation of fishing gears (fishing nets, life jackets), reduced activity such as trainings:  high temperatures affects movement and time
Ongoing adaptations: Use of baskets, rafts/canoe and spearing for fishing, on job training-teaching how to fish the hardest way and allowing other (children) to do shore fishing, borrowing from community members, short term borrowing, merry go round
Potential adaptations: Use of modern fishing gear, motorized boats and fishing rods, professional involvement, use of modern facilities e.g hall, use of local language during trainings, borrowing from microfinance institutions, establishment of financial institutions

Consequences: Shortage of manure for planting, uptake of manure and fertiliser compromised due to leaching
Ongoing adaptations: Making furrows to control the flood water, digging trenches to minimize erosion, tree planting in nursery fields, acquiring planting material from research and aid organizations
Potential adaptations: Harvesting of rain water by building water pans and dams, establish raised nurseries, outsourcing clean planting material from government and development organizations, input access through fertilizer subsidies

Consequences: Water shortage for irrigation, poor/stunted planting material, poor nursery vigour and increased seedling mortality
Ongoing adaptations: Use of water pans from households and use of drip irrigation in nursery tuber preparation
Potential adaptations: Construction of mega dams, supply of clean planting materials by research institutions

Consequences: Quality of the produce is compromised due to muddy wet conditions, difficult to find buyers due to muddy markets
Ongoing adaptations: Use of wooden platforms to place bananas at marketing, market manipulation by producers through delayed marketing(scarcity/increase demand)
Potential adaptations: Put up modern markets with relevant facilities like platforms, loading bays and with proper hygienic standards

Consequences: Lack of contracts, lack of markets(reduced marketing activities)
Ongoing adaptations: Promotion of the local consumption and sale to community, post harvest value addition(flour/wine)
Potential adaptations: Capacity building(marketing opportunities), value addition of banana pseudostem(agroprocessing into wine, flour, crisps), mineral supplementation to post harvest  products, flexible market pricing(quality dependent)

Consequences: Difficulty in land preparation, cannot plough, difficulty in harvesting, not easy to move in the farms, pests and diseases incidence, weak stems unable to support fruits
Ongoing adaptations: Digging trenches to drain water in the farm and pits, integrated pests and diseases management, use of manual labour to perform agronomic activities, establish structures to support mature banana stems, minimum tillage
Potential adaptations: Widespread campaign for soil and land conservation structures(support by county and state governments), research and promotion of moisture tolerant banana varieties

Consequences: Planting materials drying from lack of water after planting, poor stand establishment, reduced growth rates and plant vigour
Ongoing adaptations: Use of conservation agriculture(minimum tillage), agroforestry and intercropping with trees, application of organic manures and mulches, application of pesticides and insecticides, enterprise diversification, growing cover crops, crop insurance
Potential adaptations: Adoption of green housing for banana and irrigation, research to come up with drought resistant banana varieties

Consequences: Roads are impassable hence transportation is difficult- cannot reach markets due to impassable roads which leads to increased fruit perishability, reduced harvest
Ongoing adaptations: Community mobilization to improve the access to roads and facilitate transport to storage facilities, improved storage structures(above ground and moisture free)
Potential adaptations: Make the roads all weather, promote moisture free banana facilities

Consequences: Spoilage/perishability of fruits, low quality and quantity of harvested yields
Ongoing adaptations: Dry storage covered with banana stems, application of pest control chemicals, use of traditional banana preservatives(salt) to reduce perishability
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on good harvest husbandry practices(hygiene, post harvest handling, storage)

Consequences: More drugs demand due to increased chances of diseases e.g mastistis, distribution problems of drugs, feeds and supplies due to poor roads
Ongoing adaptations: More agrovets stocking, use of efficient transport means(bodaboda) to access inputs, feed conservation, access to free vaccines
Potential adaptations: Improved road network to facilitate inputs access, promote improved cattle breeds(GIRR), promote commercial fodder growin and feed conservation technologies

Consequences: High costs of inputs(drugs, pastures) due to icreased refrigeration and storage requirements, inaccessibility to high quality breeding seed
Ongoing adaptations: Provision of subsidized drugs to farmers(aid organization), use of local animal breeding stocks, seek alternative medicinal sources(indigenous knowledge), feed supplements(hire balers, rakers), use of crop residues as feeds
Potential adaptations: Provision of subsidized drugs to farmers through county and aid agencies, commercial fodder growing and feed conservation

Consequences: Low /late supply to the market, high cost of distribution by processors-due to transport challenges, reduced market activities and reduced marketing opportunities
Ongoing adaptations: Divertion of milk to local consumption(household) and sale(community), engagement with milk buying companies/organizations, supply to local towns and institutions
Potential adaptations: Improved road infrastructure to facilitate market access, use of refrigerated vehicles, forming robust farmer organizations for milk marketing, government control of milk marketing to prevent farmer exploitation

Consequences: High prices-due to low production supplies, fast spoilage-higher chances of spoilage due to high temperatures
Ongoing adaptations: Production of long life products and short life(UHT, processed/dried), prices are based on supply and demand
Potential adaptations: Extend shelf life of more product range by use of modern technology, more preservation facilities during production to cater for dry periods, implement a price determination policy

Consequences: Increased cost of prodution-due to higher usage of drugs and inputs, low profitabilty-due to low production and high costs of production, increased pests and diseases incidence, reduced animal vigour, reduced cattle weight
Ongoing adaptations: Supplementing feeds with mineral concentrates, proper animal husbandry(keeping animals in dry sheds), drug administering and application of insect repellents, enterprise diversification(crop growing)
Potential adaptations: Development and implementation of flood management and control policies, provision of subsidized drugs to farmers

Consequences: Reduced animal vigour and high pests and diseases susceptibility, increased animal mortality, increased production costs(increased drugs usage, low fodder availability)
Ongoing adaptations: Introduction of disease resistant animal breeds, disease control, fodder and pasture preservation(silage/hay)
Potential adaptations: Provision of subsidized drugs and vaccines, development of early warning systems and advisories, enhanced extension and veterinary services to farmers, sensitization of fodder preservation and conservation technologies

Consequences: Compromised milk quality(watery milk), low profitability due to high transport and handling costs, increased perishability due to poor/damaged infrastructure
Ongoing adaptations: Rejection of unhygienic milk, major road are being improved, processors shares transportation costs with the farmers, use of clean equipment to handle and store milk, capacity building programs on milk production
Potential adaptations: Intensify extension services on clean milk production, improve main and feeder roads, improve on milk bulking and storage at community and regional levels, improved infrastructure(ease road transport)

Consequences: Fast spoilage/perishability of milk-due to high temperatures, more costs due to usage of cooling temperatures-due to high temperatures
Ongoing adaptations: Introduction of more cooling centres, using electricity to run coolers
Potential adaptations: Even distribution of cooling facilities in all areas, pursue use of solar as source of power to manage dairy production activities, construction of centralized storage and refrigeration centres(community based)

Consequences: Damaged inputs-flooding destroys stored inputs causing losses to the stockists and also farmers, increased cost of production, this is as a result of over pricing of inputs due to poor/impassable roads, flooding destroys bridges and makes most roads impassable hence hampering the process of input supply
Ongoing adaptations: Early purchase of inputs, early land preparation and planting, construction of improved stores, bulk collective purchase for sharing within farmer members, community led efforts to ease transport through road repairs
Potential adaptations: Construction of communal storage structures, PMO strengthening structures for acquiring inputs directly from the companies/manufacturers, ease input access through roads rehabilitation

Consequences: Dessication-this depletes the stored seed food reserves, poor quality of planting material
Ongoing adaptations: Covering the potatoes seeds with dry matter, storage of potato suckers in open and dry shed, proper tuber sorting and storage according to state
Potential adaptations: Irrigation/construction of difused potato seed store, increased access to improved tuber varieties, establishment of community based large scale potato bulking, research on heat tolerant potato varieties

Consequences: Short shelf life-this is caused by poor quality of the potato during harvesting and storage, unstable/poor prices-this is as a result of poor potato quality-brought about by flooding, market inaccesibility due to destruction of market structures and limited opportunities
Ongoing adaptations: Selling immediately after harvest to avoid losses during storage, selling at a throw away price(prevailing market prices), targeting formal buyers e.g schools ,hotels and hospitals
Potential adaptations: Construction of modern storage facilities, value addition through processing of crisps and chips

Consequences: Poor quality of potatoes as a result of shrinking due to heat loss- are priced poorly at the markets, poor quality of post harvest value added products
Ongoing adaptations: Covering with dry matter to prevent extreme heat, sorting and grading of product for different products, join together with local associations for best tuber price bargains
Potential adaptations: Construct diffused storage for seed potato to improve the storage, farmer associations to market produce locally and externally, explore post harvest value added products

Consequences: Rotting-this is as a result of water logging, soil erosion and degradation-this reduces fertility of the soil and the soil structure, loss of planted materials through sweeping away in the slopy areas, poor stand establishment, delayed planting and crop husbandry operations, high pests and diseases incidence
Ongoing adaptations: Escavating furrows to drain the flooded water, crop rotation, construction of gabions, planting cover crops, planting grass strips, terracing escavation and also water harvesting trenches
Potential adaptations: Water harvesting through escavation of terraces and water pans, minimum tillage, conservation agriculture practising, reclamation of degraded land, adoption of water harvesting technologies both at farm level and at community level

Consequences: Plants wilting, shortened crop cycle, poor stand establishment and crop vigour, increased incidence of pests and diseases, low quality tubers(discoloration from exposure to sunlight)
Ongoing adaptations: Use of efficient irrigation, mulching, intercropping with maize, tree planting, conservation agriculture, use of organic manures, use of chemicals to prevent early sprouting, early planting
Potential adaptations: Use of drip irrigation, explore opportunities of intensive intercropping with newly emerging crops, government support to communal potato propagation efforts

Consequences: Rotting-mostly happens when the storage structures get flooded, difficulties in aggregation and bulking-this is as a result of poor road network caused by flooding
Ongoing adaptations: Selling immediately at a throw away price, underpricing, short period drying under tree shades, use of localised means of transports e.g carts and boda bodas
Potential adaptations: Construction of modern high quality storage facilities at strategic points in the community, establishment of village level aggregation centres from which buyers can access the produce at favorable times

Consequences: Pre mature sprouting of harvested and improperly stored tubers, increased incidence of storage pests(rodents)
Ongoing adaptations: Harvest and sell at gate after observations of tuber sprouting, pest and rodent control using baits and traps
Potential adaptations: Improved storage facility constructed at village level for potato seeds, rely on early warning systems and advisories on best harvest periods

Consequences: Inaccessibility to inputs(seeds, fertilisers, chemicals)
Ongoing adaptations: Informal seed acquisition pathways(neighbour and community seed systems), planting of certified seed, outsourcing inputs outside the community and county
Potential adaptations: Research on moisture tolerant seed varieties, availability of inputs through county and state mechanisms/programs, access to farm equipment used for drainage and erosion control activities

Consequences: Reduced farmer numbers access to farm inputs by suppliers(seeds, fertilizers), increased costs of agro chemicals
Ongoing adaptations: Planting seed supply by aid and government agencies, input supply by local agro dealers
Potential adaptations: Research and access to drought tolerant varieties, preservation of germplasm to maintain biodiversity, government subsidies to farm inputs, decentralization of input supply role by NCPB

Consequences: Transport cost increases as a result of poor roads, few numbers of traders involved in the maize grain businesses leading to market monopolies, loss of market/marketing opportunities
Ongoing adaptations: Road repairs and maintenance by community to facilitate produce access to markets, engagement in farmer associations for group marketing, supply to local institutions and markets
Potential adaptations: Develop new rural roads network, increase the number of players in the maize value chain, develop market policies for grain maize, establishment of grain reserves by NCPB

Consequences: Loss of income by producers, increased external grain sourcing by processors, increased price due to grain scarcity and diversion to household use
Ongoing adaptations: Collective grain marketing, accessing market information boards, existing market channels, NCPB channel market regulations, liberalized open air market for maize grains
Potential adaptations: Enhanced grain grading for market pricing, promotion of contract farming, open NCPB management to producer stakeholders, improved NCPB delivery systems at local levels

Consequences: Poor stand establishment, increased seedling mortality after planting, reduced growth rates, logging and loss of plant vigour, increased use of pesticides/herbicides
Ongoing adaptations: Soil conservation and erosion control(terracing/gabions/drainage structures), conservation agriculture, timely planting, agroforestry, use of organic manures, IPM, early warning systems, crops diversification
Potential adaptations: Promotion of land management and conservation measures, water harvesting techniques, enforcement of existing laws on soil, water and land conservation, IPM strategies, promotion of labour saving technologies, crop insurance

Consequences: Increased labour costs, poor stand establishment leading to replanting, increased weed infestation and new invasive weeds, weak plants with reduced vigour
Ongoing adaptations: Conservation agriculture, farm mechanization, use of IPM technologies, intercropping, adoption of new methods of weed control, small scale irrigation, application of organic manures, diversification to other commodities, timely planting
Potential adaptations: Irrrigation-increase land under irrigation, more reliable updates on meteorological information on weather forecasting, enhanced conservation agriculture, research on introductiom on more drought tolerant varieties, use of certified seed, awareness of weed control methods, need to embrace commercial village strategy, subsidy to mechanization

Consequences: Poor drying of grain, increased aflatoxin incidences, low quality and quantity of harvested produce, increased chances for grain spoilage during harvesting and storage, farm to storage transportation challenges of harvested produce
Ongoing adaptations: Dry grain to recommended moisture content for harvesting and storage, awareness creation of aflatoxins ,testing for aflatoxins, alternative use of transport e.g oxen, bodaboda, use of gunny bags
Potential adaptations: Research on aflatoxins, more sensitization on harvesting techniques, improve road infrastructure, revive and maintain government grain driers

Consequences: Poor quality and quantity of harvested produce, reduced perishability of stored grain(longer shelf life)
Ongoing adaptations: Testing of grain moisture content, sun drying by farmers, shade drying after crop harvest, adoption of hermetic storage bags
Potential adaptations: Restoration and repair of existing driers(government driers), enhancement and introduction of private driers, create awareness of quality standards regarding harvesting and household storage e.g use of the hermatic bags, promotion of aggregation centres at village level

Consequences: Slows down extension services, slows delivery of foods, rotting of feeds and poor diet, stress leading to miscarriage and kid mortality, reduced survival of desired breeds
Ongoing adaptations: Use of peer farmer trainers and training of trainers, feed conservation such as hay and silage, use of crop residues in feed formulation, cross-breeding
Potential adaptations: Use of media, feed formulation and artificial insemination

Consequences: Reduced working hours for extension officers and farmers, Reduced quality of feeds, reduced conception and success of breeding, low supply of goat meat, increased prices
Ongoing adaptations: Open and spacious  venues, Provision of shade, Providing goats with drinking water
Potential adaptations: Promote planting of shade trees, Construction of goats' shed, Proper ventilation in sheds to promote cross-breeding

Consequences: Poor network connections interfering with communication, hinders delivery, increased post harvest losses and power outages, limited gatherings, poor communication network , and limited access to markets
Ongoing adaptations: Use of modern communication technology (radio, Tv, mobile), construction of roads and collective marketing
Potential adaptations: Modern technology- improvement of current modern technology to reach all communities, collective marketing amongst farmers

Consequences: General body weakness which affects exhibitions and the goats may look sickly, reduced sales due to health condition and low market turnout
Ongoing adaptations: Use of telephones and site visits, providing goat sheds in exhibitions, use of tree shades
Potential adaptations: Use of improved technologies, online exhibitions, construction of market shades, refrigerated trucks for transporting and refrigerated storage areas

Consequences: It becomes difficult for goats to go out and browse freely, Accaricides will be wasted away, increase in pests and disease, increase in mortality and slow rate of accaricide supply, reduced frequency of deworming, reduced access to drugs, reduced growth rates
Ongoing adaptations: Use of concentrates, hay, silage and fodder trees, Construction of sheds, irregular deworming practices
Potential adaptations: Intensive rearing (zero grazing), adoption of spraying crush with a resting area, scheduled deworming procedures

Consequences: Loss of appetite, weight loss, increased diseases rate and increased expenditure on treatment, Body temperature fluctuations causing stress,sudden death
Ongoing adaptations: Provision of shade and water, Use of hand pump spray (Knapsack sprayer), Zero grazing
Potential adaptations: Planting of fodder trees and other trees to offer shade;,Well ventilated sheds, Spraying crush with well ventilated resting area, Construction of sheds with proper ventilation and scheduled deworming practices

Consequences: Limited access to goat meat, reduced rate of processing, reduced income for processors and power outages, Reduced frequency in quality checks by relative officers such as public health officers, poor road networks
Ongoing adaptations: Grading of roads, alternative power sources (generators), Provision of transport services e.g vehicles, Construction of roads
Potential adaptations: Increasing access to renewable energy and tarmacked roads, Creating slaughtering sites

Consequences: Low supply, reduced quality and quantity of produce, goats may die during transportation, reduced mobility of goats
Ongoing adaptations: Provision of sheds, transporting goats to slaughter houses using motorbikes
Potential adaptations: Well ventilated processing structures, create more slaughter space, use of ventilated trucks

Consequences: Packaging and transportation of chicks is affected by cost increases,  heat stress causes dehydration, quality and shelf life of drugs and vaccines reduced
Ongoing adaptations: Use of aerated boxes during transportation, Use of open trucks during transportation of feeds, Transporting the drugs in refrigerated trucks or cooler boxes
Potential adaptations: All value chain players should adopt airated boxes during transportation and use of open tracks by all transporters and proper packaging, Transporting drugs under refrigerated trucks and use of cooler boxes for short distances, establishment of regional vaccine storage centers

Consequences: Affects production of chicks and feeds thus increase in cost of production, Drought affects production of feeds because of lack of raw materials, cost of raw materials is high, high transportation and storage costs for drugs
Ongoing adaptations: Supply of chicks in curated boxes, proper packaging and use of open trucks for proper aeration, Use of cold containers and refrigerated trucks
Potential adaptations: Adoption of curated chick boxes during transportation, Use of open trucks by all transporters and proper packaging, Transporting drugs in refrigerated trucks or use of cooler boxes for short distances

Consequences: Limited market coverage and few consumers, prices will increase, limits on visitors travelling with chicks
Ongoing adaptations: Adoption of airated cages for display and adoption of value addition under refrigeration, contract agreement with buyers, structured marketing, marketing promotion and advertisement
Potential adaptations: Establishment of cold storage and aerated cages at the market centers, establishment of chicken slaughter slabs for value addition, collective structured marketing and pricing, contractual engagement with buyer, promotion and advertisement

Consequences: Drought affects the number of birds being transported and increases cost of feeds, consumers required to pay more, market penetration becomes difficult, fewer birds reach the market
Ongoing adaptations: Adoption of aerated cages for display and value addition under refrigeration, contractual engagement with buyers, structured marketing, marketing promotion and advertisement
Potential adaptations: Establishment of cold storage and aerated cages at market centers, establishment of chicken slaughter slabs for value addition, collective structured marketing and pricing, and contractual engagement with buyer, structured marketing, and promotion and advertisement

Consequences: Cost of regulating temperature is high, reduced hatchability, productivity, drought creates drafts thus increasing chick mortality rate, high disease and pests incidence
Ongoing adaptations: Use of automated incubators, use of saw dust to regulate temperature in the hatching boxes, having more aerated structures in brooding areas, use of automated brooders, proper combination and use of pesticides to control pests, regular change of litters
Potential adaptations: Use of automated incubators, more aerated structures in the brooding areas, proper sanitation and routine vaccination

Consequences: Eggs will be denatured hence low hatchability, high cost of heat regulating gadgets, reduced feeding and growth, dehydration increasing mortality rate, increased incidence of disease outbreaks
Ongoing adaptations: Use of automated incubators, use of saw dust to regulate temperature and use of open hatching boxes, use of automated brooders, having more aerated structures and water feeders, proper sanitation and use of pesticides to control pests, regular change of live litter and ring vaccination
Potential adaptations: Use of automated incubators, more aerated structures in the brooding area, proper sanitation and routine vaccination

Consequences: High cost of transportation since modification of transport cages is required and packing fewer birds, centers call for increased investments, high heat reduces nitrogen in compost due to hurried decomposition
Ongoing adaptations: Use of aerated cages and fabricated trucks, use of airated structures in market centers, construction of shaded structures to protect manure from heat
Potential adaptations: Adopt aerated cages and fabricated trucks for transportation, Establish aerated aggregation centers and cold storage facilities, Construction of chicken manure yard and application of manure management techniques

Consequences: Increased cost of transportation due to reduced number of chicks packed, reduced aggregation activity at any given time, waste and underutilization
Ongoing adaptations: Use of aerated cages and fabricated trucks, Use of aerated structures in market centers, Construction of shaded structures to protect the manure from heat
Potential adaptations: Adopting aerated cages and fabricated trucks for transportation, Establish aerated aggregation centers, and cold storage facilities, Construction of chicken manure yard and application of manure management techniques

Consequences: Leads to low loan repayment due to low yields
Ongoing adaptations: Use of early maturing seed varities, Use of more drought resistant seed varieties, Resorting to SILC as alternative to formal financial institutions
Potential adaptations: Diversifying and upscaling to early maturing seed varieties, Diversifying to use drought resistant seed varieties, Upscaling to more financial institutions

Consequences: Lending institutions are concerned of loan recovery during drought hence they reduce lending, reduced need for land acquistion, reduced seed acquisition
Ongoing adaptations: Use of early maturing seed varieities, Resorting to use of more drought resistant varieties, Resorting to SILC as formal finacial instutions alternatives
Potential adaptations: Diversifying and up scaling to early maturing seed varieities, Diversification into adaptable varieties, linking value chain actors with formal financial institutions

Consequences: Low volumes available for aggregation due to low yields, limited quantity to transport to market, low sales as a result of low yields
Ongoing adaptations: Use of cost effective transport systems e.g motorbikes
Potential adaptations: Adoption of technologies e.g MIS (radio and related media)

Consequences: Aggregation- low volumes available, Transportation- there will be low quantity to be transported to markets, limited quantity for sale
Ongoing adaptations: Adoption of low cost transportation systems e.g use of wheel barrows and motorbikes, Farm-gate sales
Potential adaptations: Adoption of low cost transportation systems e.g use of wheel barrows and motorbikes, Formation of marketing groups and MIS to caution them against extra costs

Consequences: Minimizes routine management activities e.g weeding since soil disturbance is not recommended, low harvesting as a result of low yields caused by moisture stress
Ongoing adaptations: Mulching, Sprinkling water on the vegetable leaves to prevent dessication
Potential adaptations: Cover cropping/ Mixed cropping, Scaling up to sprinkling of water on vegetable leaves before harvesting to prevent drying up

Consequences: Land preparation- very low because the soil surface is hard to work on, Crop management- very low since routine operations e.g weeding may expose crops to stress and soil disturbance
Ongoing adaptations: Small scale irrigation, Minimum tillage, Timely harvesting
Potential adaptations: Establishment of dams to collect and store water during rainy season, Crop rotation and use of herbicides to control weeds, Relying on weather information updates

Consequences: Sorting and grading- affects the yield hence low production and quality, Drying and preservation of seeds- low yield and quality of seeds hence need for preservation, minimal levels of value additions from low production
Ongoing adaptations: Sprinkling water on vegetable leaves, Establishment of aggregation/collection points
Potential adaptations: NA

Consequences: Sorting and grading- quality and quantity are both compromised, Drying and presevation of seeds- initial compromise on the quantity during harvesting leaves the farmer with almost nothing to dry, due to low production the produce is used for subsistence purposes
Ongoing adaptations: Incorporation of wood ash as preservation techniques and sundrying, Integrated pest management to preserve vegetable seeds
Potential adaptations: Adopting climate smart innovations e.g solar drier, Adoption of innovative post-harvest technologies

Consequences: Inadequate land suitable for sweet potato production due to floods, Floods negatively affect vine multiplication on farms, capital is shifted from production to food purchase
Ongoing adaptations: Drainage channels to mitigate floods, Use of raised nursery beds
Potential adaptations: Establish cut-off drains to direct excess water away from farms, Promotion of hydroponics for rapid vine multiplication, use of raised beds to produce vines

Consequences: During drought land is available, Unavailability of planting materials during drought and increase in price of planting materials when available, household income is channeled to food procurement at the expense of production
Ongoing adaptations: Acquiring land near water sources e.g river banks, water pans, Bucket irrigation for vine nurseries which are situated near river banks, Transfer of money from income generating activities currently being undertaken by farmer groups to sweet potatoes production
Potential adaptations: Establishment of more water pans to encourage rain water harvesting for irrigation, establishment of large scale irrigation methods for vine multiplication, use shade nets, providing means of accessing credit from financial institutions

Consequences: Flooding will cause inadequate supply of sweet potatoes in the market hence high prices, low supply caused by rotting and sweeping away of tubers
Ongoing adaptations: Selling at local markets or home consumption
Potential adaptations: Eliminating market dominance by middlemen over-drawing profits from the value chain compared to farmers, introduce pricing regulation system that benefits producers

Consequences: Drought affects sweet potatoes pricing due to low supply hence prices will increase
Ongoing adaptations: Individual farmer negotiation with buyers, farmers sell to their regular customers on credit, farmers use middlemen to deliver their produce to markets
Potential adaptations: Use of media to create awareness of sweet potatoes production, use of fliers and posters to create awareness, collective marketing, formation of sweet potatoes cooperative societies

Consequences: Land preparation cannot go on since the land is flooded, planting sweet potatoes cannot continue due flooding, no harvesting, rotting of sweet potato root tubers
Ongoing adaptations: In areas that are not heavily flooded, farmers use drainage channels while in heavily flooded areas farmers wait until floods reduce, Farmers plant in areas where they have established drainage channels in areas with relatively low floods, while in heavily flooded areas they wait until floods have passed
Potential adaptations: Waiting till floods subside, establishment of protection dikes along river banks

Consequences: Land is difficult to plough during drought as achieving required tilth and depth becomes difficult, sweet potatoes are not planted during drought, little to no harvest
Ongoing adaptations: Increased number of oxens used in ploughing during drought, Planting is only possible around riverbanks and water pans, Use of ox-ploughs to expose roots and hiring labour to help in harvesting
Potential adaptations: Mechanized farming, Use of climate smart agricultural farming methods/technologies, Mechanized harvesting

Consequences: Floods will affect collection of sweet potatoes as most roads become impassable, Floods cause poor infrastructure affecting sweet potatoes transportation
Ongoing adaptations: No transport because of impassable roads hence no adaptation, no ongoing adaptation option since there is no grading activity
Potential adaptations: Mobilise farmers to upscale to processing sweet potatoes into various products e.g. puree, chips and flour

Consequences: Drought has minor effect on sweet pototoes collection as there maybe just moisture loss in tubers, drought has minor effect on transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Pre-organized collection by the buyers immediately after harvesting, covering roots with soil and watering them, hiring water vendors to provide water for washing the sweet potatoes, grading done according to size
Potential adaptations: Establishment of collection centers and construction of sheds within those centers, the farmers association should acquire their own vehicles for transportation; farmers should lobby for improvement of road network, use of both piped and harvested rain water at collection points

Consequences: Reduced arable land for avocado orchard establishment due to flooding, high cost of transportation of plant materials because of impassable roads and harvest networks leading to low quality of seedlings, high cost of organic and inorganic fertilizer transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of good drainage system by individual farmers, purchase of seedlings and planting materials from nearby nurseries, on farm composing of farm yard manure
Potential adaptations: Construction of good joint community drainage systems, upgrade rural roads to all weather roads, early procurement of fertilizers and manure when dry

Consequences: High cost of land acquisation- farmers are competing for land in suitable areas and hence the price of land goes up, poor quality planting materials- nurseries are realising stunted non-vigourous seedlings that do not survive when transplanted on farms and even slow growth/establishment, low demand for organic and inorganic fertilizers when soils are dry
Ongoing adaptations: Use of high density planting and irrigating, community based tree nurseries, continous manning and standards enforcement to nursery operators, diversification by agro-dealers
Potential adaptations: Upscale of irrigation schemes targeting avocados in lower lying areas, upscale of community based tree nurseries, continous training of agro-dealers

Consequences: Low attendance or linkage forum during heavy rains farmers and other stakeholders are not able to attend meetings, Unpredicatable fruit prices- caused by few price negotiations and contracts as a result of poor negotiation forums, irregular supplies and sales, farmers are unable to harvest and deliver fruits
Ongoing adaptations: Use of electronic and print media, early planning and implementation of contracts forums, timely supply of produce through guidelines of weather forecast, buyers source produce form different regions
Potential adaptations: Conducting virtual meetings, drawing contracts with clauses protecting the players against climatic harzards, using group marketing and storage facilities

Consequences: Less interaction between buyers and farmers due to low yields hence discouraging farmers from seeking market linkages, low market prices, reduced supply to pack houses
Ongoing adaptations: Use of electronic and print media, conservation agriculture to produce better quality fruits, group marketing, reduced supply pack houses- diversification of pack house services, outgrower programme e.g Kakuzi
Potential adaptations: Upscale the use of electronic and print media, introduction of specific marketing programmes and agents to use group meetings for passing information (e.g church), upscale of conservation agriculture to produce higher quality fruits and devolop irrigation schemes resulting to better prices, upscale outgrowers extension programme to enhance conservation agriculture, construct bulking centers

Consequences: Low access to extension services due to poor road infrastructure and transport network, High levels of leaching- leads to low or poor growth because excess rain leach nutrients to levels which roots cannot uptake, the farmer will spend more on inputs
Ongoing adaptations: Use of electronic print media, engaging in conservation agriculture, split application of fertilizers, intergrated pest and disease management
Potential adaptations: Encourage and enhance use of electronic and print media, upscaling of split application of fertilizers and planting of cover crops, upscaling of integrated pest and disease management

Consequences: Low demand of extension services- because farmers demand services when land is moist and there are many ongoing activities in the farms, slow plant growth due to low uptake of nutrients, proliferation of pest and disease attacks
Ongoing adaptations: Use of electronic and print media, Engaging in conservation agriculture for example use of insect traps, mulching e.t.c
Potential adaptations: Up scale use of electronic and print media e.g Kangema FM, enhance the use of conservation agriculture

Consequences: Disruption of harvesting program- farmers are not able to strictly follow harvesting programs and also harvested fruit develops lenticel damage leading to high post-harvest losses, high cost of sorting and grading due to high incidences of lenticel damage and spotting by fungal diseases, high cost of transportation and high pos harvest losses due to impassable roads and delayed collection
Ongoing adaptations: Timely harvesting as guided by the weather forecast to minimize damaged fruits, upgrading of rural access roads
Potential adaptations: Install storage facilities where fruits can be bulked when the weather is favourable, timely delivery of weather forecast, upscale of the upgrading of the vehicle transporting and rural access roads

Consequences: Reduced yields due to low moisture availability that lead to few and small low quality fruits, high rate of fruit fall during growing season, higher cost of sorting and grading, less demand for transport
Ongoing adaptations: Conservation agriculture (Water harvesting, manure application, mulching e.t.c which leads to better quality produce, Diversification of transport network/business i.e carrying other produce from garden
Potential adaptations: Up-scaling of conservation agriculture and establishment of irrigation schemes, Upscale of transport diversification

Consequences: Destruction of hardening structures, evapotranspiration of plant lets moisture loss in plants
Ongoing adaptations: Use of wind breaks and use of metallic or strong wooden posts, improved/ specialized trucks for transportation (cold trucks)
Potential adaptations: Reinforcing mini structure at farm levels, upscale the cold truck transport, use of tsunami detectors

Consequences: Delayed sourcing of input, low income of stockist, high cost of seedling maintenance of the nursery, risk of loosing the seedlings due to lack of water, and overgrown seedlings
Ongoing adaptations: Promote water harvesting for crop establishment and propagation, shade nets for nurseries and mist irrigation, collective acquisation/procurement and delivery of goods
Potential adaptations: Automated propagation, moisture detection, soiless media, refrigerated or cold trucks to transport seedling or plantlets, rural roads improvements to all weather roads

Consequences: Poor quality banana due dust leading to low linkage and low income, Low prices due to immature harvested bananas, poor prices due to low quality bananas contaminated with dust
Ongoing adaptations: Using marketing sheds, cleaning of bananas before marketing, promote good husbandry practices, short varieties, wind breaks at farmer levels and packaging of bananas
Potential adaptations: Using online marketing, engaging in automated weighing and pricing of bananas, using marketing crates, aggregation sheds, and digitalized marketing

Consequences: Low market linkage due to low volume, low income of traders, farmers, middlemen and processors, low quality of bananas but high price due to shortage
Ongoing adaptations: Promote good agricultural practices to boost production, promote online marketing and certified farming e.g organic farm, Promote technologies that can boost production and quality, value addition and processing
Potential adaptations: Digitalized marketing, packaging of bananas in crates, waxing of bananas, digitalized pricing and marketing

Consequences: Lodging of banana stems, falling of banana bunches from the stem, increased evapotranspiration, destruction of plantation by falling of agroforestry trees, and spread of pests and diseases, damages during harvesting, wind erosion and poor health due to a dusty environment
Ongoing adaptations: Wind breaks, propping of bananas and planting short varieties, minimum tillage and mulching
Potential adaptations: Establishment of support system for bananas to prevent lodging, establishment of harvesting vails (conveyers), engaging in conservation agriculture

Consequences: Delayed planting, poor crop performance, excessive water use (irrigation), poor quality of produce and  low volumes, management cost increase, pest and disease incidences and water stress, scotching of harvested bananas, low harvested volumes, poor quality of harvested bananas
Ongoing adaptations: Water harvesting for banana production, irrigation, conservation agriculture, harvesting sheds, bagging of bunches, minimum tillage, cultivating early in the morning and late in the afternoon
Potential adaptations: Drip irrigation for banana production, bagging of bunches and harvesting sponges for harvestors, engaging in conservation agriculture

Consequences: Low quality and volumes of bananas delivered, low income, dusty processing enviroment leading to contamination, high loses due to contamination, low weight, immature aggregated bananas, destruction of aggregation sheds by winds
Ongoing adaptations: Promote propping of bananas and short varieties, promotion of aggregation sheds
Potential adaptations: Promotion of specialized aggregation sheds that regulate temperatures in the sheds, specialized packaging e.g plastic packaging to prevent contaminations through dust, using automated weighing

Consequences: Scorching of aggregated bananas and loss of value of harvested bananas, Low processed volumes, poor quality of ripening bananas, and faster drying of banana chips
Ongoing adaptations: Establishing aggregation centers, promote conservation agriculture technologies to boost volumes and improve quality, encourage collective aggregation and processing
Potential adaptations: Promotion of specialized aggregation sheds that regulate temperatures inside centers, solar powered drying of bananas, mechanized weighing of bananas(automated)

Consequences: Soil erosion cause low soil fertility hence low fodder production, poor health of dairy cow because of increased disease outbreaks and parasites, poor quality fodder due to excessive soil leaching
Ongoing adaptations: Terracing and using fodder strips,  administering vaccinations and routine management, manuring and use of fertilizers
Potential adaptations: Water harvesting through water dams, enhance disease survillance and dissemination of advisories, introduce high protein fodders and intercrop fodders with legumes (fodder maize/legume)

Consequences: The soil moisture becomes low lowering the fodder production, cows become weak due to lack of enough fodder and water
Ongoing adaptations: Water harvesting, using technologies like (Tumbukiza), Leasing land for fodder production and silage making, Use of farm by products (Maize stores, bean straw)
Potential adaptations: Enhancing water harvesting technologies, Government/donor funded irrigation schemes, Enhance adoption silage making and capacity building for farmers on fodder conservation, Introduce drought resistant fodder varieties

Consequences: Low farm gate milk prices, increased cost of promotion, low sales
Ongoing adaptations: Negotiated prices, use of less expensive promotion modes like county events, contracted distributors and sourcing other outlets
Potential adaptations: Enactment of price regulation polices, Organize promotion events (e.g roadshows), Diversification of milk products e.g milk powder

Consequences: Increased milk prices, Reduced number of promotion activity
Ongoing adaptations: Negotiating prices with processors, use of inexpensive promotion channels e.g county government events, contracted distributors and subsidized prices to county staff
Potential adaptations: Farmers to add value to raw milk, use of social media to promote products, dairy cooperative to start milk dispensing centers/ ATMS

Consequences: Poor feeding due to reduced fodder production, Outbreaks of disease and emergence of parasites, reduced delivery of AI due to bad roads
Ongoing adaptations: Use of supplements, outsourcing high quality fodder, and treatment, vaccination, spraying and deworming, using AI and use of motorcycles
Potential adaptations: Upscale silage making and enhance drainage in low areas, enhance vaccination, disease surveillance and vector control, improve access roads (grading, murraming and tarmacking)

Consequences: Reduced fodder leading to emmaciated animals and low milk production, cows develop downer cow disease- this is due to poor feeding, long calving intervals
Ongoing adaptations: Use of farm by products (maize stores, bean straw), use of suppliments, out sourcing of fodder(hay)
Potential adaptations: Enhance conservation of fodders in the form of silage and hay, enhance dairy cooperative capacity to stock inputs,fFarmers should stock own feeds, enhance use of motor cycles to transport milk due to ease of access

Consequences: Delayed or cancelled delivery of milk, Low amount of milk aggregated, Delay in milk transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Change of collection centers to more accessible points, increase number of collection centers and routes, use of alternative transport mainly motorcycles instead of vehicles
Potential adaptations: Upgrading access roads by county government, Enhance use of motorcycles that can access poor roads

Consequences: Low amount of collected milk, Low amount of milk aggregated, Reduced income due to low volumes
Ongoing adaptations: Use of conserved fodder (silage and hay), Dairy cooperative providing farmers with feeds and suppliments, Change of mode of transport -use of motorbikes instead of vehicles
Potential adaptations: Growing of protein rich fodder trees or shrubs, establish highly nutritious grass fodder e.g Rhodes grass, Establishment of alternative fodder e.g Brachiaria, Dairy cooperative to start inputs shops for hay and suppliments

Consequences: Capital- increases cost of production e.g buying multivitamin for chicks, Extension advice- the extension officers are not enough to reach all farmers therefore when there is an outbreak, extension advice will be costly
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are constructing improvised chicken structures like makuti, bamboo,and sisal structures because they are cheap and provide aeration for the birds, Farmers are opting to go for workshops, shows, farmer field school for capacity building, Farmers are using locally available materials, for example left overs rather than purchasing expensive feeds
Potential adaptations: Capacity building to connect farmers to financial institutions and financial management, Enligtening farmers of the available service providers especially government ones

Consequences: Lack of capital for start up or expansion, farmers unable to access or afford extension services, unaivalable raw materials like rice husks, sunflower and maize
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers borrow from chama's, table banking, recognized microfinance, using Uwezo fund, youth enterprise funds, grants such as Nariga, Farmers get information from Tv and Radio programmes, and farmers' field schools, Farmers use free range farming systems
Potential adaptations: Organizing farmers into groups enlightening them on importance of saving, use of financial institutions, farmers are encouraged to watch TV programs on poultry farming, drying available raw materials to preserve them for future use, use of larvae(insects) as subsitute for feeds

Consequences: Selling- Reduced weight of live birds, prices reduce due to low weights
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are using available technology to link and/or market their products e.g using WhatsApp, Farmers are using a standardized scale of measuring weight of birds e.g using a weight machine
Potential adaptations: Farmers should sell as a group to increase bargaining power and fetch better prices, Farmers should be encouraged to form poultry cooperatives, Farmers should adapt to chicken pricing according to weight

Consequences: Low sales due to loss of weight, and size of eggs- the eggs became small and have weak shells, Low linkage of farmers to buyers due to low production
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers opt to dispose a percentage of their birds before onset of dry spell, Use of modern technology to link farmers to market, Farmers use weight of bird to determine price
Potential adaptations: Formation of farmers groups i.e chicken groups to increase bargaining power, Formation of market channels e.g cooperatives societies, to improve rural farmers products marketing channels, Formulation of policies to standardize poultry products trade, formulation of barriers e.g eggs from foreign countries, and increament of cess tax to encourage local production

Consequences: Feeding- Chicken do not feed properly hence low productivity of eggs, meat and manure, Vaccination- it does not affect vaccination
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are adding value to locally available raw materials to increase nutrient value e.g omena, maize by-product, sunflower, Farmers are feeding birds local greens/fodders e.g lucern to harden egg shells, Farmers are administering vaccines and dewormers purchased from agrovets themselves
Potential adaptations: Farmers to mix feeds as groups not solely, adopting feeding systems that preserve both feed and water, organizing farmers in a way where vaccination is at once for all members to be done in groups to avoid loss of drugs, deworming to be done once for all groups members

Consequences: Poor quality feeds due to lack of good raw materials, Inadequate potable water to dilute vaccines, for chicken e.g in Wempa, Ithanga, Kambiti and Maranjau
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers use free range farming systems, use of household leftovers, Farmers harvest rain water and store in water tanks to provide water for diluting vaccines and dewormers
Potential adaptations: Using larvae from manure as feed suppliment, use of appropriate feeders and drinkers to maximize utilization of available feeds, free government services to offer poultry vaccination, members benefiting from vaccination should be organized in groups, utilize village based trained facilitation to sensitize on deworming and conduct practicums

Consequences: Collection- The number of eggs collected will reduce, shelf life of meat is reduced
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers use simple transportation methods like motorbikes and motorcycles, Farmers opt to sell live chicken rather than slaughtering
Potential adaptations: Farmers to organize transportation as a group to minimize cost, Farmers to adopt better ways of collecting eggs e.g use of trays instead of hands, Farmers have adapted to selling live birds which they should maintain

Consequences: Transport- minimal transportation of chicken products from the farm, Reduced collection and slaughtering
Ongoing adaptations: Use of cheap and efficient methods of transportation e.g motorbikes, Farmers opt to sell live birds rather than slaughtering
Potential adaptations: Rehabilitation of rural connector roads to improve movement of goods e.g reduce egg breakage during transportation, Establishment of village based collection days for poultry products e.g every Friday, collection point is Githiga poultry center, Establishment of poultry slaughtering centers for value addition by selling Kgs or packaged forms

Consequences: Poor flock conditions(drooping, loss of feathers), high mortality rates, high demand for veterinary services
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local herbs for pest and disease management, construction of chicken brooders(with electrical or charcoal heating sources), use of traditional drugs and extension services, culling and disposal for diseased flock
Potential adaptations: Use of drugs for chicken pest and disease management, enforcement of quarantine measures during disease outbreaks, collection of poultry manure

Consequences: Damage of rural access roads making it impassable, delayed input delivery, rearing poultry in household space
Ongoing adaptations: Buying certified seeds from local stockists, buying fertiliser from appointed agents, using of available agronomic equipment
Potential adaptations: Continous research and access to drought resistant seed varieties, soil testing and analysis, crop specific fertility, appropriate farm machines, subsidies for access to agro inputs

Consequences: High spoilage of meat, lack of water, high cost of labor, easy to bulk since the roads are passable, high transport costs(demand for refrigerated vans)
Ongoing adaptations: Slaughtered in houses and packed in polythene bags, farm to farm bulking, use of boda boda, use of cartons and crates, household consumption of eggs/meat
Potential adaptations: Use of modern slaughter equipments, use of cooler vans and boxes, programmed egg collection and sorting, use of improved packaging material, certification of poultry products(to assess quality/enhance market sale)

Consequences: Low farm gate prices, high market prices due to scarcity of eggs/meat, loss of marketing activities
Ongoing adaptations: Use of cartons/crates for transport to local markets(bikes), farm gate and local sales
Potential adaptations: Formation of cooperatives to facilitate poultry sales, introduction of chicken feather markets

Consequences: Increased perishability of meat/eggs
Ongoing adaptations: Slaughtered in houses and packed by use of polythene bags, household consumption of eggs/meat
Potential adaptations: Use of modern machines for slaughtering, use of cooler vans and boxes, use of cooler vans, programmed egg collection and sorting, certification of poultry products(to assess quality/enhance market sale)

Consequences: Increased production costs for irrigation, labour and use of pesticides, reduced plant vigour and stunted growth, increased livestock/wildlife/crop farmer conflict over forage
Ongoing adaptations: Timely planting, conservation agriculture, irrigation and manure application
Potential adaptations: Early warning information to guide decisions in planting, irrigation and harvesting, provide extension services to support new technologies

Consequences: Increased prevalence of pest and disease outbreaks, higher labour costs, animal poor growth rate and malnutrition, low yields, low quantity and poor quality of animal manure
Ongoing adaptations: Early pasture establishments, use of veterinary drugs following vet advice, culling/selling of weak animals, use of indigenous parasite/disease control measures, enterprise diversification(crop growing and formal employment)
Potential adaptations: Pasture establishment using mechanized means(tractors), introduction of drought management policies(county level), county support for enterprise diversification for dairy farmers, community/government support in water conservation/provision

Consequences: Increased pest and diseases incidence, reduced soil moisture, increased wildlife-farmer conflicts
Ongoing adaptations: Early maturing and drought tolerant crops(e.g. cowpeas, watermelon), use certified seeds
Potential adaptations: Developing and access to drought tolerant seeds

Consequences: Low processing because of very low harvest, high infestation of storage pest
Ongoing adaptations: Process the harvest-manual harvesting, dusting with actellic, use of people and donkeys
Potential adaptations: Acquire appropriate processing equipments e.g sheller, drying equipment and packaging, use of appropriate storage technologies e.g hermatic bags, metallic silos and improve stores, use of appropriate transportation method, bulk transportation

Consequences: High labour costs, increased pests and disease incidence, increased flock mortality, lack of water
Ongoing adaptations: Free ranging chicken, use of local herbs for pest and disease control
Potential adaptations: Use of extension services advisories and improved drugs for pest and disease management, enforcement of quarantine measures during disease outbreaks, collection of poultry manure

Consequences: Reduced working hours due to high temperatures causing the scorching effect of potato leading to the greening effect, high deterioration of potato,high incidences of moths infestation which spread viral diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Covering with earth/leaves/twigs, biological control by use of mexican marigold to control moths, IPM, make shift shades, household consumption of product to avoid loss
Potential adaptations: Construction of cold rooms/proper storage, use of mechanized harvesting technologies, improve on value addition technologies.

Consequences: High construction costs of poultry sheds(scarcity of local building resources)
Ongoing adaptations: Keeping poultry in household space, sourcing of chicks at local hatcheries, use of local resources to encourage chicken breeding("kiterenge"), individual farm breeding
Potential adaptations: Construction of modern poultry sheds, access to certified and drought tolerant and chicken varieties, access to approved chicken feeds and drugs, chicken feed subsidies

Consequences: Difficult to promote the produce during drought because of the small quantity and poor quality, low supply of produce which leads to higher prices
Ongoing adaptations: Promoting- word of mouth, media(radio), pricing-word of mouth
Potential adaptations: Mass media-electronic and print, contract farming, informing farmers in available markets

Consequences: Delay in land preparation, washing away of the soil and seed/applied fertilizers and chemicals, challenges in weed management, high labor costs
Ongoing adaptations: Using manual ploughing, manual labor in land preparation and harvesting, replanting, reseeding, staggered planting, establish drainage structures(canals, dykes)
Potential adaptations: Conservation agriculture, appropriate equipment e.g jab planter, appropriate technology and weeding e.g use of herbicide, enterprise diversification, advisories from extension agents on disease/pest control and best planting times

Consequences: Disease and pests outbreaks, poor pasture germination/establishment, hygiene challenges, low animal growth rate, parasitic infestations
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of dams, reliance on vet advisory services on disease management, silage and hay preparation from crop residues/pastures, use of indigenous drugs(herbs/concoctions)
Potential adaptations: Drain using water pans, drain the excess water to the road runways, selling of their animals

Consequences: Linking farmers to buyers-low prices are offered, reduced milk production, pricing-hiked prices due to milk scarcity
Ongoing adaptations: Farmer bargains for establishing market pricing, association with organized marketing(cooperatives), sale to milk buying agents/vendors
Potential adaptations: Government intervention in pricing of dairy products, strengthening of cooperatives to source for external markets, dairy insurance products

Consequences: It becomes less difficult to processing(shelling, sorting, grading, drying and packaging, high humidity which will lead to rotting, moulding and aflatoxin, transport challenges from farm to stores
Ongoing adaptations: Manual labor to thresh, shell, sieve, weighing and packaging in sacks, seed storage in house, cribs and stores, use of human, donkey, canter and lorries for transport
Potential adaptations: Appropriate technology for shelling, drying, sorting and packaging(sheller drivers etc, automatic weighing machines), appropriate storage facilities e.g hermatic bags, metallic silos, appropriate transport facilities i.e bulk transports, improved infrastructure e.g good roads, reliance on crop based insurance to cushion against production and post harvest production losses, frequent advisories from early warning systems

Consequences: Prices are dictated by market, so there are low prices, difficult linkage due to market flood
Ongoing adaptations: No harmonized prices, individual farmer marketing, use of cartons/crates for local transport to markets
Potential adaptations: Formation of cooperatives to facilitate poultry sales, introduction of chicken feather markets

Consequences: Storing-no milk to store, the little available milk goes bad, transportation-smooth running of transportation, contamination of milk due to dust
Ongoing adaptations: Value addition-powered milk and packaging, reconstitute for local use, export milk to areas with storage facilities
Potential adaptations: Access to small scale cooling facilities, community milk reserves, mechanized milking

Consequences: Difficult to promote, the farm produce-maize prices are low due to poor quality of maize produce
Ongoing adaptations: Marketing pricing using brokers/middlemen, market information passed verbally between farmers, processors and middlemen, association with community groups for bulk selling
Potential adaptations: Formation of cooperatives/groups to facilitate profitable market sales, new markets to sell product

Consequences: Inadequate clean seeds materials because of soil borne diseases, insects/pests, break up of seeds varieties, hindered access of inputs due to poor and damaged infrastructure in roads, increased cost of maintenance of roads, increases cost of pesticides application and labour costs, it increases environmental degradation
Ongoing adaptations: Fertiliser- GOK subsidies program, positive selection of clean potato seed, IPM, GAP, conservation agriculture, safe use of chemicals
Potential adaptations: Setting up a fertiliser plant, improved access to early maturing tuber varieties and to credit to buy farm inputs

Consequences: Storing-not enough, reduced milk for storage, transportation -difficulties in transporting the milk due to muddy roads
Ongoing adaptations: Transport of dairy products using animal means, value addition e.g. fermented milk, storage in locally available cans/holding containers, immediate sale to prevent household storage
Potential adaptations: Improved transport networks, access to refrigerated storage structures, establish community based milk reserve structures, acquire modern milking equipment

Consequences: Poor tuber formation, reduced germination and growth rates, scorching, increased pest/disease incidence, intense pesticide use, poor soil conditions(loss of soil cover)
Ongoing adaptations: Early/staggered planting, use of IPM techniques(pest and disease control), safe pesticide use, conservation agriculture(mulching/zero tillage), tree planting(wind breaks), crop rotation, intercropping with maize, small scale irrigated organic farming, use of plastic mulches
Potential adaptations: Conservation agriculture, irrigation, early warning system, green houses, hydroponics promotion, GAP, IPM, organic farming, use of chisel for minimum soil disturbance, use of plastic mulching and technology, access to crop insurance schemes

Consequences: Increased labor cost, poor quality of product and high crop losses, reduced shelf life
Ongoing adaptations: Use of IPM strategies to control pest and diseases during tuber storage, makeshift shades, manual grading, locally available storage materials(gunny bags), use of human labour in harvesting, indigenous knowledge for tuber preservation, value addition(in grading and packaging)
Potential adaptations: Establishment of sheds/storage, establish group machines for mechanized harvesting, early warning systems, more improved varieties that can stay longer in the ground, use of open nets and bags for packaging, research on better variety with longer shelf life, adopt better packaging materials

Consequences: Increased cost of labor and delayed land preparation, increase labor costs on weeding, high costs of pesticides for those who buy chemicals, high loss of soil due to erosion, poor yields
Ongoing adaptations: Early warning system, IPM, GAP, conservation agriculture, early planting, integrated land and water management(canals/drains), advisory services
Potential adaptations: Land pooling by smallholders(increase acreage and economies of scale), improved access to crop insurance schemes and early warning systems
