Consequences: Linking farmers to buyers-difficult in linkages due to poor infrastructure, pricing-high prices due to reduced milk and low market activity
Ongoing adaptations: Use of donkeys, government intervention on the road infrastructure, avail marketing information
Potential adaptations: Access to external market information, improved road infrastructure, formation of farmer cooperatives(ease marketing)

Consequences: Breeding-difficulties in breeding, multilple abortions, insemination repeats, feed provision-shortage and compromised quality
Ongoing adaptations: Use of supplements, feed/fodder conservation of maize stovers, silage making and hay, change of breeds, sourcing vet drugs and other vet guidance
Potential adaptations: Use of improved disease control drugs, provision of feed relief, access to disease resistant animal breeds

Consequences: Feed shortage and poor feed quality, high feed prices, high prices of building material
Ongoing adaptations: Poultry feed supplements with kitchen waste, farmer to farmer exchange of breeding stock, poultry drugs(use of indigenous and/or modern drugs)
Potential adaptations: Use of crop based chicken supplements, construction of improved chicken houses using locally available resources

Consequences: Shortage of commodities in the market(low supply)
Ongoing adaptations: Individual marketing, trainings in agribusiness and records keeping, use of human labor, tractors, donkeys and tractors for transport to market
Potential adaptations: Contract farming, crop insurance, organised market, value addition in cottage industry, e-marketing, opening of agriculture roads

Consequences: Low volumes of supplied tubers, deteriorated tuber quality, high prices due to scarcity and high demand, loss of marketing opportunities
Ongoing adaptations: Farm gate sales, local marketing, disposal of damaged produce for livestock consumption

Consequences: Breeding- difficult to breed, cows don't come on heat, animals get emaciated, feed shortages and compromised quality

Consequences: Low packaging activities, Low branding activities, Little transportation activity
Ongoing adaptations: Labourers adopt new income generating activities e.g kazi mtaani, boda boda riding, bee keeping and pig farming, adaptation of new technology skills e.g use of electronics, machinery
Potential adaptations: Improve storage/increase capacity to stock huge quantities of maize during bumper harvest and packaging, Enhancing diversification of goods to be transported e.g transporting cattle and sheep with barley

Consequences: Difficulty in land preparation due to formation of hard pans, low land preparation activities, reduced planting activities, minimal crop husbandry activities like weeding

Potential adaptations: Ensuring that farmers have easy access to dewormers, intensifying disease surveillance and control, providing vaccines to farmers, controlling the movement of livestock from one region to another, enforcing land-use policy, using adaptable feeding methods, providing pastures to farmers, providing water to livestock, destocking, which discourages migration, using advisories

Consequences: High costs involved, low land preparation and planting activities, reduce crop husbandry activities e.g. weeding

Potential adaptations: Upscaling use of weather and meteorological information on early land preparation, embracing climate-smart agricultural practices like selective herbicides and pre-emerging herbicides

Consequences: Difficulty/ very low drying activities e.g sun drying, Difficulty in storage, low value addition activities like milling
Ongoing adaptations: Harvesting and drying in bits, drying in special stores/grannery, transporting products to dry areas for drying, Owners emerging and improving own stores, taking products to NCPB storage for a fee, Use of small posho mills for value addition, availability of millers e.g Narok town, Olerai Osirua
Potential adaptations: Use of cereal driers- diesel, electricity or solar powered, Enhance warehouse receipting systems, develop zonal storage facilities of modern status and sufficient capacity, operationalize ene ng'etia national cerials and storage board stores, promote individual storage faciltities, develop regional value addition centers

Consequences: Low drying activities, Low storage activities due to low production

Potential adaptations: Farmers should diversify their farm practices e.g dairy farming, chicken, sorghum, millet, sweet potatoes

Consequences: High capital required for maintenance, emmaciated animals, and loss of livestock, poor pasture and browsing condition, diminished animal feeds, increased migration, human and wildlife conflict, expensive vet services, extension services, and AI costs, limited vaccines
Ongoing adaptations: Adoption of red masaai sheep, use of available grazing land, opening of parks for grazing and use of early warning advisories, migrating from lowlands to highlands, using maize and wheat residues, and hay strolls, increasing livestock offtake rates, monitoring diseases
Potential adaptations: Develop sheding for small scale farmers, introduction of drought tolerant breeds, enhance capacity building for farmers on drought mitigation, Introduction of drought tolerant feeds, subsidize animal feeds, provision of animal feeds, encourage destocking, provision of water, intesify disease surveillance, sensitization

Ongoing adaptations: Use of private deworming services, use indigenous methods for deworming, personal/individual treatment, ring vaccination by county government and donors, pasture production in dry areas by resilience, individual paddocking, community management of grazing fields through ranging /conservation, insurance uptake, using seasonal weather forecast

Consequences: Emmaciated animals, low accessibility to dewormers, low growth and development, emerging livestock diseases, high cost of vaccine, limited supply of vaccine at agrovets, low productivity, poor foliage and pasture conditions, expensive animal feeds

Consequences: Poor road networks, low flow of trades, washed out bridges, poor road infrastructure, disruption of market activities, few strategic structures for processing
Ongoing adaptations: Maintaining of excess roads, use of permits easily issued, construction of crossing bridge, use of livestock market yards, farm gates and slaughter houses, usinf indigenous knowledge available for home use eg. drying traditionally and honeyed meat
Potential adaptations: Enhance road maintenance and access roots for trekking, use of railway as alternative to market, transport cost to be regulated Increase livestock market yards, discourage farm gate sales, fumigating collection centers, avoid middlemen, embrace modern slaughtering methods and packaging, explore use of by product wastes

Consequences: Road accessibiltiy reduced due to dusty conditions, low transportation, low rustling, high animal trekking in search of pastures and water, increase accessibility to collection points, increase in transportation, low price bargain at farm gate, increased animal slaughtering, increased processing
Ongoing adaptations: Trekking in search of pasture, transportation by motorcycles for weak animals, market structure in place and sheep yard, offtake advisories and health of animals, existence of regulation but weak enforcement, selling to local community

Consequences: Strong winds do not affect seedlings rather they affect mature banana plants, Increased demand for manure and fertilizers - increased cost of production, demand for extension and advisory services increases, thus increasing cost of production.
Ongoing adaptations: Variety selection e.g Nusu Ng'ombe, On farm compost making and stock piling of manures, Use of mainstream government extension services, use of PPP's in extension and advisory service provision
Potential adaptations: Select varieties which are not susceptible to lodging, Joint sourcing/procuring of bulky manures and fertilizers to reduce cost, Establish and operationalize farmer field schoolds, use of other forms of extension approaches e.g extension, mass media such as local FM stations

Consequences: Scarcity of seedlings because nursery operators finds it difficulty to create nurseries during the dry season hence limited access and unaffordability of limited planting materials, Low demand for manures and fertilizers because during dry spell there is no planting activites hence loss of income for farmers and agro dealers, decreased demand for extension and advisory services
Ongoing adaptations: Adoption of new varieties that are early and fast maturing, Engage in other income generating activities, Addressing other enterprises and providing advisory services on other enterprises e.g drought tolerant crops
Potential adaptations: Establishment of more banana hardening nurseries within the county stocked with the right varieties, Stocking of manures and fertilizers during dry spell for use during rainfall onset, Creating awareness on other drought tolerant crops enterprises

Consequences: Loss of jobs and earnings as a result of limited products, increased prices due to high demand because of reduced supply, redundancies in marketers and researchers

Potential adaptations: Diversification into other income generating activities, Venturing into cold storage to help suppliers during times of shortage, value additiion to increase shelf life Diversifcation of skills and competencies to fit into other sectors

Consequences: Job losses due to limited products to be promoted, unpredicatable price fluctuations leading to unsteady incomes, idle marketers and surveyors leading to unemployment and low income

Potential adaptations: Diversification to other sectors, Entering into new contracts and diversification of enterprises, acquiring multiple set of skills in different fields

Consequences: Increases cost of establishment in terms of size of the holes- amount of manure and fertilizer required and choice of variety and farm protection, Lodging of banana plants, Premature harvests and damages to mature banana fingers leading to losses

Potential adaptations: Establish pockets of woodlands on the farm, Sensitization on deep planting practices, Continued practising of agroforestry

Consequences: Delayed establishment of the orchards, loss of seedlings due to moisture stress leading to increased replacement costs, Low yields, retarded growth of the crop leading to high cost of management e.g when the farmer opts for supplementary irrigation for sustainability, pests and diseases attack, reduced production in terms of size, quality, and quantity of bunches - leading to loss of income
Ongoing adaptations: Proper orchard establishment (digging deep and bigger holes and retention of unfilled spaces for collection and retention of water), Application of manure and fertilizers for water retention and supply of nutrients to enhance vigor, mulching, planting of cover crops, Desuckering to regulate evapotranspiration
Potential adaptations: Use of weather advisory and services in planning input acquisition and orchard establishment, Continued use of mulch and cover crops for moisture retention, encourage water harvesting and storage for use during dry spell, drilling of boreholes, Promoting other management practices such as pruning(removal of the male bud)

Consequences: Sorting and grading becomes costly and tedious, Underutilization of the packaging materials/containers, Redundancies in transportation and carriage capacity, diseconomies of scale, and loss of revenues and profits
Ongoing adaptations: Rudimentary sorting and grading skills, Use of the locally available materials for packaging, Venturing into other transport businesses
Potential adaptations: Train farmers on sorting and grading, Use of apporpriate packaging and transporting materials, Diversification to other businesses

Consequences: Loss of key market segments that require specific grades of quality, loss of livelihoods due to handling of few quantities, underutilization of packaging due to limited products, redundancies of transportation capacity leading to diseconomies of scale
Ongoing adaptations: Shading of the harvested banana bunches, Cushioning of the banana fingers, Diversification to other businesses e.g transportation of avocado, cane and potatoes
Potential adaptations: Setting up of cold storage facilities at collection centers, wrapping of banana bunches at farm level during harvesting, Promote use of appropriate transportation and holding facilities, Diversification to other businesses

Consequences: Affects the implementation of extension packages leading to reduced level of production, makes the house inhabitable- this leads to reduced milk yields, reduces fodder production, reduced milk trade
Ongoing adaptations: Online extension services which are very limited, Service provider based extension services, Substandard housing units, Use of banana stems and maize left overs
Potential adaptations: Enhancing online extension services, Providing standard housing for dairy cow with right specification and construction, Establishment of hay barns

Consequences: Hinders implemetation of production activities leading to low yield of feeds, Restructuring and renovation of the housing unit to minimize leakages hence quality manure, leads to reduced yields, leading to reduced fodder production
Ongoing adaptations: Reliance on rainfed farming, using extension packages, using substandard housing in response to heat stress, use of banana stems and maize left overs
Potential adaptations: Use of irrigation based production, Standard housing according to specification and construction, Establishment of hay barns

Consequences: Damaged roads leading to delay in milk transportation to market hence spoilage, Reduces fodder for conservation and quality of the fodder,  Inadequate quality and quantity of product

Potential adaptations: Use of deep freezers and milk coolers, Construction of more hay barns to store feeds, Do proper milk pricing to attract increased production

Consequences: Easy transportation and timely delivery of milk leading to reduced milk spoilage, Quality feeds due to favourable temperature conditions, Low-quality raw materials in value-added products
Ongoing adaptations: Use of bodaboda to transport milk, fermentation of excess milk, use of standing hay i.e feed directly from the farm, sourcing from other potential farms
Potential adaptations: Use of deep freezers and bulk coolers, construction of more hay barns for storage of fodder when it is excess, do proper milk pricing to attract production

Consequences: Reduced heat signs leading to reduced milk production because of low calving intervals, Inadequate fodder production, destruction of feed, formulation of raw materials, increasing rates of disease, reduced milk production.

Potential adaptations: Improved nutrition and proper housing for the dairy cow, Establishment of fodder specifically for conservation and enhanced use of mineral supplements, Use of qualified and certified veterinary officers to advice on disease control and management

Consequences: Extreme hot temperatures hindering breeding, low rates of conception, prolonged dryspell leads to poor quality materials for feed formulation, vaccinations control expected diseases

Consequences: Poor quality milk, Reduced milk volumes

Potential adaptations: Use of alcoholic guns and lactometer, Increased milk production through use of dry matter (conserved), Embrace digital milk recording management system

Consequences: Easy transportation and timely delivery of milk leading to reduced milk spoilage, Quality feeds due to favourable temperature conditions, Low-quality raw materials in value-added products

Potential adaptations: Use of alcohol gun, lactometer, Increase milk production through use of dry matter feeding, Embrace digital milk recording management system

Consequences: High cost of labour and inputs due to additional materials for temperature regulation, Mortality- increased death which will result to losses and low income, increased feed prices due to inadequate raw materials and limited resources

Consequences: Increased temperatures requires that heat proof housing materials are sourced to regulate temperatures, Increased temparatures increases maturity rate thus increasing cost of acquisition, inadequate feeds cause increased competition and prices

Potential adaptations: Smart climate modern structures use of backup generator for manual incubators, use of automatic incubators with standby generators, ration feed formulation at farm level, capacity building on emerging feeds and feeding systems and demonstrations

Consequences: Scarcity and unavailability of seeds and organic manure, high costs of seeds
Ongoing adaptations: Preservation of seeds from previous crops, seed multiplication by ATC Njabini, slicing, greening, lacing with parraffin, use of farmyard manure, blending manure with fertiliser, use of low rates of fertiliser, use of ash to control aphids
Potential adaptations: Seed bulking by both ATCS-Njabini and Ol Jororok, involvement of private sector in seed multiplication and importation, create awareness to farmers on how to make organic fertilises, subsidising cost of chemicals, availing potato varieties resistant to diseases and early maturing varieties

Consequences: Damage infrastructure-thus increasing cost of production, damage to fodder and milk storage structures
Ongoing adaptations: Patching up roads and creating diversions, use of cheaper means of transporting donkey, feed conservation in sheds, value addition(powdered milk, fermentation)
Potential adaptations: Development and maintenance of all weather roads, milk processing plants

Consequences: Rainfall dependence due to lowered capacity to irrigate, increased production costs(in mechanized and irrigated farming)
Ongoing adaptations: Planting clean seed, planting in deep trenches on fields with higher moisture retention(high soil organic matter), irrigation and water sprinkling to prevent frost damage, mulching, intercropping, agroforestry, staggered planting
Potential adaptations: Provision of water for irrigation, mechanization of planting activity, mechanised spraying, introduction of varieties resistant to pests and diseases, introduction of environmentally friendly chemicals, mechanized harvesting activity, use of clean tools-awareness creation

Consequences: Difficult working conditions, high cost of labor due to few working hours, scarcity of laborers, leaching of fertiliser, high cost due to intense spraying program, high cost of labor for spraying, high incidences of environmental pollution, high chances of poisoning through inhalation of chemicals, high incidences of diseases and weeds, germination before harvesting
Ongoing adaptations: Scanty and inconsistent input(fertilizer, chemicals), application at planting and within crop cycle, planting in trenches/trash lines to conserve moisture, strip cropping, manual land preparation, tree planting, water harvesting, staggered planting
Potential adaptations: Mechanization(land preparation, tilling, planting, spraying), access to protective gear for agronomic practices(spraying), advisory services for planting times and production requirements, conservation agriculture, county support to construct drainage channels

Consequences: Loss of employment opportunities and livelihoods, lack of storage facilities
Ongoing adaptations: Manual sorting and grading, manual packaging in bags(nylon), volume based packaging, use of lorries/trucks and bikes, loading done manually, truck collects the bagged potatoes from the remotest end till it is full, storage in dry sheds, pest and rodent control
Potential adaptations: Mechanized harvesting, weight based packaging, mechanical loading, value addition

Consequences: Input accessibility challenges(inaccessible roads)
Ongoing adaptations: Internal borrowing from enterprises, borrowing groups, raising floors with locally available materials, draining around the house, use of the sawdust, local brooding
Potential adaptations: Internal borrowing from value chain saccos, cooperatives and banks, use of expertise and approved designs by the ministry, establishment of housing units, promoting incubators to individual farmers

Consequences: Increase in pests and diseases incidences affects fodder production and milk production
Ongoing adaptations: Traditional herbs and concoctions
Potential adaptations: Develop early warning systems so farmers prepared with pesticides before hand, train and implement on farm good agricultural practices, feeds harvesting and conservation

Consequences: Infertility-due to poor nutrition, scarcity-leads to high cost of feeds, reduced access to credit
Ongoing adaptations: Use of bulls, use of crop residues e.g maize stovers, feed conservation
Potential adaptations: Supply concentrates to improve fertility, teach farmers on breeding cycle monitoring and also implement feeder establishment and conservation, establish dairy relief farmers, input subsidies to farmers, fund to cushion producer, promotion of disease tolerant animal breeds

Consequences: Reduced income and return to the farmers, sales reduced, job losses(processors, transporters)
Ongoing adaptations: Diversification of alternative products e.g powdered milk
Potential adaptations: Enhance sustained on farm milk production, community based milk reserves, access to insurance products to cushion dairy activities

Consequences: Low level of product supply
Ongoing adaptations: Low sales(farm gate/local markets)
Potential adaptations: Farmer associations/cooperatives to increase bargaining power

Consequences: Reduced/low production of eggs and poultry manure, high transport costs due to  reduced economies of scale
Ongoing adaptations: Best breed selection/high yielding breeds, immediate post laying selling eggs, use of local containers to store, transporting individual in small quantities, defeathering
Potential adaptations: Record keeping of individual birds, use of modern storage and communal facilities, communal transportation of products by groups and saccos, improving infrastructure, value addition of poultry products

Consequences: Increased operation cost-use lots of cost to collect feed and milk
Ongoing adaptations: Control of milk delivery to bulking centres
Potential adaptations: Establish mechanisms for sustained milk production and supply, establishing processing plants

Consequences: Scarcity of potato seed transport problems, fertiliser soaking/dissolving, caking of fertiliser, limited access to inputs due to transport challenges
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers secure seeds from usual markets or stocking from previous crop, buying from seed multipliers, buying subsidized feeds from cereal boards, buying from agro dealers, use of manure, some farmers plant with no manure or fertiliser, farmers acquire the chemicals at the time of spraying as need rise
Potential adaptations: More seed multipliers to come on boards, training of farmers on how to do on farm seeds bulking, more subsidized fertiliser specific for potatoes to be available and in nearby shops ,training on composting, farmers to be given loans on agro chemicals,where possible subsidized chemicals to be availed, bulk sourcing through groups

Consequences: Decrease in quantity of milk produced-reduced/lost marketing, outlets operation cost will go up-use more cost to source more milk
Ongoing adaptations: Reduced marketing activity due to milk scarcity, sale of milk at low farm gate prices
Potential adaptations: Niche markets, contract farming, access to insurance products to cushion dairy activities

Consequences: Difficulty in transport due to poor state of roads, seed spoilage
Ongoing adaptations: Seed transportation(boda boda/donkeys), use of terraces(drain excess water), seed recyling, local scale seed multiplication
Potential adaptations: Improved road infrastructure, to ease access to inputs, improved seedbed husbandry(raising of seedbed), construction of cut off drains

Consequences: Increase pests and diseases, poor establishment of fodder and pastures-due to poor germination and survival rates
Ongoing adaptations: Administration and application of locally available drugs/ointments for pest and disease control, on farm diversification(crop growing)
Potential adaptations: Enhance access and monitoring on the use of veterinary services and insurance, establishment of drought resistant pastures and fodder, harvesting and conservation of feeds

Consequences: Low prices due to low quality and reduced demand, poor marketing linkage-high promotion but with low demand
Ongoing adaptations: Agent determines price done by word of mouth, sale on local markets
Potential adaptations: Farmers groups to enhance bargaining, formalized marketing(contracts), new market opportunities

Consequences: There is scarcity of potatoes, nothing much to be priced, no linking activity
Ongoing adaptations: Tuber sale at farm gate prices(low prices)
Potential adaptations: Direct access to processors, contract farming to urb exploitation, farmer associations to facilitate marketing agents

Consequences: Higher costs due to increased demand for vet services, increased mortality rates for chicks, high costs of feed
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local disease control methods for various diseases e.g use of aloe vera, building well ventilated housing for the chicks, localised cross breeding of chicken to set superior traits e.g weight gains, disease  tolerance
Potential adaptations: Vaccination should be done when there are foreseen drought or other hazard risks, promote chicken hatcheries within the sub counties, promote the planting of various raw materials for on farm feed formulation(sunflower), routine vaccination, reduction of raw material costs

Consequences: Reduced potato quality and quantity, high unit cost of storage, high unit costs of transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Application of indigenuous technical knowledge, selling the produce immediately after harvesting to reduce storage costs
Potential adaptations: Initiate public private partnerships to provide affordable forecast services, construction of high quality and modern storage facilities

Consequences: Low bargaining power in the markets, extra feeding costs due to decreased slaughter, refrigerated trucks are required to reduce produce spoilage
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers sell their eggs and chicken locally individually and to middlemen due to low volumes
Potential adaptations: Educate contract farming guidelines and procedures to farmers, develop aggregation centres at ward levels, county support to explore better market outlets, branding

Consequences: High mortality of chicks while in transit from hatcheries, increased incidences of diseases, malnutrition and weight loss, reduced hygienic conditions due to dust
Ongoing adaptations: Feeding the chicken early in the morning to avoid high temperatures, use chicken housing with improved ventilation, feed chicken from household kitchen waste, diet supplement including available cereals, on farm feed formulation and feed rationing
Potential adaptations: Plant locally available species as feed sources, build farmer capacity in management of hatcheries, supplement with improved commercil feed, adopt water harvesting(tanks)

Consequences: Cold air and soil can lead to premature harvest or crop failure, increased cost of production from increased use of fungicides, high costs of labour for land preparation and crop management
Ongoing adaptations: Use of organic fertilisers, purchase of certified seeds and select in the subsequent seasons, protecting crop from cold by laying grass over soil and crop(mulching)
Potential adaptations: Adjust planting dates to escape frost damage, remove obstacle to cold air movement and drainage within the farm, apply potassium based fungicide to assist tissue recovery after frost, application of foliar feeds with potassium nitrogen

Consequences: Poor grades in terms of sizes and quality, low yields
Ongoing adaptations: Use of indigenuous technical knowledge, mixing grades to sell at high price, consumption of poor quality produce
Potential adaptations: Promote the use of integrated weed management, improved storage facilities(pests and rodent free)

Consequences: Low rates of crop establishment, delay in crop development(longer maturity period), increased incidence of pest and diseases, stunted growth
Ongoing adaptations: Use of soil bands around roots to protect underground buds, timely weeding to reduce competition for nutrients, use of integrated pest and diseases management(cultural and traditional methods) to reduce production costs
Potential adaptations: Providing wind and cold protection by planting wind breaking trees or solid structure such as houses, training on integrated weed management, integrated pests and diseases management

Consequences: Vaccines and vet chemicals easily go bad, death of chicken on transit from far hatcheries, low supply of materials for feed formulation, high cost of feeds
Ongoing adaptations: Breeding of indigenous poultry resistant to diseases, use of cross breeds with improved disease tolerance and production attributes
Potential adaptations: Design and promote appropriate chicken housing for local conditions, set up community/satellite hatcheries, improve breeding programs, capacity build on feed formulation, routine vaccination and breeding

Consequences: Increased in chicken sale prices due to scarcity, extra costs for easier transportation and preservation, reduced market activity/linkages
Ongoing adaptations: Sell products at farmgate to the middlemen, traders purchase small quantities from other markets to satisfy the demand, selling the products directly to the consumers from the farm or share the costs with their farmers groups
Potential adaptations: Form local marketing groups to improve on aggregation, provide financial support for investment in production infrastructure e.g hatcheries, value addition of poultry meat(cooking/frying)

Consequences: Increased cost per unit of packaging, increased marketing cost per unit of produce, high cost of transport per unit of produce
Ongoing adaptations: Selling in smaller quantities, increase the cost of produce-hiking of prices to increase their profit margins, use of cheaper transport(carts and motor bikes, pick up trucks)
Potential adaptations: Support farmer communities to develop equitable linkages with VCC actors and markets, adopt crop insurance to protect from crop failure, increase the markets and collection points to reduce transportation, branding

Consequences: Poor quality seedlings, water stress, quality of manure is low
Ongoing adaptations: Use of certified planting material from certified nurseries(JKUAT, KARLO and Farmer Groups), use of improved banana varieties, use of organic matter for fertilisation
Potential adaptations: Set up tissue culture banana nurseries, set up small scale water harvesting and irrigation systems, training on manure composting, banana hardening varieties

Consequences: High seedlings prices, slow uptake of nutrients, high cost of planting material
Ongoing adaptations: Use of cheaper planting materials, planting around kitchen waste water drain point, use of mulch(grass/hay)
Potential adaptations: Strengthen extension services, provision of certified and clean planting material, implementation of water harvesting techniques, promote conservation agriculture

Consequences: Produce attracts the low value markets due to low quality, loss of high value market due to delayed maturity, increases the eventual price of produce due to high cost of production
Ongoing adaptations: Sell produce at the low value markets, consume the produce at household level, sell to local markets at lower prices, sell directly to consumers to reduce cost of transportation
Potential adaptations: Strengthening existing linkages within the banana VCC, motivating to produce high quality fruits, development of value added products and markets to maintain demand during harsh seasons, capacity building in strategies to reach regional markets, branding

Consequences: Less soil moisture, black cotton soil becomes difficult to work on/plough, increased cost of production due to increased use of pesticides(increased pest incidence), high labour requirements, reduced labour efficiency
Ongoing adaptations: Use of manure, application of indigenous technical knowledge, reducing hired labour for farm management activities to lower costs, use of irrigation and integrated weed management
Potential adaptations: Practising water harvesting, conservation agriculture, introduce new technologies that harmonise with farmers local knowledge, train extension agents to establish, improve or support pilot/demonstration plots, outscaling integrated weed management

Consequences: Low establishment in planting and rooting, poor growth and development, banana pseudo stem collapse, increased incidence of pests and diseases, slow growth rate, water stress
Ongoing adaptations: Small scale water harvesting, irrigation small scale, prop banana pseudo-stem using strong physical support, use of cultural and mechanical methods of controlling pests and diseases
Potential adaptations: Promote and provide water harvesting technologies and irrigation, grants provision for water harvesting and irrigation, support farmers with tools and equipments, integrated pest management training, GAPs

Consequences: Reduced supply of fertiliser, low supply of seeds, low quality seeds, increase in pesticides demand
Ongoing adaptations: Use of organic fertilisers, purchase of certified seeds and select in the subsequent seasons, reduce the use of pesticides to save costs
Potential adaptations: Use of certified/clean planting material, use of drought tolerant with high yield, subsidise the costs of certified seeds, capacity build on IPM in farms to reduce on chemical use, fertilizer subsidies

Consequences: Low quality milk, stunted growth, mortality of animals, heat/cold stress, low production due to the cold, high production cost due to procurement of drugs and specialised labour
Ongoing adaptations: Use of supplements, delayed breeding, reduced milking frequencies, use of traditional methods of pest and diseases control
Potential adaptations: Promotion of improved fodder, forages and feed, promote improved livestock breeds and animal husbandry, county wide training on prevention and treatment of diseases, training farmers on fodder conservation and dry season feeding

Consequences: High effect on harvesting quality and quantity, high levels of harvest spoilage
Ongoing adaptations: Subdivide banana bunch into banana hands for sale to increase profits, processing to flour or chips to increase market value, use of improvised makeshift storage structures
Potential adaptations: Promotion of weather index based insurance, setting up of processing facilities at county level, provision of county level cold storage facilities, specialised storage for raw bananas to prevent spoilage

Consequences: High effect on harvesting quality and quantity, high storage cost per unit of produce, increased risk of milk spoilage from antibiotic contamination, increased costs for milk refrigeration
Ongoing adaptations: Household consumption, immediate sale to prevent household storage
Potential adaptations: Value addition at local level, promote access to refrigerated storage structures, small scale cooling facilities, training on how to handle dairy cows under drug treatment, separating milk from diseased and healthy animals

Consequences: Reduced grass vigour and growth rate, reduced milk production(calving increases production), high cost of production from the procurement of drugs and specialist services due to dystocia
Ongoing adaptations: Water harvesting in small scale or supplementation, use bull service, AI, hand spraying
Potential adaptations: Promotion of improved fodder, forages and feed for livestock, promote improved breeds and tolerance to such weather related risks, rehabilitate existing infrastructure e.g. cattle dips, hay bulking

Consequences: Decreased feeding, increased disease incidences, reduced cleaning rates, reduced hygienic conditions, increased demand for extension services, high feed intake, low egg production
Ongoing adaptations: Feeding the chicken early in the morning to avoid high temperatures, cross breed local and improved breeds to acquire disease tolerance, feed chicken from household kitchen waste, farmers have improved dust masks
Potential adaptations: Educate farmers on importance of improved ventilated housing, promote and bulk the seeds for the feeds(easy to grow varieties), access to early warning advisories(timely vaccination), farmers professional breeding programmes, government to subsidize the cost of dust masks

Consequences: Perishability of the eggs and meat increases, reduced slaughter activities due to stress and reduced growth rates
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers store eggs on sawdust to reduce temperature, slaughter on order, use of sawdust or trays
Potential adaptations: Develop cooling stores by aggregation centres within the ward,s develop/construct satellite slaughter house in every sub county, improve the feeding to get quality eggs to last longer, better access to cage facilities for marketing

Consequences: Lack of feed(fodder and pastures), calving rates go down, increased pests and disease incidences, increased demand for vet services which increases production costs
Ongoing adaptations: Supplement feeding, halting/timing breeding to ensure births occur during weather conditions, using traditional methods for diseases and pest control, culling
Potential adaptations: Plant heat tolerant fodder, use improved reproductive technologies e.g. embryo transfer and sexed semen, conduct routine vaccination, campaigns to reduce disease burden, disease surveillance

Consequences: Increased cost of packaging and transport cost per unit of packaging from overall low production, high market prices for end consumers
Ongoing adaptations: Selling in smaller units, use of cheaper transport means(pickups), using brokers to offtake their produce to the market
Potential adaptations: Support development of cheaper packaging material, expanding market by developing range of potato products, reduce distance to market by developing collection points and markets at ward level, advocacy for standard packaging and branding

Consequences: Loss of contract market due to low grade and volumes of dairy products, high cost of dairy products, rejection of buyers in case of contamination
Ongoing adaptations: Sale to neighbours in small quantities for higher prices, formation of common interest groups and farmer cooperatives to improve aggregation
Potential adaptations: Drawing of milk purchase contracts to set quality and quantity levels and prices, strengthen cooperatives through capacity building, training of treatment of dairy cows

Consequences: High storage costs, low volumes of produce to be transported, high risk of contamination due to use of antibiotics
Ongoing adaptations: Traditional preservation for household consumption, use of farmer groups and community based organisations to store and transport
Potential adaptations: Value addition of milk and milk products, setting up collection points close to production areas to save on transport costs, identify opportunities for community post harvest processing to add value

Consequences: Perishability of the eggs and meat is high, meat will go bad hence need for direct refrigeration, low volumes of production, high energy requirements
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers store eggs on sawdust to reduce temperatures, they slaughter on order
Potential adaptations: Install refrigeration facilities at local levels, have alternative meat preservation methods(drying, brining), construct satellite slaughterhouse at sub county

Consequences: High prices due to high cost per unit of milk, brokers and middlemen maximise on the high prices at the expense of farmers, loss of market due to antibiotic contamination
Ongoing adaptations: Delivery to high value markets such as hotels, farmers negotiate milk prices and sell directly to the consumers
Potential adaptations: Reducing costs per unit of product by bulking and selling as organized unit(cooperative), provide accurate and timely market information, farmer associations and branding

Consequences: Reduced availability of the product on the market, increased market prices, low quality products
Ongoing adaptations: Consume their produce at household level, farmers sell their produce at farmgate, selling at the open air market, direct produce selling to consumers
Potential adaptations: Set up financial mechanisms for investments in production and value addition infrastructure, strengthen the cooperatives capacity building and linkages for financial support, branding

Consequences: Low banana quality, loss in banana bunchweight, increase in cost due to transporting low volumes
Ongoing adaptations: Storage for household consumption, create collection and produce processing centres, form farmer groups to share produce transporting costs, value addition through flour and jam making
Potential adaptations: Value addition at farm level, educate on methods of produce processing and preservation at the farm level, establish collection points closer to farmers, develop road infrastructure to save on transport costs

Consequences: Reduced quality and quantity of pasture, increased feed and water intake, high demand for drugs to treat against pest and diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Use of feed supplements, increased use of locally available feeds, using conventional drugs to treat conditions()vaccines
Potential adaptations: Use improved fodder varieties, protection of animal from cold(comfortable/ protected sheds), vaccination routines at county level, water harvesting, hay bulking and fodder conservation

Consequences: Plant seedling chilling injury, increased disease incidences, increased use of fungicides, low quality of planting material
Ongoing adaptations: Use tolerant potato varieties, early planting, use of certified seeds, stocking of seeds, use of organic manure to improve growth
Potential adaptations: Develop local frost forecasts(promotion of early warning systems), capacity building on timely and appropriate use of fungicides, construction of communal planting seed storage structures, provide financial mechanisms to purchase inputs

Consequences: Poor infrastructure/poor roads, apiary location (land)- floods the locations making it difficult to set up an apiary, rain destroys installed beehives/welting
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of a bee house with a roof/modern bee house, use of quality materials which are water proof
Potential adaptations: Introducing bee friendly trees in every homestead e.g battle brush, sunflower, hyacinth, marigolds, blackberries, pumpkins, strawberries, raspberries in order to attract bees, workshop for making beehives and bee keeping accessories, pre-qualification of local merchants to source beehives

Consequences: Reduced suitability of locations to have apiaries
Ongoing adaptations: Cooperatives and unions to link farmers & groups to suppliers, planting bee-friendly trees in apiary sites, providing syrup in the apiaries, training on construction of bee equipment
Potential adaptations: Introducing bee-friendly trees, pre-qualification of local merchants to source the beehives, training local artisans

Consequences: Selling affected by low production of honey, low yields hence no promotion
Ongoing adaptations: Establish platforms for promotion e.g webistes, local radio, TVs, facebook, e-marketing, door to door deliveries
Potential adaptations: Regional and national exhibition, e-marketing platform, web-adverts, forming a collateral union, signing formal contracts with motels, supermarkets, wholesalers e.t.c (buyers)

Consequences: Low honey produced hence low promotion and sales
Ongoing adaptations: Establishment of cooperatives to add value to honey, package label and grade adverstisement through websites, whatsapp, facebook, creating awareness through local radio FM, TV, exhibition, SMS e.t.c, diversifying honey products- bee syrup, wax, pollen and honey grading
Potential adaptations: Grading of honey as per the nectar - e.g croton, acacia e.t.c, regional and national exhibition, e-marketing platform, web adverts, forming a collateral union, signing formal contracts with motels, supermarkets, wholesellers etc

Consequences: Bee hive inspection- bee daily activities are low making it impossible to inspect, colony separation- small colonies that splitting is not possible (reproduction is low)
Ongoing adaptations: Introducing green artifical feeding to trigger reproduction and later colony splitting technology, introduction of flow hive technology
Potential adaptations: Using centrifugal machine to avoid comb damage, introducing complete processing system with settling tanks, wax processors, honey press, enhancing collection centers in every zone

Consequences: Small, dormant swarms and colony separation is not possible, inadequate foliage leads to reduced honey production
Ongoing adaptations: Development of farmer field school to improve management of bees and inspection of colonies, establishment of modern beekeeping to improve splitting of big colonies, use of clearer board when harvesting to avoid killing bees during drought period
Potential adaptations: To install surveillance cameras in the hive, to insert/place a tracker in every queen, to introduce double suppers in the langstroth to create space for the swarm, placing queen excluders to separate honey and pollen/broods, placing comb sheets/comb starters with plastic cells

Consequences: Processing- inadequate honey for processing, transportation- poor road networks
Ongoing adaptations: Flow hive technology (only harvest when its ready), bulk collection and stored in the settling tanks awaiting processing, establish and enhance collection, storage and aggregation points at respective zones
Potential adaptations: Grading honey according to the nectar e.g. croton, acacia

Consequences: Processing- no yields which affects processing, storage- during drought, honey yields reduces leading to no storage
Ongoing adaptations: Using centrifuge machines to draw honey without breaking the combs, using settling tanks to separate honey and wax, establishing and enhancing honey collection centers to improve transport logistics
Potential adaptations: Using centrifugal machines to avoid comb damage, introducing a complete processing system with settling tanks, wax processor and honey press, enhancing collection centers in every honey zone

Consequences: Moderate demand for inputs, impassable roads constrain input supply
Ongoing adaptations: Fodder conservation, planting/bulking of fodder, centralized vaccination, training of para-vets
Potential adaptations: Equipping veterinary laboratory, introduction of e-technology on disease surveillance and tracking, introduction/building of gene bank in the existing livestock improvement center, establisment of AI facility, establishment of model feed lots, capacity building of farmers on feed formulation, establishment of  strategic stores

Consequences: Increase of input prices, outbreak of diseases associated with drought, reduced breeding, high mortality rates, frequent abortion
Ongoing adaptations: Planting of drought resistant and early maturing fodder crops, animal tracking, training of paravets, introducing improved breeds, controlled breeding
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on pasture production, preservation and storage, purchasing of seeds and equipment, equipping of vet-laboratory for fast disease testing, introduction of e-technologies in disease surveillance and tracking, capacity building on good quality breeds

Consequences: Delayed transportation because of poor roads/floods, demand is higher than supply (few animals in the market)
Ongoing adaptations: Formation of cooperatives, networking, establishing policy and regulatory frameworks
Potential adaptations: Introducing sales apps, introducing live weighing scales and price tagging animals, holding organized auction days, developing and using digital tools for data collection of buyers & sellers

Consequences: Low prices due to emaciated animals
Ongoing adaptations: Networking, formation of cooperatives, establishing county policies
Potential adaptations: Building awareness on marketing/ auction days, introducing apps for marketing, introducing liveweight scale/price tagging, holding virtual training days for farmers

Consequences: High productivity, availability of seeds, low prices of feeds, increase in wet weather associated diseases e.g foot and mouth disease, increase in cost of disease surveillance, high risk of waterborne diseases, high acaricide cost
Ongoing adaptations: Controlled grazing/grazing plans, fodder conservation, provision of vaccines, water harvesting, disease control
Potential adaptations: Establishment of vaccines centers at subcounty level, establishment of more spray races/dips, formation of cattle dips management committees, establishment of animals holding grounds and enroute  to the market

Consequences: Low productivity, scarcity of feeds, high prices of feeds, increase in drought associated parasites, increase in disease surveillance
Ongoing adaptations: Animal migration (pastoralism), purchasing of hay/droughts, survival pellets, supplementation of animals with vitamins, increasing water pans , boreholes for ease of spraying
Potential adaptations: Training on feed formulation and establishment of feed lots, establishment of strategic stores, establishment of vaccine distribution centers in every sub-county, enforcement of policy on stray dogs, deworming and vaccination, capacity building on the importances of cattle dips management commitees

Consequences: High cost of transportation, low number of animals to be collected, high prices of animals, high body weight
Ongoing adaptations: Improvement of infrastructure, increased number of slaughter houses in all markets points
Potential adaptations: Establishment of airstrip/airport, purchasing of trucks to transport livestock to abottoirs, construction of modern abottoir at subcounty level, value addition of slaughter by products, organized auction days, networking social apps

Consequences: Low prices for livestock carcasses, high transport costs, low livestock body weight
Ongoing adaptations: Working through strategic marketing points, building abattoirs in each market point, livestock off-take
Potential adaptations: Training on the importance of animal holding grounds for marketing, building of modern abattoir and linkage to market, capacity building on value addition of by products of slaughter animals

Consequences: Supply of feeds will be delayed due to the destruction of infrastructures e.g roads, bridges caused by floods, supply of equipments will also be delayed, high cost of equipments due to high demand /low supply,  inaccessibility to veterinary services by local farmers
Ongoing adaptations: Purchasing of feeds in bulk, formation of groups with common interests, training farmers on how to make their own feeds, training individual farmers/ groups on artisan (Jua Kali ) products, training farmers on poultry practices and husbandry
Potential adaptations: Training of farmers to make feeds using locally available materials, formation of groups with common interest to purchase feeds in bulk, capacity build the existing groups, training of champion farmers on diseases prevention, control and vaccination, construction of improved housing with insolation rooms, training of the youth/women to make equipments in polytechnics within the country

Consequences: Shortage of feeds, availability of equipment but there is low demand for them
Ongoing adaptations: Training on how to make their feeds, storing of feeds in bulk, training of farmers on making and handling of equipment, training the farmers on how to handle vaccines
Potential adaptations: Purchasing of feeds in bulk, training farmers on how to make their own feeds, training farmers, youth and women on artisanry to make their own equipments, training of farmers on the best poultry products and husbandry

Consequences: Due to destruction of infrastructures and outbreak of diseases there will be low income to farmers and brokers, As a result of transmission of diseases, the availability of products and by-products is limited
Ongoing adaptations: Establish a good storage facility by groups of farmers for bulking of products, Use of individual farmers/groups to promote chicken products, training groups on the utilization of chicken products, training of farmers on poultry practices and husbandry
Potential adaptations: Establish a good storage facility by group of farmers for bulking of products/byproducts, training groups on the utilization of chicken products, use of individual farmers/groups to promote chicken products/by products, training of farmers on best poultry practices and husbandry

Consequences: Promotion- market information will be strengthened as a result easy access to buyer/trader, the sales of chicken and its by products will be high but at low prices
Ongoing adaptations: Estabish a good storage facility by groups of farmers for bulking of products and byproducts, use of individual farmers/groups to promote chicken products and by products, training groups on the utilization of chicken products, training of farmers on poultry practices and husbandry
Potential adaptations: Establishing a good storage facility by group of farmers for bulking of products/ by products, training groups on the utilization of chicken products, use of individual farmers/groups to promote chicken products/by products, training of farmers on best poultry practices and husbandry

Consequences: Chicken feeds will be swept away by floods, a lot of feed wastage, difficult to clean the poultry house resulting to disease outbreaks
Ongoing adaptations: Use of locally available materials, training farmers on chicken feed consumption, digging cut-off drains to channel water away form poultry house, formation of groups/ cooperatives to enhance cold-chain storage at the local level by use of renewable energy, training of farmers on handling of vaccines
Potential adaptations: Training farmers on chicken feeds consumption, construction of poultry houses with a gentle slope on the floor for easy cleaning, formation of groups/cooperatives to enhance cold-chain storage at the local level by use of renewable energy

Consequences: Low availability of feeds from the farms, farmers will incur high cost to buy the feeds, chicken health will deteriorate, outbreak of diseases as a result of dust particles
Ongoing adaptations: Storing of feeds in bulk, training on proper feeding of chicken to farmers, training on proper cleaning of poultry house, training farmers on handling vaccines, formation of groups and cooperatives to enhance on cold-chain storage facilities
Potential adaptations: Storing feeds in bulk to utilize during drought, encourage production of cereal and other chicken feeds, training farmers on hygiene and proper cleaning methods at poultry house, formation of groups and cooperatives to enhance on cold chain storage facilities, training farmers on handling of vaccines

Consequences: Reduction of white meat on eateries/restaurants, transmission of diseases leading to death and loses to farmers/traders
Ongoing adaptations: Purchasing in bulk at eateries/restaurants, good storage facility, establish a good storage facility for bulking of products/by products to enhance the quantity, ferrying of products by farmers in bulk to reduce individual cost of transportation
Potential adaptations: Establishing a good storage facility for bulking of products/by products to enhance the quality purchasing in bulk at eateries and resturanats, good storage facilities Ferrying of products/byproducts in bulk to reduce the cost of individual transport

Consequences: Increase of white meat in the hotels eateries, there would be more supply of chicken and its by products leading to low prices
Ongoing adaptations: Purchasing in bulk at eateries/resturants, good storage facilities, establishing a good storage facility for bulking of products to enhance quality, ferrying of products and by products by farmers in bulk to reducte the cost of transportation to individuals
Potential adaptations: Purchasing in bulk at eateries and resturants, good storage facilities, establishing a good storage facility for bulking of products or byproducts to enhance the quality, ferrying of products/by products in bulk to reduce the cost of individual transport

Consequences: Adequate feeds and water, increase in foot rot incidences and pneumonia, provision of veterinary services, high incidences of disease, high demand of veterinary services, sheep/goats deaths
Ongoing adaptations: Storage for future use, differed grazing, controlled grazing, capacity building, grazing management commitees, mass vaccination, disease surveillance, supportive treatment, regulation of agro-dealers, use of ethno medicine, upgrading of indigenous breeds, maintaining pure breeds, control inbreeding, capacity building of farmers

Consequences: Shortage of feeds, unavilability of water, conflicts and low production, limited access to vet services, high cost of vet drugs, outbreak of diseases, unscrupulous dealers who sell fake drugs to the farmers

Services through facilitation, equipping of labs, strenghening diseases surveillance and reporting

Consequences: Limited access to acaricides, high supply of fake drugs, high resistance to the accaricides, outbreak of diseases (ECF), low production (meat and milk), high infestation of worms, high cost of drugs, low productivity and death

Consequences: High bulking and fattening- availability of quality feeds, high market prices, poor road networks/infrastructure, high transportation cost, lack of market access, losses due to road accidents/prolonged hours of transporting animals

Consequences: Inadequate quality feeds, high cost of feeds, less bulking and fattening, transportation of sheep and goats to the market- low supply to the markets, high transportation costs, roads banditry increases

Consequences: Low farmer sale prices at farm gate, reduced marketing activities and linkages, market scarcity of poultry products, increased market prices by brokers and traders, high perishability of products

Consequences: Increased feed losses(moulds/rotting), limited acccess and high feed /drugs cost due to transport challenges, low access to breeding chicks, high labour requirements and costs
Ongoing adaptations: Use of improved/traditional poultry breeds, proper drying of grains and storage in a dry place, use of chicken cross breeds, use of drugs/traditional herbs for pests and diseases control
Potential adaptations: Establishment of feed drying units in each ward, farmers to have elementary knowledge on vet services, establish county supported policy framework on feed formulation, road infrastructure improved to facilitate feed access

Consequences: Reduced viability of seeds, reduced demand for inputs, reduced input access(low supply), increased costs due to scarcity

Consequences: Reduces the quality for selling, reduced quantities and reduces market accessibility, reduced activity of farmer associations

Potential adaptations: Use of standardized market weights(kgs instead of volumes), county support to access external markets, access to crop insurance products(cushion against loss)

Consequences: Land preparation becomes difficult as droughts create hardpans, reduced viability, seed scarcity, reduced demand for inputs(seeds/fertilizers)
Ongoing adaptations: Mechanisation of land preparation i.e oxdrawn ploughs, retain crop biomass to conserve moisture, planting of drought tolerant and certified seeds, contracting labor, use of traditional seed supply systems(farmer to farmer)
Potential adaptations: Access and promotion of certified seeds, access to information(seed preservation, dressing and pest control), diversify planted bean varieties to marketable varieties

Consequences: Increasing incidences of storage pests/rodents, poor harvest quality and low quantity, labour scarcity and inceased costs

Potential adaptations: Mechanisation of harvesting, threshing and winnowing, promote value addition(tinning), access to improved storage structures(pest free structures)

Consequences: Reduced costs of processing, poor quality and quantity of harvested produce, loss of value addition opportunities

Potential adaptations: Improvement of harvesting, sorting and grading equipment(reduces losses), improved post harvest handling(sorting, grading), explore bean value addition products(drying, roasting and tinning)

Consequences: Limited access to inputs, limited labour requirements

Consequences: Low market supply(scarcity and high demand), reduced farmer prices(low quality), reduced market/marketing opportunities, shift in market focus(cereal/legume commodities), loss of market linkages, information and marketing opportunities
Ongoing adaptations: Seed hoarding to increase market prices, sale of seed locally and at farm gate, use of middlemen/brokers for marketing
Potential adaptations: The farmers should add value to their produce by applying insecticide for preservation and sell when the market is up, the farmers should come together as a cooperative to help the collective bargaining, formation of producers marketing groups, county support to explore external markets and repair damaged road infrastructure

Consequences: Low quality of planting seeds, labour scarcity, high labour costs

Consequences: Increased temperatures affect poultry through stress which leads to low quality feeds and high costs, labour scarcity, increased water demand, increased vaccine stability

Potential adaptations: Restructuring the houses and researching for newer economical designs, improved poultry breeding programme, promote growing of local grains as feeds, county support to establish millers per sub county, introduction and availability of thermostable vaccines, improved coverage of trainings for disease control

Consequences: Low market supply(scarcity and high demand), reduced farmer prices(low quality), reduced market/marketing opportunities, shift in market focus(cereal/legume commodities)

Potential adaptations: Use of standardized market weights(kgs instead of volumes), county support to access external markets, access to crop insurance products(cushion against loss)

Consequences: Slaughtering-inadequate water so hygiene is low, transportation-dust(dressing costs go high), low carcass weights, increased incidence and rapid perishability(high temperatures), increased energy requirements(cold storage and refrigeration)

Consequences: Poor crop germination and establishment, poor workability of land during ploughing and planting, low agronomic efficiency, increased pests infestation

Potential adaptations: Access to subsidized and mechanized land equipment(rippers, subsoilers), county support for animal training(draught power), access to irrigation equipment, conservation agriculture

Consequences: Poor seed establishment and growth vigour, increased production costs(land preparation), reduced efficiency in labour and fertilisers applied

Consequences: Increased difficulty in land preparation, deteriorated soil quality(low organic matter, microbial activity), poor germination and crop vigour, reduced use and efficiency of fertilisers

Potential adaptations: Minimum tillage and conservation agriculture, establish community owned farm machineries(jab planters, harvesters), apropriate use of meteorological information, use of cultural weed control methods, adoption of greenhouses, drip irrigation

Consequences: Poor seed germination, low growth vigour, reduced agronomic efficiency(fertilisers/applied chemicals), reduced labour efficiency, land preparation challenges, increased weeds prevalence, high labour costs(weeding)

Consequences: Market scarcity of poultry products, reduced farmer prices(farm gate), loss of market and marketing opportunities(undefined markets), shift in market focus, increased market prices(brokersand traders)

Consequences: Poor drainage since the water infiltration rate in the soil is lowered hence poor germination-the seed rots, limited access to inputs(transport/terrain challenges), limited labour requirements

Consequences: Poor quality of harvested grains, high afflatoxin incident, challenges in grain drying, shelling and grading, high transport costs, loss of post harvest value opportunities

Potential adaptations: Promotion of solar powered grain driers and shellers at farm level, establish community cereal banks(storage reserves/seed banks), improvement of rural access roads by the county government

Consequences: Communication breakdown between buyers outdoor promotion activities cant take place well

Consequences: Reduced slaughter(increased chances for contamination), limited transport(farm to storage), increased perishability(egg, carcass), increased labour requirements(dressing), divert to household consumption

Consequences: Reduced surplus- no produce for marketing-thus no additional/extra money for other domestic requirements, reduced prices-quality supply is greater than demand, divert produce to local market and household consumption

Consequences: Reduced farmer prices(low quality), increased trader prices due to scarcity, reduced marketing linkages, divert produce to local markets and household consumption, reduced household income

Consequences: Late planting, logging and leaching of nutrients, poor germination and establishment, increased labour requirements, challenges in land preparation, pests and diseases incidence

Consequences: Rate of preparation-low and expensive, more man power is required for quality work hence high labor costs, increased seed loss by pests and diseases, low fertilisers efficiency, reduced labor requirements and efficiency(more time consuming)

Consequences: Shortage of planting seeds, limited access to inputs due to transport challenges, labour scarcity hence high labour costs

Consequences: Reduced flock vitality(reduced:feeding, brooding, breeding, egg laying), malnutrition(low feeding rate), low growth rates, increased pests and disease incidence, high labour costs

Potential adaptations: Improved breeder technology(facilities), capacity building and access to modern disease and pest facilities, research into improved poultry housing(using local resources e.g. hyacinth reeds)

Consequences: Competition with pests/rodents, low quality(very light) and poor harvest quantities, high spillage rate-easily crash and get wasted(due to low density)

Consequences: Increased feeding rates, high energy requirements(heating), increased diseases prevalence(coccidiosis) and flock mortality, high cost of veterinary services

Consequences: Low quality due to low density and poor harvest quantities, increased post harvest damage due to pests and rodents, reduced post harvest value addition and commercial processing opportunities

Potential adaptations: Promotion of modern driers and storage facilities at farm levels(moisture free), promotion of community cereal banks, mechanization of harvest activities(harvesting, winnowing and sorting)

Consequences: Delayed or irregular harvesting process, the timeliness of production collection will be irregular, slowed transportation speed(field to storage), increased post harvest losses and afflatoxins contamination

Consequences: Transporting-reduced volumes in transit, bulking-reduced production against demand, running costs go up due to high demand for cooling and refrigeration facilities, increased perishability

Potential adaptations: Sattelite storage facilities for milk before transportation, train farmers on value addition at farm level, use of alternative energy(solar energy)

Consequences: More collection centres will be required to meet the target on the buyer because volumes per site will be low, damage to the roads are minimised, time will be used by buyers to meet the consumers leading to increase the cost of transportation, better drying for value addition activities(flour making, crisps) but in low volumes to meet the market demands

Potential adaptations: Organized bulking to specific sites with shades and cooling facilities, organized mechanized vehicles with cold storage, use of modern machineries for processing

Consequences: Shortage of feeds and water, increased cost(purchasing animal health drugs), increased refrigeration and storage requirements for drugs, increased labour requirements

Potential adaptations: Introduction of bulk camps and promoting use of aprons, bulk purchase of drugs and vaccines by community groups(livestock keepers/cooperatives), capacity building of most veterinary assistants

Consequences: Reduced levels of land preparation due to more challenges in land preparation hence increasing costs and time invested, high risks of pests and diseases, high demand for manual planing

Consequences: Transporting-less volumes transported, low volumes are bulked against demand, increased cost of production and processing facilties utilisation

Consequences: Challenges in land preparation(ploughing), delayed planting, reduced crop germination and establishment rate, low agronomic efficiency, increased pests incidence

Consequences: Low sales, increased costs of production, price fluctuations, increased milk spoilage

Consequences: Disruption of grazing time, rotational timing is affected(inbreeding), increases in disease prevalence, disease control becomes difficult due to disruptions in grazing time, low growth rates
Ongoing adaptations: Grazing early in the morning and bringing the goat late in the evening, buck is kept longr at the farm because rotation is affected, withholding the goats during vaccination and deworming
Potential adaptations: Planting browse trees such as acacia at the household level, introduce AI for meat goats, draw annual goat operational plan indicating schedules for deworming,vaccination and dipping, promoting use of aprons, water harvesting

Consequences: Inadequate availability of feed leading to long distances for grazing areas, emaciation leading to death, mortality rates for kids and adults is high, disruption and collapse of rotation system, increased pests and diseases prevalence
Ongoing adaptations: Some farmers store feeds during the dry spell, farmers sell bucks who have stayed longer in the herd, regular spraying and deworming, carrying out vaccinations as provided by the government
Potential adaptations: Farmers should be equipped with appropriate equipment for harvesting fodder and storage, draw community goat breeding plan to enhance buck rotations, scheduled mass deworming-spraying and dipping, massive vaccinations campaigns, access to early warning systems

Consequences: Delayed trainings due to diversion of funds meant for training, transportation will be affected by envisaged decreased volumes, delaying the acquisition of goats, reduced number of goats available for slaughter
Ongoing adaptations: Flaying meat cutting and hygiene is done in the traditional way, the goats are sold at the household level and therefore no transport costs, staff are utilising the skills they have at the moment
Potential adaptations: Establish economic goat collection centres with enough goats to avoid leaving the flayers empty, meat cutters and others should  be taken to KMC for training subject to successful fundraising and resource mobilisation, introduction of bulk camps

Consequences: Delayed trainings from extension services due to the dimension of funds, transportation and processing will be affected by the fluctuation in the availability of goats, low supply for bulking of goats at the dry spell begins
Ongoing adaptations: Selling goats to immediate consumers and traders in small units, farmer to farmer exchange of knowledge within neighbourhoods
Potential adaptations: Seek alternative sources of funds to carry out proper trainings, bulking of goats in large numbers to sell, promote holding facilities, seek alternative sources of funds to facilitate exchange tours to the best performing counties e.g KMC, Dagoretti, Babadogo slaughterhouses

Consequences: High labour costs, reduced quality of planting material, increased costs of agro chemicals
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are using their indigenous traditional knowledge, use of conventional improved varieties
Potential adaptations: Adoption of rainwater harvesting structures, research and development of drought tolerant varieties

Consequences: Low manure quality for composting, acquisition of suitable certified variety will be affected, inadequate stocks in the agrovets(fertilisers and other agro chemicals)
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are using their indigineous technical know how, recycling of seeds(harvested seeds), use of integrated pest management(IPM) practices
Potential adaptations: Seed bulking by farmers/organizing, KFA to stock appropriate seeds, more research on drought tolerant varieties, capacity building on IPM options, research on ICT to enhance adaptability

Consequences: Reduced farmer prices(low quality), increased trader prices due to scarcity, reduced marketing linkages, divert produce to local markets and household consumption, reduced household income
Ongoing adaptations: Aggregation of grains, farmers will be selling at farm gate
Potential adaptations: Associations to facilitate pricing/marketing, contract farming, improved rural access roads to improve supply to better markets, regulated grain pricing through government policies

Consequences: High capital required, extension service advice on early maturing crop varieties, more time consumed for technical advice, more labour is required
Ongoing adaptations: Farmer savings, access to public extension and service extension, use of family labor
Potential adaptations: Linkage with financial sources(banks), public private partnerships in extension provision, supply of clean planting materials by research institutions

Consequences: Transportation of produce will be reduced, reduced product quality and yield, increased risk of post harvest damage due to pests(rodents), reduced value addition and commercial processing opportunities
Ongoing adaptations: Low storage and packaging due to low production
Potential adaptations: Improved storage structures(pest free), promotion of community based grain aggregation centres for bulking the grains

Consequences: Land preparation- very costly, delayed land preparation, increase in pests, planting-delayed planting, poor crop germination, very expensive
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed land preparation, poor germination, costly land preparation, delayed planting, sporadic planting delayed harvesting, premature harvesting
Potential adaptations: Having heavy implements, practice zero tillage, use of herbicides early planting, dry planting harvesting, introduction of drought tolerance or early maturing variety, introduce irrigation to farmers

Consequences: Seed-lack of planting seed, high seed price, scarcity of seed, poor quality seed /fertilizer/manure
Ongoing adaptations: Relief seed distribution, supply of subsidized fertilizer by state government, farmers making their own manure, intercropping, extension services are interupted
Potential adaptations: Establish seed farms under irrigation e.g. Hola and Bura scheme for seed bulking, establish a fertilizer processing plant, farmers to be trained on compositing, organize, strategize and improve extension services through research, farmer linkages

Consequences: Limit access to produce markets due to damaged roads and high costs for riverine transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Produce hoarding to force price increases, divertion of market produce for household consumption
Potential adaptations: Collective marketing using farmer cooperatives, value addition to diversified consumer products

Consequences: Increased market costs due to scarcity of product
Ongoing adaptations: County governments buying produce from farmers
Potential adaptations: Tapping into organized markets and seeking new marketing opportunities outside the county

Consequences: Increased storage pestse.g. bruchids and weevils, diminished quantity and quality of harvested seeds
Ongoing adaptations: Storage-use of sacks, plastic, jerricans etc, bulking on the floors farmer groups bulk their produce
Potential adaptations: Improved seed storage structures, use of sisal gunny bags, use of storage chemicals, use of silos

Consequences: Lack of seeds, poor germination, washing away of seed, rotting of seed, no germination, leaching of fertiliser, washing away of manure
Ongoing adaptations: Relief seed distribution, subsidized fertiliser extension services
Potential adaptations: Land reclamation through drainage, replicate existing irrigation schemes such as Hola and Bura scheme for seed bulking, agriculture department to demonstrate training on compost on situ, use of motorized boats

Consequences: Inadequate supplies, poor quality of fruit limiting shelf life, decreasing product prices and opportunities for value addition
Ongoing adaptations: Marketing of fruit on niche markets(for juice)
Potential adaptations: Value addition, strengthen cooperatives to add value to products and of alternative niche markets(for non ripe mangoes), international market linkages

Consequences: Loss of tree flowers, pests incidences, disease damage and fruit bursts at fruiting stage, loss of fertilizer and pesticides through runoff and leaching
Ongoing adaptations: Stopped application of fertilisers and pesticides, on farm diversification, seeking alternative means of livelihood
Potential adaptations: Drainage canals

Consequences: Shelf life reduced pest increase(fruit fly), reduced quality and quantity of harvested fruits
Ongoing adaptations: Sun drying of harvested fruit either under trees or in storage sheds, value addition only minimal (juice making)
Potential adaptations: Low temperature storage facilities, mango processing e.g domestic or commercial drying

Consequences: Damage to existing roads hinder fruit transportation to markets and increase transportation costs, low fruit quality lower fruit purchase costs
Ongoing adaptations: Maximise on family labour to harvest and ferry mangoes to collection points, use any mode of available transport e.g lorries, buses, maximise price negotiations within existing informal market standards
Potential adaptations: Use of boats(speed) for consolidation, use of refrigerated trucks to transport ripe mangoes to the market, establishment of niche specialty markets for non ripe mangoes

Consequences: Loss of crop produce through rotting/sprouting/germination of harvested seed
Ongoing adaptations: Use of jerricans and gunny bags  to store seeds no grading, repair and reinforcement of food storage facilities
Potential adaptations: Improved grain storage facilities

Consequences: Hinder access to orchard fields, low fruit quality from damages incurred at harvest and damaged storage structures
Ongoing adaptations: Mangoes are stored in houses and homelands before sale, sorting/grading of fruits
Potential adaptations: Build special places/stores, use of four wheel vehicles e.g landcruiser, sorting, grading and proper packaging

Consequences: Hinders access to nursery inputs, poor seedling establishment in waterlogged soils
