Ongoing adaptations: Seedlings are raised in homesteads away from the flood prone zones, source seedlings from outside suppliers
Potential adaptations: Establish central community nurseries, promote grafting

Consequences: Low yields, poor quality, susceptibility to pests and diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Unplanned/incidental pruning  at the wrong time of the year/seasonal cycle, agroforestry, water harvesting, tree planting, on farm diversification, alternative means of livelhoods
Potential adaptations: Pruning at the right duration within the seasonal cycle, use of IPM

Consequences: Stunted growth and susceptibility to pests and diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Destocking of weak and old goats, use of indegenous knowledge to treat animal diseases, animal migration to other communal pasture lands, seek alternative means of livelihood e.g employment
Potential adaptations: Creation of disease-free zones, research for newly emerging diseases, introduction of new superior breeds

Consequences: Contributes to premature crop harvesting, increase likelihood of storage pests, increase processing costs for mills repairs due to processing of premature seeds
Ongoing adaptations: Storage-renovation of stores, transport-alternative transport means, processing-greasing of machines and repairs
Potential adaptations: Renovation and expansion of stores, relocation of stores, diversity transport means for alternative uses, put processing machines to alternative uses, import raw materials

Consequences: Increased risk mortality during transportation, poor quality increases meat processing costs
Ongoing adaptations: Off takes, culling of old and weak goats, feed conservation
Potential adaptations: Abbatoirs at accessible points, community based cold storage facilities

Consequences: Reduced use of high quality soil fertility inputs like farmyard manure
Ongoing adaptations: Home seed nurseries; either tree or vegetable nurseries with minimal use of pesticides and selective mulching
Potential adaptations: Training on integrated pest and management (IPM), water conservation structures e.g. zai pit technology, basin construction

Consequences: Wilting and flower abortion, reduced crop yields /crop failure
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers prepare their farms with the use of their traditional farm tools(hoes), use of tractors and ox plough, farmers are growing crops through irrigation using generator water pumps, farmers selects the pesticides then spray by themselves, extension services by GOK and NGOs
Potential adaptations: Promotion of the conservation agriculture tools and implements(planters and subsoilers), use of cheap land preparation by use of oxen, pursuing the use of solar powered irrigation system, training farmers on modern irrigation methods, more trainings should be done to the farmers on the use of IPM

Consequences: Increased mortality risk during transportation to external markets
Ongoing adaptations: Selling goats within the community, slaughter for household consumption
Potential adaptations: Construction of modern abbatoirs, capacity building on meat grading and value addition

Consequences: Delayed land preparation and planting, increased agronomic labour costs(planting, weeding), seed and seedling losses from water logging and rotting
Ongoing adaptations: Early seed and biomass harvesting, agroforestry, water conservation techniques, cover crops, on farm diversification
Potential adaptations: Drainage structures

Consequences: Shift focus from identifying markets and value addition opportunities
Ongoing adaptations: Participation in animal off take programmes, meat sales to local markets
Potential adaptations: NA

Consequences: Land preparation-delayed land preparation, recess flood planting, increased incidence of seed and seedling rotting
Ongoing adaptations: Early crop and biomass harvesting, on farm diversification, seeks alternative means of livelihoods
Potential adaptations: Reclaim land and build dykes, enact policies/by laws to adress floods, reclaiming by drainage, early harvesting, farmers should do timely planting, proper storage to avoid aflatoxins

Consequences: Low income, loss of potential markets and market linkages
Ongoing adaptations: Selling at the existing market prices and sale of produce at farm gate price
Potential adaptations: Contract farming opportunities

Consequences: Poor pasture establishment, lower pasture quality
Ongoing adaptations: Migration of livestock to other pasture land, tree planting and agroforestry species
Potential adaptations: Communal pasture lands along waterbodies such as river Tana

Consequences: Vet drugs-increased costs of treatment, inaccessibility of extension services due to poor road network, reduced quality and quantity of pastures
Ongoing adaptations: Rangeland reseeding and pasture germination
Potential adaptations: Flood mitigation practices, research for new emerging diseases and parasites, new technologies of reporting diseases on site new technologies on pasture production e.g tumbukiza, community protected pasture lands

Consequences: Goat prices-low prices due to high supply, farmers dispose their livestock at throw away prices, quality of end products-low quality meat and quantity
Ongoing adaptations: Value addition through alternative meat programmes, slaughter for household or local consumption
Potential adaptations: Transportation of goats and goat products to outside markets and counties, contract marketing, access credits from financial institutions, linkage to market information services

Consequences: Increased prevalence in animal diseases like CCPP, drowning of animals-loss of livelihoods, increased husbandry costs such as hoof trimming
Ongoing adaptations: Destocking of weak and old goats, use of indegenous knowledge to treat animal diseases, animal migration to other communal pasture lands, seek alternative means of livelihood eg employment
Potential adaptations: Disease tolerant and climate-adapted goat breeds

Consequences: Low prices, low incomes to the farmer, limited access to the market due to bad roads
Ongoing adaptations: Pricing-farmers sell at existing market prices, transport-farmers bear the transport cost alone, harvested produce majorly consumed at household level
Potential adaptations: Sorting and grading, looking for market opportunity and market survey farming, commercial groups for collective marketing and share the transport cost

Consequences: Loss of seeds, increased budget for pesticides, tools
Ongoing adaptations: Seeds-farmers lose their seeds during floods and buy seeds from other sources
Potential adaptations: Building seed stores, provide subsidized seeds.

Consequences: Lack of seeds for planting in the subsequent season, pest population increases increasing the cost and usage of pesticides
Ongoing adaptations: Seeds-government distribute seeds, NGOs distribute seeds to farmers within the county, pesticides-provision of pesticide by GOK, NGOs
Potential adaptations: Training farmers on seed bulking and banking, farmers to be trained on income sharing to buy seeds at a critical time, training farmers on organic farming e.g intercropping, rotational cropping and conservation, farmers should empowered to use modern tools for conservation agriculture

Consequences: Storage-rotting of maize, aflatoxin attack, total loss transport-difficulty in transport, becomes expensive, becomes a risky business
Ongoing adaptations: Storage-treatment of stores/repairing, relocation transporting
Potential adaptations: Stores to be built on higher grounds, story build stores, water resistant stores

Consequences: Fast drying of pods, shattering of some pods, likelihood of attack by termites, fast rate of threshing, easy wastage due to weight loss
Ongoing adaptations: Shade drying under trees, brief storage in sacks before sales at market
Potential adaptations: Use of tarpaulins to dry pods and provide shade, use of raised stores for drying, use of tarpaulins and threshing machines, use of hermetic bags, silos and improved warehouses, promote use of moisture metres to enhance storage

Consequences: The chicken meat will spoil at a higher rate, high costs for cold storage, discoloring of meat before and during grading
Ongoing adaptations: Slaughtering at night or early in the morning, storing in cold water, using nylon bags and plastics for transportation, dipping transportation sacks in the cold water. Use of ice for cooling and cooler boxes
Potential adaptations: Use of modern slaughter houses at local level, use of modern packing materials, use of modern storing facilities like freezers, capacity building on special vehicles with coolers for transportation, use of licenced meat transport containers, insuring the product, more training on meat handling

Consequences: Restricted movements hence brokers take advantage and exploit the farmers, reduced income, increased transportation cost
Ongoing adaptations: Travelling to market point to inquire on the market prices, use of cellphones to ask for prices, use of donkeys and women to carry produce to the markets, use brokers who come for products at home, use tin as measuring instrument instead of weighing machines
Potential adaptations: Farmers to form groups/cooperatives for marketing/better returns, media involvement to inform farmers of prices, use of IT to get information, use of aggregation for collection, cooperative to purchase means of transport to ferry products to the centres, use of moisture meters, use of digital weighing machines, use of legislative framework

Consequences: Reduced labour and delayed preparation of land, delayed planting and decreased viability of seeds, increased water requirements, crop wilting
Ongoing adaptations: Use of integrated pest, weed and disease management, working(planting and weeding) in the morning and in the evening, seed broadcasting during ploughing, intercropping
Potential adaptations: Minimum tillage and use of herbicides, dig holes for planting, mechanized planting, use of shallow weeders, integrated weed management

Consequences: Poor hygiene, slow process of defeathering, reduced quality and quantity of meat and eggs, reduced shelf life, high spoilage rates
Ongoing adaptations: Reusing the same water, defeathering without water hence low quality, removing with bare hands, destocking(slaughtering and sales of whole stock)
Potential adaptations: Use of modern defeathering machines, have permanent supply of water and electricity, construction modern slaughter houses and machines for removing internal organs, invest in modern plucking, weighing, grading and labelling equipment

Consequences: Reduced demand of certified seeds, reduced purchase of agro chemicals
Ongoing adaptations: Borrow seeds from neighbours and friends, seed recycling and purchase from open markets, exchange of seeds, cultural methods of treating seeds, use of untreated/uncertified seeds
Potential adaptations: Formation of cooperatives to provide seeds to farmers on credit, subsidize/donation of certified seeds by government or NGOs, introduction of cover crops, introduce community based seed bulking

Consequences: Slow growth rate of chickens, increase in diseases, increased needs and costs for veterinary care, increased costs related to provision of feed and water
Ongoing adaptations: Use of traditional herbs(aloe spp and pepper) to treat chickens, use of growth promoters
Potential adaptations: Have policy to regulate poultry health, capacity building on improved health management, train farmers on appropriate vaccination regimes

Consequences: Low yields, poor quality produce, easier storage and processing, reduced incidence of fungal diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Use of storage chemicals to reduce post harvest losses, mortar and pestle for grinding, home consumption
Potential adaptations: Use of hermetic storage bags, establishment of aggregation centres, use of digital weighing machines for bulk sales, use of moisture meters to reduce storage losses

Consequences: Decline in milk quality and quantity, increase in cost of handling and transportation, increased spoilage of milk
Ongoing adaptations: Training cooperative and groups that have coolers, improving on milking hygiene, group sharing of costs for use of cold storage facilities
Potential adaptations: Expanding cooling facilities at collection centres, adopting value addition on milk to increase income, improvement of roads to ease transportation introduction of government policy to reduce cooling electricity charges

Consequences: Difficult in land tilling(extra labour and costs in breaking of hard pans), delayed land preparation, strained/ delayed planting, wilting, poor germination rates
Ongoing adaptations: Delayed tilling until rain starts, reduce area of land planting, early planting/dry planting, use of conservation agriculture practices(minimum tillage, intercropping), mulching with other crops residue
Potential adaptations: Introduction of sub-soilers and rippers to improve seed planting environment, scaling up and capacity building on conservation agriculture, water harvesting

Consequences: Lower supply to market, reduced transportation costs, high demand
Ongoing adaptations: Use of cellphones to contact traders, visit to markets during market days with samples, use of donkeys, motorbikes and women backs for transport, use of tins and spring balance as measuring instruments
Potential adaptations: Use cooperatives to set prices and search for marketing, use of media to look for market, use of pick ups and lorries to transport, use of digital weighing machine, promote contract farming, formation of producer/marketing groups

Consequences: Decrease in goat feeds which translates to poor health of the goats hence increased demand for drugs, reduction in pasture, vulnerability to diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Feed supplementation and fodder production and storage, use of crop residue for feed
Potential adaptations: Training on supplementary feeding, farmers to keep improved breeds that are resilient to heat and diseases, dissemination of feed formulation technologies and information

Consequences: The chicks will have heat stress leading to death of chicken/affected growth, coops constructed using iron sheets get very hot, increased pests and diseases, increased water requirements
Ongoing adaptations: Use local materials for reducing temperatures e.g glass, use of locally available materials e.g banana leaves, use of traditional herbs e.g pepper and aloe vera to treat chicken
Potential adaptations: Train farmers on construction of improved(ventilated and temperature regulating) enclosures, use of modern thermostats to detect changes in temperature, use of temperature regulating brooders, adopt the vaccination regime by the breeders

Consequences: Decline in fodder and hay, high cost of feeds and supplements, increased vet health care requirements
Ongoing adaptations: Storing and conserving pastures and fodder, use of crop residues as feed, use of kitchen wastes on feeding the animals
Potential adaptations: Keeping high quality breeds that are heat tolerant, training on breed selection and fodder production, purchase of feed mixers for on farm feed production and rationing

Consequences: Reduction in ordering demands of certified seeds, reduction in demand of agro chemicals, increased spoilage of seeds
Ongoing adaptations: Recycle the seeds, purchase from open markets, borrowing from friends, use of traditional ways of agro-chemicals, use of organic manure, no use of agrochemicals
Potential adaptations: Formation of farmer cooperatives to provide certified seeds on credit, introduction of cover crops, introduce community based seed bulking, table banking, formation of agrovets in cooperatives, use integrated pest management, use of resistant varieties and early maturing varieties, capacity building and research

Consequences: Lack of capacity for farmers to purchase drugs, increase in demand for the drugs due to poor conditions of the goats, poor quality and low quantites of pasture, scarcity of water
Ongoing adaptations: Setting up of agrovet shops in the rural areas, feed supplementation, preservation of crop residues in small scale in the upper and middel part of the county, encroaching gazetted lands e.g hills, forests and game parks
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on supplementation, fodder conservation and preservation, construction of hay banks, introduction of drought tolerant fodder materials, step up extension service provision, commercialize pasture production, controlled grazing

Consequences: Low prices, fewer buyers, low returns, low market prices/returns to the farmers as a result of poor body conditions
Ongoing adaptations: Introduction of cooperatives to help to stabilise market prices, farmer groups formed, individual farmer negotiation with buyers in livestock market centres, set days for livestock markets, open air marketing, off taking of livestock by ministry of livestock
Potential adaptations: Enhance capacity of the cooperatives on pricing, introduce weighing of animals during selling/buying, policy and legislative frameworks which are farmer friendly, establish contract goat farming

Consequences: Low milk production, increased susceptibilty to pests and diseases resulting in increased animal health management costs
Ongoing adaptations: Vaccination of animals by government, introduction of alternative fodders(oats, vetch and desmodium)
Potential adaptations: Promote water harvesting for livestock, improved livestock health management, investing in weather resistant dairy enclosures

Consequences: Unreliable supply of milk to the market, decline in high quality milk supply
Ongoing adaptations: Formation of milk marketing cooperatives, sales in the local market with minimum value addition
Potential adaptations: Collective marketing through cooperatives, enforce contract marketing and supply accessing credit facilities for milk cooling facilities

Consequences: Reduction of milk supply, decline in milk quality due to feeding in low quality dry matter
Ongoing adaptations: Pooled transportation of milk, sales at local market
Potential adaptations: Policy intervention on milk supply fluctuations, contract milk marketing, subsidizing animal feed supply to farmers by cooperatives, improved access to affordable credit

Consequences: Decline in volume of feed rations to the market, low fertility and reproduction rates, low weight gain
Ongoing adaptations: Diversification of feed ration ingredients from different sources, on farm feed formulation of dairy rations, use of locally available materials for construction of low cost shaded enclosures, long term planned construction for efficient dairy herd management
Potential adaptations: Formation of new feed ration technologies, accessing affordable credit for construction of efficient housing, routine animal health practices and disease/pest control

Consequences: Loss of animals during transportation. Increased cost of transportation less slaughtering activity due to the poor quality of meat and meat products. Poor health of the goats also can translate to poor quality skin
Ongoing adaptations: Introduction of livestock market at the locations level to reduce stress as a result of long walking distance slaughter facilities for local market. Meat inspection by qualified persons from county government. Additional value for external markets non existent of bulking sites than the markets. Largely traders buy directly from the market
Potential adaptations: Introduce bulking sites for improved transportaation through cooperatives capacity building of farmers on supplementary feeds and value addition of meat and meat products. Construct more modern slaughter houses in the local villages/centres creation of marketing/bulking sites. Capacity building of farmers on importance of bulking. Strengthen cooperatives

Consequences: Slow growth rate of the chicks, the prices of feeds will increase, high demand for vaccines resulting in shortages
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local ingredients to supplement feed, use of traditional feeds
Potential adaptations: Improved breed development and selection, constuction of feed factory

Consequences: Decline milk quality due to feeding on low quality dry matter, high cost of transport and handling due to prevailing dusty conditions which leads to milk contamination
Ongoing adaptations: Supplementing dairy cow feeds, pooled transport of milk by farmers, improvement of rural access roads, investment on milk cooling facilities forming farmer organisations to create synergy and lower overhead costs, create partnership with development partners
Potential adaptations: Invest in efficient dairy breeds, fodder and pasture conservation, investment in road infrastructure and milk storage construction of standard and sustainalble large scale milk storage facilities, training on milk handling and storage

Consequences: Lower prices for chickens and eggs due to lower quality
Ongoing adaptations: Local household consumption, sales at local market
Potential adaptations: Use of specialised poultry transport vehicles, contract chicken farming, linking chicken farmers to suppliers

Consequences: Low prices/returns to farmers, demotivation of farmers due to low prices, unstable markets, change of enterprises from goat farming
Ongoing adaptations: Individual negotiations with traders during marketing, some farmers sell during the peak price periods, animals sold in open air market by individual farmers, exploitation by middlemen
Potential adaptations: Capacity build of cooperatives and individuals on price determination/negotiations, enhanced policy/legislative framework for policy determination, establish goat marketing centres in different locations

Consequences: Decline in amount of fodder and hay, decline in milk supply with increase in demand
Ongoing adaptations: Fodder conservation during high supply season, use of farm residue and by products, use of supplement feeds, increasing area under pasture and fodder, use of efficient breed, subsidized AI services by county government, use of dairy bulls in some areas
Potential adaptations: Invest in drought tolerant fodder, enforce conservation agriculture for dairy production, commercialization of pasture production, application of climate smart agriculture techniques, introduction of high quality pastures and fodder seeds, expanding of AIservices by dairy organisations, intensify extension services and  capacity building on AI providers

Consequences: Increase in housing cost due to modification of the housing units, poor health of the goats, low reproduction, increased cost of animal husbandry
Ongoing adaptations: Storage of crop residue for feeding during dry spell, grazing in protected areas, use of local indigenous knowledge/traditional medicines, farmers buying drugs and administering themselves
Potential adaptations: Introduce storage structures for the pasture, capacity building on supplementary feeding, introduction of agro ecologically adaptable feeds, capacity building on livestock management and stock control, scaling up the extension services, water harvesting for livestock

Consequences: The day old chicks are stressed and this may cause massive death and poor health of the chicks, reduced availability and increased cost of feeds, spoilage of vaccines
Ongoing adaptations: On arival of the chicks they are given multivitamins, glucose and liquid paraffin, use of traditional herbs e.g aloe vera, feeding the chicks on locally available feeds e.g millet, improvising on cooling materials e.g use of saw dust and grass in brooding enclosure
Potential adaptations: Development of local feed formulation enterprises, use of modern incubators, improved breed development and selection, promote electric ventilation e.g(fans)

Consequences: Reduced income for farmers, reduced shelf life of meat and eggs
Ongoing adaptations: Local household consumption, transport using small cages with a few birds, sales at local poultry sale yards, night time transporting
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on marketing, procurement of special poultry transport vehicles, establish contract farming, increase number of shaded poultry yards

Consequences: Transport costs likely to increase due to lack of buyers due to weak animals, low quality and quantity, reduced market value
Ongoing adaptations: Walking animals to  the market, transport using motorbikes, slaughter houses for local markets, inspection of meat after slaughter
Potential adaptations: Enhancing capacity of cooperatives to bulk and transport, capacity building on value addition of meat and meat products, capacity building on value addition of goat meat

Consequences: Expansion of shelter due to increased heat and to avoid overcrowding may lead to the farmer incurring extra costs, reduced feeds and water availability and could make the animals vulnerable to diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Introduction of housing units for goats, storage of crop residue for feeding during the dry spell, grazing in protected areas, use of local indigenous knowledge/medicines, farmers buying drugs and administering themselves with their basic knowledge on animal health
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on importance of housing/shelters for the goats, introduction of supplementary feeds, pasture conservation and preservation, introduction of agro ecological friendly feed materials, capacity building on feed management, capacity building on disease surveillance, scaling up the extension services, availability of drugs

Consequences: Affects decision making in site selection, high cost of feeds due to impassable roads and high cost of transportation
Ongoing adaptations: Acquiring land in the higher areas as opposed to lower areas, use of seeds that have high tolerance to excessive rainfall, use of organic/ indigenous available pesticides e.g. pepper and wood ash
Potential adaptations: Water pan construction on the farms to harvest excess rainfall, scale up into varieties of seeds that are tolerant to excess rainfall, upscaling on the use of organic pesticides

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Affects decision making whether to acquire land due to unpredictable rainfall patterns, reduced sales for agro-dealers and farmers
Ongoing adaptations: Diversity to other crop enterprises, use of recycled seeds by farmers, use of indigenous technical knowledge e.g use of ash, pepper
Potential adaptations: Adopt use of weather advisory from meteorological department, adopting weather information sharing platforms and technologies e.g Yara weather mobile app, met platform, get accurate regular weather updates

Consequences: Reduced selling prices due to poor quality, and reduced market volumes leading to an increase in price for consumers, reduced access to market with weather roads, increased transportation costs, reduced sales due to excess rainfall, interference with market centers' activities
Ongoing adaptations: Increase labor in sorting and grading to fetch good prices, incase of low prices the farmer recyles seeds from previous season, farmers sell to other farmers or middle men to reduce cost of transportation, selling at farm gate, use of modern market stalls by traders
Potential adaptations: Diversification of beans varieties to take to market, adopt digital marketing and cooperatives platforms to link with consumers, prior market survey on the needs of consumers before production, marketing through cooperatives

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Unpredictable market trends, loss of contracts especially if supplying to institutions, inability to honour the contract with buyers
Ongoing adaptations: Pricing information sharing between farmer to farmer through social medial and market places, information sharing between farmers, sourcing beans from other markets, planting beans in two seasons to get more for selling
Potential adaptations: Beans pricing should be included in county policies, use of digital platforms in quoting prices of bean produce, formulation of cooperatives to help set prices, use of cooperatives to link buyers and farmers, enhanced extension services and formation of cooperatives to link farmers to buyers, increase acreage in planting season and bean varieties, capacity building to farmers/traders on varieties of beans which can cope with uncertainities

Consequences: It causes soil compactness and soil erosion that leads to high cost of land preparation i.e increase in labour and machinery cost, high incidences of pests and diseases, high cost of labour and application of pesticides, high cost of labour during planting
Ongoing adaptations: Ploughling along contours, ploughing only during dry season to reduce surface run off, practice dry planting, hiring more labour and spreading tarpaulin during harvesting
Potential adaptations: Construction of terraces, adapting to weather advisories from weather forecasters

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Uncertainity in the time for land preparation, delayed land preparation and poorly prepared land, incase of early rainfall onset farmers are not well prepared for planting, planning of planting activities becomes difficult, prolonged dry spell lead to delay in seed germination, interference with harvesting calendar and prolonged rainy season leads to beans rotting and reduced yields
Ongoing adaptations: Waiting until the rainy season starts, dry planting, use of organic manure for planting, planting in two seasons, hiring of more labour during harvesting, spreading in storage structures and cover with tarpulin
Potential adaptations: Liase with weather/extension service providers on appropriate time for land preparation, encourage planting on second season, monocropping for beans, planting short season's bean varieties, use of extension advisory for timely farm operations

Consequences: High cost of transportation and labour, poor road accessibility from the farm, rotting  of the beans, difficulty in threshing due to high moisture content, it reduces the quality of produce, high labor costs, extended drying periods, high losses due to rotting/spoilage
Ongoing adaptations: Use of animal draft power, construction of drainage channels, hiring more labour, spreading in a storage structure to reduce moisture content, sorting of grains, storing using hermatic bags until the weather changes, sorting and grading
Potential adaptations: Government should construct all weather roads with good drainage system to facilitate transportation even during excess rainfall, adopt current technology for threshing and winnowing beans e.g threshing machines, use of seed driers machineries and modern grain/cereal storage facilities to increase seed shell life

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Change post-harvest calendar, interfere with transport planning, interference with plant operation for threshing and winnowing, storage facilities may not be in place- prolonged wet season affects drying and storage
Ongoing adaptations: Use of draft power for farming, use of manual labour to transport from farm, use of tarpaulins during threshing and winnowing, use of spacious storage structure for threshing, hire more labour, use of sun drying for drying beans, increase labour for drying
Potential adaptations: Liasing with weather advisories service providers in post-harvesting activities planning, use of modern technology for threshing and winnowing, use of modern technology for drying and storage e.g solar driers, grain storage stores

Consequences: Seasonal roads become impassable leading to difficulty in accessing farms thus causing delay in service delivery, cycle loss and waste of production calendar for dairy farmer and high cost of production due to repeat breeding and longer breeding calendar, inadequate feeds due to destruction of forage and pasture lands by floods leading to scarcity of raw materials, unfavourable weather conditions for feed preservation
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers using private service providers who are locally available, open up water ways and drainage to direct floods away from farms, make use of locally available service providers, some cooperatives have dairy hubs offering extension services
Potential adaptations: Having own kits on farm level for easy access and quality assurance, more cooperatives to adopt extension through dairy cooperatives, evacuate or dig dams to drain water from flooded areas, plan to relocate the population near river banks and in low lying areas away from flood prone areas, link to digital platforms for extension or online information, encourage infusion of dairy hubs at producer organizations and cooperatives to offer extension services

Consequences: Heat stress limits the animal exhibitions of oestrus signs making the farmer lose that cycle and need for more repeat breeding, limited feeds to maintain the body physiological hemostasis and functionality, moisture stress leads to inadequacy or limited access to raw materials leading to high cost of feeds and feed scarcity
Ongoing adaptations: Housing the animals to mitigate heat stress effects, planting suitable varieties for silage making (rhode grass),hay production and stocking in anticipation of drought, extension services- through field days as extension is demand-driven due to lean staff, field days deliver the extension services closer to the farmers
Potential adaptations: Research on suitable breeds and breeding programs that will be successful despite heat stress, research on suitable nutritional feeds that can go all seasons e.g bracharia spp. for fodder, capacity building for farmers to encourage adopting of technologies for on-farm feed formulation and preservation, link farmers to online extension plaforms that are in existence or create more where lacking, have more media extension services through radio, TV, and other channels

Consequences: Physical movement for milk and milk products promotion is hampered during flooding, gatherings during flooding create room for promoting dairy products, floods cut off products from the markets, losses due to high perishability of milk
Ongoing adaptations: Use of extension forums such as field days to promote their products, use of charitable organizations or activities to promote their products e.g donations, selling at local market, use of available transport means to deliver the products to market centers, bringing products closer to the buyers
Potential adaptations: Invest on electronic and digital platforms for promotion, enhance use of local extension forums such as field days, local markets, lobby for repair of impassable roads that are hindering suppy of products to the market, sell products to local market, invest on transportation modes to deliver products to buyers

Consequences: Inadequate products to be promoted, inability to meet market demand for the product due to shortage during moisture stress, higher prices for the scarce commodity
Ongoing adaptations: Preservation of milk during peak periods to sell during scarcity, get milk from other sources so as to meet the target, link with other producers to get enough according to demand, purchasing milk from other areas during shortage to meet market demand and maintain customers
Potential adaptations: Invest more in milk preservation to have products for promotion in the future or during scarcity, invest in milk preservation equipment and expand their capacity on value addition to prolong milk shelf life for sale during shortage, re-negotiating on contracts to avoid penalties during shortage

Consequences: Leads to scarcity of feeds for livestock due to destruction of pasture lands and fodder crops, leads to increase of biting flies that are vectors of diseases, likelihood of disease outbreaks increases such as rift valley fever, floods may lead to displacement of both farmer and livestock due to destruction of farm structures
Ongoing adaptations: Opening up drainage and water ways to direct floods away from farms, preserve feeds before onset of flooding, plant crops not easily carried away by floods, stock on high grounds, vaccination prior to outbreak, spray insect breeding sites to reduce biting insect population, partial or temporary relocation to higher camping sites like schools, de-silting of existing dams, early warning systems and advisories by relevant departments
Potential adaptations: Dig dams to store excess water for future use, relocate people from flood prone areas, upscale the draining of flooded areas, planting suitable fodder crops, sinking of dams in high flooding areas, relocation of occupants to higher grounds, construction of dykes, encourage adherence to early warning systems and weather advisors, upscale awareness creation and adoption of technologies on disease control, review existing policies and regulations on disease control, enroll and implement prevention and control strategies prior predisposing hazard occurrences

Consequences: During prolonged drought, there will be inadequate feeds for livestock feeding and increased feeds prices, decrease in pasture quality due to moisture stress, moisture stress makes disease control difficult due to the illegal movement of animals from various places in search of feeds, reduced volumes to be milked, reduced workload for farm laborers
Ongoing adaptations: Use of locally available residues e.g maize stovers during dry season, conserving feeds through silage, hay making and stocking, prevention and control strategies in place e.g livestock vaccination, downsizing farm labour during moisture stress and uptake of farm mechanization to reduce labour cost
Potential adaptations: Upscaling onfarm feeding formulation, preservation/conservation technologies, planting drought resistant fodder crops such as sorghum for feeding during moisture stress periods, come up with new policies and regulations to ensure enforcement of livestock movement control, and create or upscale awareness on livestock vaccination importance, small scale farmers should invest in farm mechanization while large scale farmers should upscale to use of milling machines

Consequences: Impassable roads causes difficulties in accessing bulking sites thus spoilage of milk, loss of produce and delay in delivery of milk to end users, loss of manpower due to accidents, wear and tear thus increasing transportation costs
Ongoing adaptations: Use of temporal mitigation strategies e.g filling gunny bags with sand to bridge impassable roads into the bulking and storage centers, use of readily available modes of transportation that can manage the poor roads, using alternative modes to deliver milk to the collection centers
Potential adaptations: Invest on alternative modes of transport that will aid in delivering milking to bulking and storage centers in time, lobby on upgrading rural impassable roads to make transportation easier, using readily available modes of transportation, processors to take own initiatives in collaborating with government to repair their feeder roads affected by floods

Consequences: Moisture stress reduces milk production, therefore, less quantity available during bulking and storage thus increasing costs, during prolonged drougt the volume of milk production drops, therefore quantity available for transportation is less thus increasing transport costs
Ongoing adaptations: Improving genetics of their livestock to ensure enough milk to be bulked, make use of dry feeding to maintain or have constant production for bulking, bulking and transporting as group/cooperatives to utilize economies of scale,  make use of  cost-effective means of transport during scarcity e.g motorcycles, mobilize and contract more farmers to ensure enough quantities for processing, making of powdered milk for use during shortage
Potential adaptations: Upscalling technologies to improve/ ensure constant production across the season, use of cost effective energy sources e.g solar for cooling, uUpscale the use of cost-effective means of transport, upscale farmer recruitment to ensure quantities for processing, invest more in preservation equipment for excess milk during peak season

Consequences: Poor hatchability affecting one day old chicks supply, high cost of required material for feed formulation, ineffective vaccines resulting from transporting and poor handling leading vaccine viability loss, flock losses due to disease outbreak
Ongoing adaptations: Improve self hatch by manual provision of moisture, farmers resort to buying chicks at older stages than one day chicks, and increase the number of hatcheries, incubators donated to farmer groups and indvidual farmers, source cheaper raw materials from Uganda, use of type cereals "Mwoze maize", free-range rearing, grow own crops to do own feed formulation using farm byproducts, resorted to traditional methods using herbs, ice packs for farmers doing self vaccination and other traditional methods like herbs
Potential adaptations: Capacity building for farmers at different input levels e.g egg picking and handling, use of incubators, used hatcheries, provision of solar powered incubators to reduce cost of electricity and fuel even large scale, opportunity for serial bulking to be used during dry season, formulation of policies that favour farmers strengthen the cold chain and capacity building for farmers

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Increased prices of feeds due to how supply of raw materials, low egg supply due to poor feeding of layers- high cost of eggs leading to high cost of chicks, expensive feeds, high cost of production
Ongoing adaptations: Growing of crops for own raw materials, sourcing cheaper options e.g Uganda market, use fo solar powered incubators on small scale, ITK (self hatch practices) e.g using local breed- syncronization hatching, selection of good breeding flock avoiding in-breeding, use of vaccination schedule
Potential adaptations: Capacity bulking on staggered hatching, invest in farmers being able to pick up business with support technically and economically, engage farmers to grow early maturing varieties on contract farming and stock for future use, enforcing quality policy making and use to protect farmers from exploitation, cooler and cold chain at producer level to strengthen cold chain and opportunity for employment for youth and women to technically support farmers

Consequences: Loss at transportation, low chicken demand and low sales, increased costs of advertising and promotion, low bargaing power for farmers, less profit realized
Ongoing adaptations: Farming farmer groups to improve market access, joining social media platforms like M-shamba, poultry farmers WhatsApp groups, farming of common interest groups, joining producer organizations, and improved fast maturing breeds, improved breeds, improved feeding options, and group marketing
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on sustainable production by staggering ages of growth to have chicken throughout the year, strengthen capacity of producer organizations to meet farmer needs, strengthen producer organizations capacity, embrace new ways of marketing platforms e.g WhatsApp business, Facebook, and market groups support and fund farmers bench marking for motivation and eye opening opportunity to do poultry for business

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Affects bargaining power due to poor slaughter weight, products not competetitive fetching low prices thus low profits for farmers
Ongoing adaptations: Group marketing, wholesale pricing average for entire flock, alternative sources of income, and improved breeds
Potential adaptations: Strengthen the capacity of producer organizations, put up poultry hubs to cater for whole value chain, capacity building on financial literacy and contract farming for poultry farmers, support the improved breeds, capacity building and avail poultry insurance, support producer organizations to work hard in hand with farmers

Consequences: Readily available on farm and durable housing material, extreme temperatures are labour intensive for control of temperature, poor feeding and reduced production of eggs, lower feed uptake affecting growth rate
Ongoing adaptations: Use of adjustable canvas curtains on airspaces to moderate temperatures, increase in number of drinking cointainers available for chicks to ensure hydration, use of semi-intensive methods like a protected run (where chicks come in and out), free range, supplimentations from kitchen waste, use of whole grains, traditional practices/ indigenous technical knowledge (ITK), limit visitors to chicken houses or use of foot baths, use of information technology(IT) to obtain information and technical advice from experts, capacity building by the ministry and other organizations
Potential adaptations: Technology for use of solar powered fans and capacity building for production, on farm feed formulation, promote proper feed mills and mixers capacity building, development and implemetation of vaccination program

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Missed opportunity on construction and improvement of housing structures- farmers not sure it will work, high cost of production with increased feed prices, cannibalism due to not enough feeds
Ongoing adaptations: Being in touch with on farm information givers, use weather advisories to make decisions, use of home made feed variations and some for cheaper readily available feeds and raw materials, diversification to other business
Potential adaptations: Introduce solar powered fans and capacity building on housing and production, embrace technology for alternative feeds like hydroponics and capacity building, observe biosecurity measures

Consequences: Decreased egg production due to stress, spoilage at bulking of eggs due to high temperatures, losses during transportation, increased preservation and transport costs
Ongoing adaptations: Use of amino acids and vitamins, use of egg boosting supplements in feed and drinking water, capacity building on egg collection and storage, keeping produce in cooler places in the home and improving ventilation, using cages to transport and use of crates
Potential adaptations: Facilitating the producer organizations with coolers and adequate or proper bulking space for both eggs, live chicken or processed meat

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Reduced egg production and reduced profits, low volumes makes transportation expensive, poor slaughter weight and low prices
Ongoing adaptations: Learn other feeding methods, joining Common Interest Groups (CIGs), resort to wholesale average prices on a flock
Potential adaptations: Use of hydroponics and vermiculture technologies, capacity building on proper feeding and nutrition programs, identify breeds for business e.g sasso kuroiler for weight

Consequences: Lender with holds release of funds, economic loss due to reduced leasing, cost of leasing land goes down, input prices especially fertilizers reduce (positive for farmers), changes in seed variety usage thus affecting output, low demand for maize inputs
Ongoing adaptations: Use last season's produce as capital and leasing part of own land to generate captial, advance leasing of land by farmers, price reduction by agro dealers, provision of extension services by agrodealers as after sale services, adoption of drought tolerant seeds and early maturing seeds, government subsidies
Potential adaptations: Advancement of low interest loans to farmers, crop insurance, promote use of climate smart agricultural practices, adoption of conservation agriculture, enhance research on suitable seed varieties e.g GMO, enhance home made manure preparation and application, use of slow release fertilizers

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Lenders with hold funds, farmers redirect funds to other uses, economic loss due to leasing/ re-leasing due to uncertainities, excess leasing by land owners leaving them with no land for farming
Ongoing adaptations: Farmers are seeking alternative sources of capital, the farmer leases land, joining farmers' producer organizations, production of on-farm manure, and reducing the rate of inorganic fertilizer application
Potential adaptations: Warehouses receipt system, subsidies by government agencies, formation of producer organizations for maize value chain, soil conservation structure maintenance, own farm manure preparation, farmers savings- embracing saving culture for farming inputs, using slow release fertilizer

Consequences: Increased produce prices due to reduced yields, positive impact due to passable rural roads, leads to reduced output sales at higher prices, ready market
Ongoing adaptations: Reduced consumption of maize produce, introduction of pricing and movement policy concerning produce
Potential adaptations: Investment in food reserve mechanisms and development of sustainable government policies on maize produce

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Delayed rainfall onset will increase prices, early rainfall onset will reduce prices, early or late rainfall cessation will increase prices, grading is easier with early rainfall cessation but difficult with late rainfall cessation, early onset, late onset, and late cessation of rainfall will affect transportation negatively due poor roads or state of harvested produce while early rainfall cessation will have a positive impact
Ongoing adaptations: Using dryers and shellers, and sorting cobs, use of hermatic bags, insecticides usage, fumigation and warehouses, proliferation of small-scale millers
Potential adaptations: Adopt maize varieties that are not susceptible to lodging, disseminate dryer services to all farmers, and producer organizations should assist farmers in acquiring dryers, adopt warehouse receipt system and promote portable silo usage

Consequences: Ploughing land becomes difficult due to hard pans, poor seed germination, wilting of germinating shoots or seedlings and staggered growth or crop failure
Ongoing adaptations: Herbicides application to reduce livestock grazing which causes hardpans, harrowing of farms, application of conservation agricuture i.e minimum tillage, replanting, gapping and converting failed crop to silage, use of herbicides, weeding manually and integrated pest control
Potential adaptations: Use of farm machinery to break hard pan, use of cover crops to conserve moisture, use of planters, adoption of climate smart agriculture, avoid planting with manure and time application on the rainfall onset, promote biological weed control methods, research on weed tolerant varieties, and integrated pest management

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Repeating land preparation which increases cost of production, poor germination success resulting in replanting for those who are able, loss of yield due to planting after onset of rains, decay of maize in farm, difficulty in accessing farm during harvest due to muddy conditions and poor harvest if rainfall cessation comes early
Ongoing adaptations: Timely dissemination of information on the rainfall onset and cessation, mechanized planting, dry planting, irrigation if land is near water source, and relying on weather forecast
Potential adaptations: Application of conservation agriculture, adoption of hand planters for small scale farmers

Consequences: Enhances on farm drying of the crop which is a positive consequence for farms, there is less produce for shelling, makes the drying process easier, may cause fire outbreak on farm, less produce for storage
Ongoing adaptations: Influx of imported maize, planting maize for two seasons instead of one
Potential adaptations: Adopt seeds that can be grown for two seasons and improve on the strategic food reserves

Hazard: Uncertainity in the onset of rains and growing season
Consequences: Crop decays when rainfall cessation delays, afflatoxin build up on maize produce, prolonged season will damage stored product through decay, early cessation will positively impact on crop's drying process, uncertainty impacts produce availability for millers/processors
Ongoing adaptations: Market timing to sell at good prices (storage to time market), selling of green maize, aggregation of maize by small-scale farmers for better bargaining power, farmers prefer selling at farm gate, hiring of appropriate transportation through pooling, and temporary grading of roads, selling to brokers, change use of produce e.g use as animal feeds, sale to millers where there is scarcity
Potential adaptations: Increase of millers for value addition, price fluctuations and by-products, county government goodwill to encourage major millers in county, increase of number of millers and warehouses

Consequences: Heavy rains make it difficult for extension officers to reach farmers due to muddy roads, tools and equipment may not reach the farmers due to destruction of available infrastructure, low seed supplies
Ongoing adaptations: Extension services- phone calls are done to ensure farmers get the required information though in small-scale, tools and equipments- they use local methods or crop practices such as sticks to plant the seeds, seed supply adaptation- they use available seeds especially seeds from previous harvests
Potential adaptations: Extension services- promote extension services, promote localized trainers of farmers models, tools and equipment- early delivery of tools and equipment, seed acquisition- early delivery of seeds

Consequences: Extension services- provision of extension services is hampered greately as it can only be given to small-scale farmers living along water sources, tools and equipment- reduces supply of tools
Ongoing adaptations: Extension services adaptation- concentration of extension services to producing areas, tools and equipment- no adaptation, seed viability loss- no adaptation; late planting
Potential adaptations: Extension services- promote extension services, creation of awareness through tvs, radio etc, tools and equipment- promotion on the use of locally made equipment e.g jua kali, seed acquisition- improvement on storage facilities of seeds to maintain viability for long

Consequences: Linking fishermen to buyers, inaccessibility due to flooding since the road networks will be affected by floods, grading/weighing- it will be difficult to reach the market hence no jobs for grading or weighing
Ongoing adaptations: Linking viable mobile phone and reshedule delivery of dried fish, source for alternative jobs, rescheduling or postponing buying until they repair their stores
Potential adaptations: Supporting electronic fish marketing information systems (EFMLS), improving road infrastructure, relocating flood-prone markets to safer ground

Consequences: Linking fishermen to buyers - shrinking of the market, grading and weighing- due to low production there will be loss of jobs to those doing grading, stores owners lose income
Ongoing adaptations: NA
Potential adaptations: E-marketing with improved production, tenders and contracts, introduction to modern weighing and packaging machines, constructing modern aggregation stores

Consequences: Supply of equipment (gears and vessels), flooding will cut-off road network hence hindering supply, extension services- hampers movement of extension staff
Ongoing adaptations: Purchase enough raw materials and ready gears stock, passing information through mobile phones - providing extension services through calls or SMS, use of locally available materials like rafts
Potential adaptations: Enhance stocking of gears and vessels, promotion and adoption of digital extension services, promote and support use of local raw materials

Consequences: Supply of equipment- low supply of raw materials e.g timber for boat making, extension services- the uptake of knowledge and technology will be affected, reduced artisanal boat and fishing gear making
Ongoing adaptations: Use of alternative fiber-glass boats by the rich but not the poor
Potential adaptations: Promoting greater use of fiber-glass boats, extension services: promote farmer-to-farmer extension, promote and support use of locally available raw materials

Consequences: Gutting- there will be low quantity of fish to gut and cut threfore loss of jobs for the youth, washing- low quantity of water and poor quality of water which will affect fish quality, low fish production
Ongoing adaptations: NA
Potential adaptations: Use of cages to boost production, restocking and construction of fish ponds along riverside ecosystems

Consequences: Transportation- hampers transportation by cutting off roads, processing- flooding compromise water quality, destroy processing units, destroys packing units hence youths lose their jobs
Ongoing adaptations: No ongoing adaptation for fresh fish but dried fish are stored for later transportation however the fresh fish is sold at low prices, process the fish in small-scale in their houses using traditional means like salting, the youth seek alternative ways to earn a living such as basket weaving
Potential adaptations: Construction of modern fish processing units, improving the road networks, construction of modern processing units with clean water, construction of packaging units on raised grounds that are flood resillient

Consequences: Transportation- there will be low quantity to transport hence affects those dependent on transport business, processing- low supply of water for processing which will affect fish hygiene, low fish quantity to package hence job losses
Ongoing adaptations: NA
Potential adaptations: Unlock transportation with improved infrastructure, improved modern fish processing units, modern fish stores

Consequences: Floods destroy road networks, limited access to veterinary services and increased chicken diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Feed rationing
Potential adaptations: Establishment of feed reserves in higher safe places, establishment of proper early warning systems, strengthening community diseases reporters, establishment of drug stores on raised areas safe from flooding, establishment of hatcheries/incubators on higher grounds

Consequences: Inadequate feed supply- drought reduces feed supply thus low production, inability to access veterinary services and poultry inputs e.g drugs, during drought chicken are susceptible to diseases, poor poultry reproduction due to inadequate feeds
Ongoing adaptations: Destocking and feed storage, use of native herbs and establishment of community agro-vets (Naipi), supply of cockerells
Potential adaptations: Establishment of feed stockist in every sub county, government and development partners intervention through provision of subsidies on inputs (e.g voucher system), strengthen  the community disease reporters through capacity building, establishment of drug stores in each sub-county/wards, and employment of more veterinary officers by the government, provide incubator/hatcheries and introduce indigenous breeds because they are more resistant to drought

Consequences: Low selling- no networks to access the market, low promotion- low nutrition programmes promotion
Ongoing adaptations: Local selling within the villages
Potential adaptations: Low selling- establishment of groups and cooperative societies, low promotion- use of radio and phone calls to promote chicken/chicken products, repair of road networks and strengthen local marketing system at village level

Consequences: During drought more chicken are sold at low prices, high supply of chicken to the market
Ongoing adaptations: Traders buying in bulk and keeping live chicken, farmers look for more market points for the chicken, local communication through phones/verbal
Potential adaptations: Establishment of structured marketing system, farmers form cooperatives for marketing, chicken and products advertisement through radios, posters e.t.c

Consequences: Heavy rains causes limited time for selling and buying in markets, leads to increase in prices and causes difficulty in transporting goods to the market, pricing- due to heavy rains, the poor may not be able to transport their produce to markets where they can fetch good prices
Ongoing adaptations: Selling is postponed
Potential adaptations: Selling- promote market delivery and linkages through middlemen, pricing- promote contract farming linkage of farmers to buyers, improve social networks

Consequences: Selling-  reduced produce for sale, pricing-  increases market price due to inadquate supply
Ongoing adaptations: Buyers look for alternative grains and sellers incur low income, linkage of farmers to buyers- importation of produce
Potential adaptations: Encourage intensive farming methods, pricing- enactment of policies that control this trade; government and NGOs intervention through importation, linkage of farmers to buyers- enhance use of TVs and radio

Consequences: Poor land preparation and compaction, accelerated weed growth planting and weeding- sorghum requires minimum rainfall especially during planting and weeding, intense rainfall affects planting and weeding as extra labour is required to ensure proper growth
Ongoing adaptations: Zero tillage (no land preparation is done, instead direct planting is done), some done by government equipment, planting and weeding- planting method chop and plant, use of pangas to dig holes for planting and removal of weeds at early stage, harvesting adaptation- harvesting is done by cutting the head and placed in bags to minimize losses and contamination during harvesting
Potential adaptations: Land preparation- early land preparation, planting and weeding- use of herbicides, harvesting- enhance cutting and bulking

Consequences: High labor costs, water scarcity during planting causes crop failure, affects crop yield and may completely destroy produce
Ongoing adaptations: Irrigation schemes and livestock feeding
Potential adaptations: Land preparation- rely on weather forecasting data, planting and weeding- improvement of and encouraging of irrigation; enhance installation of solar panels harvesting- diversification of farmers to other sources of livelihoods

Consequences: Heavy rains affect processing since it makes drying of produce difficult and may cause rotting, it also causes wastage of produce storage- heavy rains affect produce and may lead to losses during storage of food or cereals, cool filthy conditions, hinders produce transportation from the farm to stores and markets which increases post-harvest losses
Ongoing adaptations: Processing adaptation- drying is done on farm or processing by putting sorghum heads into an open store to allow time to dry, storing adaptation- open storage in stores, transportation adaptation- transporting using donkeys and women carrying the produce
Potential adaptations: Processing- use of mechanic shelters and open drying in stores, storing- use of improved and well ventilated stores; use of hermetically sealable bags, transportation- improvement of roads from farms to markets

Consequences: Processing- lack of produce for processing, high cost of importation incurred by processors, drought reduces the produce and may make it difficult to have any food to store
Ongoing adaptations: Importing produce, transporters will transport commodities, buying small quantities of produce for survival
Potential adaptations: Encouraging large-scale production of sorghum through irrigation, improving/ promoting irrigation methods, livelihoods diversification

Consequences: Poor market accessibility and reduced source of income since few animals are accessing the market
Ongoing adaptations: Availability of markets at ward level
Potential adaptations: Insurance of animals, increase market centers, early warning system, improve accessibility to markets by improved transportation and communication infrastructure, provision of an insurance policy for compesation of lost animals

Consequences: Poor market price due to low quality of livestock selling at a loss and reduced income
Ongoing adaptations: No adaptation but coping mechanism e.g feeding on livestock during drought, intermittent in supply to some stakeholders
Potential adaptations: Early destocking, policy (destocking), insurance of animals and enhancing market places within the county

Consequences: Reduced livestock breeding, death of animals e.g young ones, and emergence of low quality animals, increased demand for deworming services hence increased costs, and delayed vaccination services due to floods
Ongoing adaptations: NA
Potential adaptations: Establishing flood early warning systems and mapping flood prone areas or zones, enhancing indigenous knowledge and extension services, capacity building on pests and diseases, establishing early warning system on pests and diseases

Consequences: Breeding- reduced and regulated breeding, death of high breed animals, deworming- reduced number of dewormed animals due to drought, reduced meat quality, death of animals in the long run
Ongoing adaptations: Use of herbal medicine and government intervention in deworming through scattered and intermittent government intervention by vaccination
Potential adaptations: Selective breeding of hardy species, capacity building on breeding to increase production, offtake of less adapted species (destoking), enhancement of indigenous knowledge, enhancement of government intervention withing Turkana county e.g extension services, research enhancement of vaccination across the county, early warning system (surveillance) and communication infrastructure e.g Safaricom, telecommunication lines

Consequences: Delays processing, poor network and impassable bridges, delayed transportation, bulking process delays and increase in bulking costs
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of bridges is ongoing and improvement of access routes
Potential adaptations: Construction of modernized meat processing unit within the county, mapping of flood prone areas, improvement of transport infrastructure (climate smart roads) and early warning system (enhacement of weather forecast), increase bulking areas within the county and proper selection of bulking areas

Consequences: Low productivity in terms of quality and quantity of meat due to drought, reduced income, reduced number of animals being transported and increased cost of transportation,  delayed bulking process due to scarcity of animals and increase in cost of bulking
Ongoing adaptations: NA
Potential adaptations: Using early warning systems, early destocking, constructing modernized meat-processing unit within the county; improving transport infrastructure (climate-smart roads) and mapping grazing routes for early access; mapping dry grazing areas for ease of access and increasing bulking areas within the county

Consequences: During drought the cost of transportation of chicken and its products increases, more farmers dispose their chicken/sell their chicken for processing since they have no feed to sustain them
Ongoing adaptations: Selling chicken as a group, feed supplimentation with local feed and keeping live chicken at slaughter houses, refrigeration to extend shelf-life and preservation
Potential adaptations: Farmers to start aggregation centres and improvement of road networks, establishment of cold chains i.e refrigeration, chilling e.t.c and establishment of standard chicken slaughterhouses, establishment of a chicken meat processing plant

Consequences: Vaccination- high demand for chicken vaccination, inadequate feeding- access to feed is cut-off
Ongoing adaptations: Feed rationing, high vaccination demand, transfering the chicken to people houses during refuge
Potential adaptations: High vaccination demand- establishment of cold chains on safe raised ground, establishment of early warning systems, establishment of stores on raised ground, capacity building for farmers and early warning system establishment, destruction of housing- chicken houses construction on higher grounds, proper designed and firm raised floors

Consequences: Drought causes low immunity of chicken therefore more vaccination is required, during drought the feeds will be inadequated thus low production and productivity
Ongoing adaptations: Provision of vaccines and suppliments, provision of feed suppliments and kitchen refuse and other remnants of human food
Potential adaptations: Establishment of cold chains for vaccines in each sub-county, employment and deployment of more veterinary officers by the government, increase the number of community disease reporters, and vaccination programmes, on-farm feed formulation and capacity building for farmers on better feeding programmes, construction of chicken housess suitable for dry areas and enhancing capacity building for farmers

Consequences: Cut-off of transportation- floods destroy transport networks, slaughtering- destruction of slaughter infrastructure e.g kanam, nakwanae kudi
Ongoing adaptations: NA
Potential adaptations: Building of bridges by government, maintance of the accessibility of roads, establishment of early warning system, proper design and construction of chicken slaughterhouses on raised grounds, capacity building for slaughterhouse workers, proper design and construction of processing facilities on safe areas

Consequences: Submerged grassing land, land degradation e.g soil erosion, and increase of invasive speciese.g. prosopis (mathenge) encroaches grazing land, submerged pasture and reduced quality of fodder due to erosion
Ongoing adaptations: Utilization of prosopis which spread during floods, soil and water harvesting through gabions and waterpans construction especially in lowland areas, early warning system, storage of feed and diversification of livelihood to crop farming
Potential adaptations: Enhance prosopis control through utilization, fast track formulation and operationarization of climate change policy bill and regulation, operationalization of water act policy, early warning system, enhance storage of feed, re-seeding of pasture land and tree planting, and mapping of wet and migratory routes and gazette them, diversification of livelihoods e.g bee keeping and poultry production

Consequences: Due to reduced fish production caused by flooding many youths and women lose their jobs, compromises water quality hence affect fish hygiene after washing, destroys the gears mounted in the lake
Ongoing adaptations: Do alternative jobs like weaving baskets, get alternative source of water from Napasinyan (Nakina wells), lending from the rich who own shops and pay using fish
Potential adaptations: Introduction of cage culture to boost production of fish, construction of modern fish bandas (structures) with piped water

Consequences: Land- shortage of water, loss of vegetation cover, land degradation (e.g soil erosion), feed- loss of vegetation cover (fodder), death of animals and prevelence of pests and diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Drilling of boreholes, water harvesting, water pans and dams, treeplanting (fodder trees) and water act policy, ekwar (use of enclosures), participating in rangeland management, storage of feed, water act policy and building peace across borders, cash transfers and diversification (e.g charcoal selling)
Potential adaptations: Fast track operationarization of Turkana county water act 2019 (sand dam, boreholes, waterpans and catchment protection), soil conservation intervention e.g tree planting, enhancing existing adaptation strategy e.g ekwar, conflict management within and across boarders, planting of drought tolerant fodder trees and shrubs e.g ewoi, ekunoit, edome, ekalale; enhance participatory range management policy- fast track formulation and operatiorazation of climate change policy, enhancement of cash transfer to reach a wider population, diversification of income e.g bee keeping, production of gum arabic, charcoal production

Consequences: Supply not able to meet demand, higher milk prices

Consequences: Quality deterioration and high perishability during transport to markets, high transportation costs due to low accessibility

Potential adaptations: Improvement of rural roads, improvement of market information

Consequences: Low quality eggs and chicks which are not preferred in the market and usually fetch low prices, low profits due to high mortality and high cost of production, impassable roads make marketing difficult, supply not meeting demand

Potential adaptations: Capacity building on marketing and sales, improved road networks for better access to the markets

Consequences: Increased costs of veterinary output, feed scarcity, reduced quantity and quality of pasture

Consequences: Low milk production, low fertility and reproduction rates, low weight gain, occurrence of mastitis hence no milk

Consequences: Land preparation is expensive, low germination rates, lack of synchronisation of farm activities

Consequences: Feed and fodder scarcity, reduced quantity and quality of pastures, increased costs of veterinary inputs

Consequences: Low prices due to destocking by farmers, reduced availability of milk and meat

Consequences: Shortage of milk and milk products, low quality of milk and meat products, increased demand for packaging and storage

Consequences: Low milk production, emaciation and death, increased susceptibility to pests and diseases hence death, lack of energy for draught power, affects labor of farm activities

Consequences: Reduced milk quality and quantity

Consequences: Low quality eggs and chicks, supply not able to meet demand, low prices

Consequences: Irregular market access and loss of marketing opportunities, market flooding hence low prices

Consequences: Poor timing in harvesting, losses of crops in the field, post harvest losses if cobs are not stored where they can dry properly

Consequences: Low production leads to high prices, shortages in local markets and in households

Consequences: Affects the availability of seed, high cost of seeds, delays in fertilizer /manure usage, leads to wastage of time bound fertilizers like organic, delayed acquisition of hired labor, and family labor will be idle thus increasing costs

Consequences: It hinders promotion due to risk of inadequate supply, increased costs of production, low volumes for sale hence increased product prices

Consequences: Loss of product to be promoted, loss of business, loss of trust, increased price along the value chain due to shortage

Consequences: Hinders timely land preparation, increases risk of soil erosion, increases cost of land preparation, delayed planting, poor germination due to seed wash, increased pest and diseases, delayed management practices, reduced rate of growth, loss of soil fertility due to leaching and erosion

Consequences: Loss of resources- cost of labour and time, increased cost of land preparation, delayed planting, poor germination, delayed routine management practices, delayed harvest, reduced yield

Consequences: Soggy unworkable soils, high cost of land preparations due to soils, destruction of soil structure, delayed establishment of the orchard, high labor costs during planting & weeding, delay in disease management (spraying), unfavorable weeding conditions resulting in poor workmanship

Consequences: Compromises germination percentage/ low germination rate, it makes planting difficult, leaching of nutrients, the lush pastures will cause bloat, excess rainfall will hinder feed delivery to the animal in time, slow growth rates hence scarcity of feed
