Consequences: Climate shocks (lack of rainfall, high temperatures) increases more during drought spells leading to lower productivity, vaccination exercise become expensive, increase in disease outbreaks, low hatching rates, high mortality rates and slow growth rates
Ongoing adaptations: To capacity train on feed formulation by use of local available ingredients to cope with drought spell, training of disease community reporters(DCR), on farm water harvesting, participatory scenario planning(PSP) for various weather and climate scenarios
Potential adaptations: Use of recommended disease management(vaccination, deworming) schedule, enhancing on farm water harvesting and storage facilities

Consequences: Linkages with buyers affected by high temperature while transporting chicken and eggs to their destination, high maintenance cost for vehicles, poor prices because of few quality products
Ongoing adaptations: Sales to middlemen, sharing of market information from farmer to farmer
Potential adaptations: Development of cooperatives for collective marketing, development of chicken and egg business plans for cooperatives and individuals, improved road networks for easier market acess

Consequences: Decreased number of farmers being linked because of low production due to drought spell, reduced prices of chicken and other products, inputs prices also increases
Ongoing adaptations: Local household consumption
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on marketing and sales, improved road networks for better access to the markets, government supported chicken sales during drought

Consequences: The chicken feeding habit is affected because they feed less, reduced production i.e less eggs and weight loss, increased costs due to high maintenance of cold chain, delay in implementation of vaccination progams
Ongoing adaptations: Participatory scenario planning (PSP) for various climate and weather scenarios, training of disease community reporters (DCR), improved ventilated chicken housing, feed supplementation(household waste)
Potential adaptations: Construction of improved temperature regulating enclosures

Consequences: Irregular/inadequate supply to markets, low prices for volumes and lower quality produce, difficulty in securing constant market
Ongoing adaptations: Use of display at market centres, sell by size, travelling to other external markets to seek for buyers
Potential adaptations: Organise group marketing through cooperatives, capacity building on sales by weight

Consequences: Lack of availability of seeds, reduced purchase of pesticides and other farm inputs, lower income for agro dealers
Ongoing adaptations: Variety selection, use of indigenous traditional knowledge
Potential adaptations: Capacity building on appropriate seed selection(short season and early maturing varieties), improved agrometeorological information and droughts early warning

Consequences: Reduced product for promotion, high market price due to limited supply
Ongoing adaptations: Display at market or roadsides, sell by size, travel to other places to look for buyers/customers
Potential adaptations: Use of social media, trade fares, agricultural show for marketing, use of weighing/measurement scale in kgs, use of mobile phone (SMS, WhatsApp) for marketing

Consequences: Delay in land preparation, untimely planting, reduced yield, uncertainty in pesticide application
Ongoing adaptations: Use of shallow wells and generators for irrigation, use of organic pest control methods, late planting with onset of rains
Potential adaptations: Promotion of solar powered irrigation, scaling up farmers field schools for shared learning, capacity building on IPM(neem and garlic seeds), capacity building on early planting

Consequences: Incurr more expenses to purchase seeds for planting, limited seed availability
Ongoing adaptations: Sharing weather and input information from farmer to farmer, variety selection(drought tolerant-crimson, sweet, sugar bay)
Potential adaptations: Use hybrid seed variety(Sukari F1, Asali F1), use of early maturing drought tolerant and high yielding varieties, use of irrigation infrastructure and water storage, group training use of organic pesticides for control of pests

Consequences: Low milk volumes collected/ reduced volumes for bulking, cost of transportation will rise as animals go deeper into far areas of better browse conditions, higher chances of more spoilage
Ongoing adaptations: Awareness raising on milk hygiene
Potential adaptations: Introduce solar powered refrigeration systems for cooling, establishment of a central processing plant, introducing special vehicles with cooling systems to transport the milk, establishing more collection/bulking/cooling points to other major towns, introducing specialized milk vessels

Consequences: Low linkages because most produce is consumed at home, high prices due to low supply vs high demand and inconsistent supply
Ongoing adaptations: Linking farmers to local traders, individual sales, local consumption
Potential adaptations: Collective marketing through cooperatives, enforced harmonized producer pricing mechanism

Consequences: No linkages as the product is consumed at household level, no service for extension, higher price for the product, high demand but low supply for the commodity, market opportunities underexploited
Ongoing adaptations: Use as animal feed, household consumption with minimal sales at local markets, sharing market information from farmer to farmer
Potential adaptations: Linking farmers to the external market, creating awareness on pricing information within and outside the county, capacity building on the use of by products as livestock feed, fuel

Consequences: Reduced land preparation, no germination, pesticide scorching by the sun during dry periods-results in higher chemical residue on the crop, increased presence of pests and diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Manual tilling of land with farm implements such as jembe, hoes and fork, haphazard scouting for pests capture and kill, uninformed/blanket use of pesticides and other chemicals
Potential adaptations: Conservation agriculture like minimum tillage, mulching, 10% tree cover in farm land, proper spacing/recommended, application of farm yard manure, supplement irrigation, use of modern sprayers such as knapsack, construction of water harvesting structures

Consequences: Money that could have been used for purchase of seeds could be diverted to other uses, mistrust between the farmer and service provider, limited seed availability
Ongoing adaptations: Drought escaping seeds (drought tolerant) seeds like crimsom sweet, sugar bay, use of generators and shallow wells, routine extension service visits, use of inorganic pesticides which have residual effect
Potential adaptations: Use of solar driven power for irrigation, use of drought tolerant, early maturing hybrid varities like Sukari F1, Asali F1, farmer field school, use of organic pesticides like neem plant seeds, garlic

Consequences: More resources due to increased distance covered since livestock are far away, additional transportation costs as bikes go deeper into interior areas to look for milk, cold storage costs increases
Ongoing adaptations: Establisment of milk cooler plants, use of passenger service vehicles and motorbikes in transporting to cooling facilities, consumption of milk at household level
Potential adaptations: Building more processing facilities at strategic routes, introducing refrigerated transport systems, upgrading market access roads, setting up more collection/bulking points even into the interior where camels would be migrating to, improving telecommunication systems into production areas

Consequences: Movement of extension service provider is reduced due to high temperatures, poor health of chicks and increased mortality, higher vaccines storage costs due to increased electricity costs for cold storage
Ongoing adaptations: Farmer to farmer sharing of information on changes in weather and climate, farmer to farmer information sharing on health management
Potential adaptations: Funding of radio programmes to share information on weather variability and climate change, purchase of refrigerated vaccine storage equipment, expansion of access to electricity for vaccine storage, development of small scale feed production facilities

Consequences: High chick disease prevalence, high mortality rate of chicks, diversion of extension services to emergency drought mitigation measures, feed shortages and increase in prices of inputs
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local ingredients to supplement feed, sharing of drought early warning information from farmer to farmer
Potential adaptations: Training of farmers on extension services on chicken and egg production during drought, local refrigerated storage of adequate medication and vaccinations for chickens, improved feed production, storage and conservation methods and facilities

Consequences: Livestock would be far away in search of feed resources making disease control complex, lost contact between extension staff and farmers since farmers would be far away with the livestock, pasture scarcity, higher electricity costs for cold storage of vaccinations
Ongoing adaptations: Disease surveillance/monitoring by farmers, farmer to farmer information sharing on browse and pasture availability
Potential adaptations: Border point disease surveillance, recruiting more technical staff, increase number of local mechandise supplying feed suppliments, drugs, training of community paravets, finalising and local level application of national livestock policy

Consequences: Reduced produce for storage and processing, reduced quantity and quality of crop
Ongoing adaptations: Traditional method of storing under the trees for shade, storage under sheets, hired labour for transporting the produce
Potential adaptations: Cool houses for longer shelflife, motor vehicle transportation, use of wheel barrows, use of cartons

Consequences: Inadequate produce for storage, reduced transport, severely reduced harvest
Ongoing adaptations: Under tree storage and iron sheet stores, use of donkey carts, casual labour, use of bags
Potential adaptations: Cool warehouses, well ventillated constructed houses, capacity building on value addition

Consequences: Linkages disrupted, less volumes available for sale, increased costs to market (all affect milk price at loss)
Ongoing adaptations: Individual sales at local market or to middlemen, use of passenger vehicles for transport to market
Potential adaptations: Establishment of incubation centres for farmers, farmer exchange programmes, establish designated milk selling stalls at designated markets, establish value addition technology centres/incubation centres for sustained knowledge dissemination, introduce refrigerated milk transport vehicles

Consequences: Untimely vaccination time as livestock owners move far away to better areas, vaccinations storage leading to more additional costs/expired distorted deworming/breeding programming, more resources spent to track livestock in far away areas
Ongoing adaptations: Disease surveillance/monitoring, health management (deworming and  hoof trimming), training and creation of awareness on milk hygiene
Potential adaptations: Expanding disease surveillance scope to all leaders of the county, finalizing livestock policy, training producers on basic herd health management aspects, attaching milk hygiene trainers to groups of producers, introducing recommended milk handling equipment

Consequences: More resources needed to buy vaccines, more resources required for routine practices, more resources for personnel to track and attend to livestock
Ongoing adaptations: Regular testing of livestock on diseases, regular training and capacity building on management of livestock health
Potential adaptations: Routine livestock disease testing to ascertain immunological status, sustained trainings on managing heat stress on the camels, acquisition of the recommended equipment for clean milk production and distributing to producer groups in a revolving model, training farmers on diagnosis and treatment of camel disease

Consequences: There will be soil compaction leading to extra ploughing and harrowing thus extra cost incurred to achieve the right tilth, exposing the crop soil cover to sun resulting to high evaporation of available moisture hence wilting of the crop, low germination rate and poor stand establishment
Ongoing adaptations: Making ridges and contours for moisture conservation, use of indigenous knowledge to inform planting
Potential adaptations: Construction of water harvesting structures, conservation agriculture, technical advice on use of mulching, cover crops and intercropping, technical use of selective herbicides, capacity building on integrated pests and disease management

Consequences: Low yields, poor quality produce, little processing
Ongoing adaptations: Early harvesting, household consumption with minimal value addition, use of traditional on farm storage structures
Potential adaptations: Construction of high quality storage facilities by government, use of modern pre and post harvest equipment and facilities to reduce losses, train farmers on modern storage structures, train farmers on value addition(processing and packaging)

Consequences: Unpredictability in timing of harvest period, reduced and inconsistent business and income for transporters and processors
Ongoing adaptations: Use of on farm storage facilities, local processing(store grinding)
Potential adaptations: Improved extension capacity on pre and post harvest management, capacity building on value addition, processing and packaging, improve accesss to extension advice(harvesting times)

Consequences: More disease control measures, little time for extension services, more resources required for stock control measures/interventions, increased costs of veterinary inputs
Ongoing adaptations: Movement of animals from place to place in search of browse, pasture and water, sharing of early warning information from farmer to farmer
Potential adaptations: Periodic disease surveillance and drought monitoring, animal body condition assessments developing a policy document setting a side a given number of county budget to support extension service provision, giving subsidies to farmer groups to set up local merchandise for input provision, improvement of drought and pasture/browse monitoring and information sharing systems

Consequences: Fewer producers/farmers will be reachable for linkages, reduced market information access, less volume of milk available for selling since camels are far away into the interior, low income due to high malnutrition levels
Ongoing adaptations: Group sales and marketing, using motorbikes to transport milk
Potential adaptations: Establishment of incubation centres for farmers, farmer exchange programmes, establish designated milk selling stalls at designated markets, establish value addition technology centres/incubation centres for sustained knowledge dissemination, introduce large vehicles with cold storage systems for milk transportation

Consequences: Extra cost to farmers by ploughing twice inorder to enhance aeration, quick emergence of weeds forcing the farmer to carry extra weeding, reduced harvests, uncertainty in planning farm operations
Ongoing adaptations: Practice of conservation agriculture (zero tillage), advice on early weeding, indigenous technical knowledge to inform seasonal activities
Potential adaptations: Training farmers on conservation agriculture, early land preparation campaign, construction of water harvesting structures, train farmers on use of herbicides and early weeding and use of mulching materials to supress weeds, capacity build farmers on pre and post harvest management

Consequences: Animal malnutrition, increased mortality, low reproductive rates, high prevalence of pests and diseases
Ongoing adaptations: Goat herding, controlled feeding, culling of weak animals, use of traditional medicines, use of traditional drought early-warning systems
Potential adaptations: Pasture conservation, improved access to vaccines, enforced culling during disease outbreaks, land conservation, enterprise diversification, access to modern early-warning systems advisories.

Consequences: Poor pasture quality, inadequate water supply, high demand for drugs from agrovets, high demand for extension services
Ongoing adaptations: Alternative feed resources, artificial insemination(AI) services, use of locally sourced improved bulls
Potential adaptations: Feed or fodder conservation technologies, capacity building for supplements preparation, pasture conservation and use of alternative pest and disease techniques, introduction of feed supplements

Consequences: High mortality rate, increased demand for veterinary services, reduction of goat population
Ongoing adaptations: Use of traditional herbs for treating the goats, tree planting for pastures, migration from flood-prone areas,  reliance on indigenous pastures, chemical control of pests and diseases, culling and vaccination, livestock diversification
Potential adaptations: Reafforestation and replanting of pastures, flood control and water capture measures, rangelands management

Consequences: Reduced meat and milk production
Ongoing adaptations: Use of traditional meat and milk preservation methods, farm gate disposal during intense drought
Potential adaptations: Access to modern milk and meat preservation methods, access to animal insurance programmes to cushion farmer goat losses

Consequences: Inadequate pasture water, pressure on extension services
Ongoing adaptations: Alternative feed resources, artificial insemination, using locally sourced improved bulls
Potential adaptations: Supplementary feeding

Consequences: Inaccessibilty to  farm inputs, lack of credit facilities, low use of mineral fertilisers
Ongoing adaptations: Use of certified hybrid seeds, moisture tolerant  varieties, reliance on informal seed systems, non-use of organic or non-organic fertilisers, use of polliated maize varieties
Potential adaptations: Promotion of moisture-tolerant varieties, upscale use of polliated varieties, county support for provision of inputs

Consequences: Reduction in milk and meat, increased incidence of milk and meat products spoilage, destruction of storage infrastructure
Ongoing adaptations: Use of traditional metod of meat preservation for instance smoking, value addition of stored milk products, use of refrigeration facilities
Potential adaptations: Adoption of modern technologies of meat preservation e.g refrigeration, training farmers on post harvest handling of goat products,rehabilitating the flooded areas, setting up a slaughter house and a meat processing plant, revive the hides and skin tannery

Consequences: Low pricing of bulb onions in the market, low bargaining capacity, low demand for the produce
Ongoing adaptations: Pricing of bulb onions, linkage of markets transport to market, bulb transport using locally available means
Potential adaptations: Formal marketing structures, collective market transportation, contract farming arrangements

Consequences: Inaccessibility to farms due to destruction of roads by floods, low sales of inputs(seeds) fertilisers,chemicals
Ongoing adaptations: Maintenance of roads to enhance acceessibility to farms and easy input supply, easy supply of farm input before the onset of rains, farm inputs offered on credit to facilitate easy planting
Potential adaptations: Construction of roads (all western roads) with drainage systems, strengthen easy supply of farm inputs, strengthening of credit facilities to farmers

Consequences: Changes in prices of inputs, deterioration of nurseries.
Ongoing adaptations: Use of certified seeds, drought scaping vareities, use of foliar fertilisers, use of drought tolerant varieties
Potential adaptations: Use of drought tolerant varieties, continuous use of foliar fertilisers to complement basal fertilisers, use of water efficient technologies

Consequences: Low volumes of bulked produce
Ongoing adaptations: Timely curing of bulb onions, proper grading, storing and packaging in nets, proper storage
Potential adaptations: Utilization of curing technique, packaging and storage in cold stores, improved access to modern storage facilities, promotion of value addition

Consequences: High incidence of pests, increased theft of maize due to scarcity
Ongoing adaptations: Maize stores for storage owned by famers, pest control, small scale milling
Potential adaptations: Upscaling to modern silos for storage, use of IPM practices

Consequences: Distortion of planting durations, poor productivity, increased incidence of pest and disease
Ongoing adaptations: Staggered planting, construction of soils and water structures, tree planting, agroforestry and crop rotation regimes, enterprise diversification
Potential adaptations: Promotion of conservation agriculture, awareness raising on soil and land management, agroforestry systems, viable tree systems

Consequences: Decreased production and quality of bulb onions, increased incidence of pest and crop failure
Ongoing adaptations: Utilization of drip irrigation, chemical control, conservation agriculture, crop rotation, cover crops
Potential adaptations: Hygiene of production site, integrated pest management, spraying, conservation agriculture, integrated with soil and water management technologies.

Consequences: High transportation costs due to destroyed roads, high post harvest losses, high storage costs
Ongoing adaptations: Use of above-ground storage facilities,  use of donkeys instead of lorries,trucks during flash floods, timely  harvesting, sorting and grading, curing to increase the shelf life, engagement in farmer cooperatives to facilitate bulb storage
Potential adaptations: Awareness raising on improved storage facilities, access to alternative methods for bulb storage, improved access to  early warning systems

Consequences: Increased market price
Ongoing adaptations: Use of local markets
Potential adaptations: Linkage with consumer organizations for profitable milk sales, enterprise diversification

Consequences: Low milk supply, poor quality of milk, increased market prices

Potential adaptations: Linkage with consumer organizations for profitable milk sales, enterprise diversification

Consequences: Demand for drought-tolerant seeds, high costs of mechanized equipment for production
Ongoing adaptations: Certified-hybrid maize seeds,  drought-tolerant varieties, use of open pollinated maize series
Potential adaptations: Certified drought tolerant maize varieties, use of farmyard and compost manure, upscaling use of open pollinated varities

Consequences: Inaccessibility to market, scarcity of animal feed by-products
Ongoing adaptations: Small-scale mining, sale of produce locally, low market activity and loss of job opportunities by traders
Potential adaptations: Improved roads linking farmers to markets, online marketing

Consequences: High cost of products due to low supply of produce, farmers incur losses from high post harvest losses, reduced market activities.

Potential adaptations: Develop crop insurance cover for farmers, expand existing number of stores to enhance storage, county support in seeking external markets and marketing opportunities

Consequences: Low pasture access, loss of vegetation cover, structure destruction, inaccessibility to inputs

Potential adaptations: Construction of flood resistant structures, improved access to extension service agents, construction of more livestock resources

Consequences: High labour costs, low availability of pasture, demand for animal drugs

Potential adaptations: Sourcing of hired labor, construction of storage structures, introduction of drought and disease resistant breeds

Consequences: Low market activity, low product supply, high market prices

Potential adaptations: Reliance on modern weather forecasting to predict suitable time for goats sales, cooperatives to bargain better market prices, county funds to cushion farmers from market losses

Consequences: Reduction goat sales, higher market demand and prices

Consequences: Low milk volume, high milk spoilage, poor milk quality, low household quality

Potential adaptations: Pasteurization and packaging,  cultured milk products, promotion of cooling structures in rural areas, using solar energy,

Consequences: Low milk volumes, high incidences of milk spoilage, high transportation costs, under-utilization of facilities, reduction in transporters.

Consequences: Malnutrition, poor animal vigor, increased disease incidence, high production costs, increased animal mortality

Potential adaptations: Modern certified vaccines, mechanization of dairy process

Consequences: Lack of pastures, high cost of operations, increased animal mortality
Ongoing adaptations: Regulating animal movement, sale of sick animals
Potential adaptations: Use of modern vaccines, modern feed conservation technologies, mechanization of dairy process

Consequences: Poor quality and quantity of harvested produce, increased seed spoilage, poor household food security, increased transportation and harvest labour costs

Potential adaptations: Land reclamation from floods, county support for shared storage facilities

Consequences: Soil erosion, stunted and weak plants, formation of gulleys, water logging, poor stand establishment, high pest and disease incidence, difficulties in field activities

Potential adaptations: Upscale of conservation agriculture, development of drainage structures

Consequences: Crop failure and pests and diseases, low crop production,
Ongoing adaptations: Staggered planting, use of small-scale conservation agriculture, irrigation
Potential adaptations: Upscaling of conservation agriculture, upscaling of irrigation, upscaling of the water harvesting technologies

Consequences: High maize prices, contractual feuds of markets
Ongoing adaptations: Stabilizationof maize prices through creation of maize reserves, form farmer unions to aid produce bargains
Potential adaptations: Online marketing (e-trading) platform, grain reserves for dry season milling, associations to link farmers to markets and improve their accessibility

Consequences: Fingerlings can be swept away and some can die, variable water flows, blockage of water ways by debris and garbage, destruction of infrastructure

Potential adaptations: Protection of water catchment areas, training farmers on dykes construction, training on soil awareness and soil conservation

Consequences: Increased evaporation reduces water levels which is not favourable for fish fingerlings - when water level goes down the fingerlings will not survive

Potential adaptations: Training on water harvesting techniques, introduce high quality species

Consequences: Low fish market supply due to oversupply and poor infrastructure

Potential adaptations: Improve access to foreign markets, high quality species, good storage facilities through incentives

Consequences: Promotion-there will be less fish to promote in the market, increased market prices
Ongoing adaptations: Supply of electricity and road infrastructure
Potential adaptations: Improved access to foreign market, good storage facilities, improved credit facilities, support investments, alternative energies for storage and transporting

Consequences: Loss of fingerlings and spawning grounds, damage to fishing nets
Ongoing adaptations: Proper pond siting, conservation of water of catchment areas, construction of dykes, treatment of wasted water
Potential adaptations: Training farmers on better pond construction methods, training on good pond siting, protection of water catchment areas, soil conservation, construction of dykes

Consequences: Interference with spawning sites, depletion of fingerlings stock
Ongoing adaptations: Proper siting of ponds, proper timing of rainfall onset, constructing water pans
Potential adaptations: Training farmers on proper pond siting, training on water harvesting techniques, protection of wet lands and water catchment areas, provide early warning systems to guide decision in water management

Consequences: Storage and cooling facilities destruction, delayed transportation of produce

Consequences: Increased cost of production and preservation to reach the markets while fresh, high rates of spoilage while reaching the market, reduced fish population and pond yields, harvesting premature fish

Potential adaptations: Installation of electricty at the landing sites, installation of solar poweed refrigerators, capacity building training on ice production at the site

Consequences: Low germination seeds, rotting of seeds and young plants due to excess water, leaching of the nutrients, poor access roads hamper the transportation of inputs(seeds, fertilisers)

Potential adaptations: Step up conservation agriculture to modulate soil water content, proper timing of farm practices according to weather forecast, use of farmyard manure alongside fertiliser to improve soil structure, use of appropriate technologies to drain off excess water

Consequences: Reduced seed viability, reduced input access and increased costs due to low supply

Potential adaptations: Use of drought tolerant varieties, upscale conservation agriculture to improve soil water content

Consequences: Poor access roads hamper the transportation of the produce, spoilage of produce in transit, low prices due to poor quality

Consequences: Prices go up due to low or no supply of the commodity, reduced marketing opportunities

Consequences: Few people will plant, wastage of fertiliser because it is unavailable for plants through leaching, water logging, increased pests and diseases incidence, poor seed germination, rotting of seed, stunted growth, poor  nutrient absorption, reduced herbicides efficiency

Potential adaptations: Conservation agriculture, proper timing and placement of fertilisers stay at crop root zone, use of FYM/compost manure to enhance soil structure and boost function of inorganic fertiliser, planting on ridges

Consequences: Heat stress, poor seed germination, stunted growth, flower abortion and poor seed production, accelerated plant development and reduction of grain filling period

Potential adaptations: Upscale conservation agriculture practices(crop rotation, cover crops, minimum soil disturbance), early warning systems, low cost irrigation structures, agroforestry

Consequences: Poor yields hence low volumes for packaging and storage, challenges in produce storage(spoilage due to high moisture), delayed transportation of storage

Consequences: Reduced yields, increased incidence of storage pests/rodents, poor produce quality and low quantity

Potential adaptations: Establish farm feed processing units, set up vaccine collection centres(sub county level), invest in water harvesting and storage facilities

Consequences: Increase in prices, low farmer sale prices(farm gate)

Consequences: Reduced feed quantity, increases cost of production, delayed vaccination and reduced effectiveness

Potential adaptations: Promotion of conservation agriculture to help in soil management, biological weed control using cover crops, integrated nutrient and water management practices, weather forecast services to guide on timely planting dates, use of drought tolerant varieties

Consequences: Reduced yields, reduced grain quality, dampening of the produce leading to rotting and aflatoxins
Ongoing adaptations: Improve cereal drying, construction of feeder roads to connect farms and main road networks, construction of cereal stores, promotion of cereal banking and post harvests cereal management, promotion of shelling machines
Potential adaptations: Construct post harvest handling infrastructure e.g. cereal driers and cereal stores, capacity building to farmers on post harvest handling, hand shelling machines, modify and improve road infrastructure

Consequences: Reduced plant populations and therefore yields, reduced quality for milling, reduced grain shelf life, increased incidences of pests, increased costs of storage for pesticides
Ongoing adaptations: Construction of local stores, capacity building on post harvest handling, use of pesticides
Potential adaptations: Maintenance of rural access roads and milling infrastructure, promoting the tertiary industry in the construction of storage facilities like the metal silos and PIC bags, promote cereal banking for easier management, farmers promoting farmer innovations in post harvest handling
